This program identified a mechanism common to the major forms of heart failure, whereby a key molecule that helps the heart's fuel generating machinery is depleted. Restoring levels of this molecule were able to recover the heart from heart failure in model systems, which will now be tested in patients in this application.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor John O'Sullivan, Doctor Sean Lal, Doctor Yen Chin Koay, Doctor Andrew Philp, Professor Sally Inglis, Rong Tian
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Cardiovascular medicine and haematology, Cardiology (incl. cardiovascular diseases)

Project Name: Advancing preclinical development of novel GPCR-targeted therapeutics for heart failure
Project Summary: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (where compliance of heart muscle is decreased, making the heart stiffer) is now the most prevalent form of heart failure, particularly women. Traditional heart failure drugs are ineffective here - new innovations in drug discovery are required. We have identified a novel drug discovery approach to target heart failure with preserved ejection fraction that has the potential to effectively address this urgent, unmet clinical need in women and men.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Rebecca Ritchie, Doctor Chengxue Helena Qin, Doctor Lauren May, Professor Jean Yang, Professor Grant Drummond, Professor Andrew Taylor, Doctor Kristen Bubb, Professor Stephen Nicholls, Doctor Alexander Pinto, Professor Paul Stupple, Professor Gemma Figtree, Doctor David Shackleford, Associate Professor Gabriele Schiattarella
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Cardiovascular medicine and haematology, Cardiology (incl. cardiovascular diseases)

Project Name: Gap Junction Modulation: A Novel Molecular Target in the Management of Ventricular Arrhythmia in Ischaemic Cardiomyopathy
Project Summary: Although decreased electrical conduction in the heart has been identified as a mechanism for ventricular arrhythmia that underlies sudden cardiac death following heart attack, there are no current treatment modalities that target this mechanism directly. We have developed novel therapeutic approaches to address this issue. Through this proposal, we will continue to expand our trajectory towards the clinical translation of this discovery by utilising gene therapy and other advanced therapeutics.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Eddy Kizana, Associate Professor Leszek Lisowski, Associate Professor Saurabh Kumar, Professor Ian Alexander, Doctor Dhanya Ravindran
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Cardiovascular medicine and haematology, Cardiology (incl. cardiovascular diseases)

Project Name: Novel, targeted therapies for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
Project Summary: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is the predominant form of heart failure with no effective treatment currently available. Inflammation and oxidative stress are the key factors driving HFpEF pathologies. The enzyme, namely, ASK1, is the convergent point of HFpEF pathologies and a potential therapeutic target. ASK1 inhibitors to be developed in this study will provide new treatment improving the management and quality of life for HFpEF patients.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor David Kaye, Doctor Guy Krippner, Associate Professor Bing Wang
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Cardiovascular medicine and haematology, Cardiology (incl. cardiovascular diseases)

Project Name: Post-thrombectomy intra-arterial tenecteplase for Acute manaGement of Non-retrievable thrombus and no-reflow in Emergent Stroke (EXTEND-AGNES TNK)
Project Summary: The EXTEND-AGNES TNK multicentre study will test whether adding tenecteplase, a powerful clot busting medication, during clot retrieval procedure will improve recovery by dissolving smaller and inaccessible blockages in the small arteries across 18 Australian major stroke centres. If effective, the study will bring a new treatment that can be immediately used in Australia to significantly maximise the effectiveness of current stroke treatment and improve stroke patients' outcome.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Felix Ng, Professor Geoffrey Donnan, Professor Timothy Kleinig, Professor Stephen Davis, Doctor Lan Gao, Professor Vincent Thijs, Professor Leonid Churilov, Professor Peter Mitchell, Doctor Fana Alemseged, Professor Patricia Desmond, Doctor Kathryn Hayward, Professor Bruce Campbell, Alice Ma
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Cardiovascular medicine and haematology, Cardiovascular medicine and haematology not elsewhere classified

Project Name: Impact of Total Arterial Revascularisation in Coronary Artery Surgery on cardiovascular, cerebrovascular and multiorgan outcomes - an RCT (TA Trial)
Project Summary: Coronary artery disease affects 4 million Australians annually and occurs in patients with multiple coexisting cardiovascular comorbidities undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery. Complications are related to failure of bypass grafts to remain open (patent). This multi-centre RCT proposes that the exclusive use of arterial grafts, vs some use of venous grafts (in addition to arterial grafts, - the current standard of care) will lead to improved patient outcomes and survival.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Alistair Royse, Professor Paul Bannon, Associate Professor Elaine Lui, Doctor Andrea Bowyer, Doctor Sandy Clarke-Errey, Professor Julian Smith, Professor Michael Vallely, Professor Christopher Reid, Professor Rinaldo Bellomo, Professor Colin Royse, Associate Professor David Eccleston, Professor Guy Ludbrook, Doctor David Tian
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Surgery

Project Name: Neonatal probiotics to prevent early-onset acute respiratory infections (ARIs) in high-risk children: A multisite randomised controlled trial (RCT)
Project Summary: Acute respiratory infections (ARIs) are a leading cause of hospitalisation and preventable death among Aboriginal infants. The first microbes encountered by the infant gut shape systemic immune development and future susceptibility to infection. Through an international partnership, we propose a randomised controlled trial to determine if neonatal probiotics can reduce the risk of ARI in the first year of life. Secondary aims will evaluate safety, the gut microbiome and immune development.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Michael Binks, Professor Peter Morris, Associate Professor Peter Richmond, Ms Amy Bleakley, Professor Anne Chang, Professor Mike Taylor, Doctor Celestine Aho, Professor William Pomat, Doctor Dennis Bonney, Doctor Anita van den Biggelaar, Doctor Robyn Marsh, Ms Adrienne Kirby

Project Name: Strategies and Treatments for Respiratory Infections and Viral Emergencies (STRIVE)
Project Summary: Despite highly active treatments for people with early COVID-19 infection, therapies for people who have severe disease are much less effective. A global master platform study called STRIVE has commenced to study the most effective treatments and strategies in people who are hospitalised with severe respiratory illness. The first trial in this platform will study a novel antiviral drug for COVID-19. This application aims to support ten Australian sites to join this new international network.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Gail Matthews, Professor Mark Boyd, Associate Professor Janine Trevillyan, Associate Professor Stuart Turville, Doctor Susan Maddocks, Associate Professor James Robinson, Doctor Nila Dharan, Associate Professor Bridget Barber, Professor Gregory Dore, Associate Professor Benjamin Rogers, Associate Professor Claudia Dobler, Professor Anthony Kelleher, Associate Professor James McMahon, Professor Steven Tong, Professor Virginia Wiseman
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Infectious diseases

Project Name: Title Closed-loop Insulin delivery by glucose Responsive CompUter algorithms In Type 1 diabetes pregnancies (CIRCUIT)
Project Summary: Many (>50%) newborns of pregnant women with type 1 diabetes (T1D) are harmed by abnormal glucose exposure in the womb. With Canadian researchers, we will randomly assign women to use a new automated insulin delivery approach or standard insulin delivery and test whether blood glucose is improved, birth complications reduced and diabetes self-care demands lessened. Findings could result in more effective and easier ways for women with T1D to have healthier pregnancies and children.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor David Simmons, Doctor Sarah Price, Associate Professor Glynis Ross, Doctor Wadad Tannous, Doctor Arianne Sweeting, Professor Dharmintra Pasupathy, Professor Christopher Nolan, Doctor Melinda Morrison, Mrs Simone Marschner, Professor Ngai Cheung, Renza Scibilia, Professor Denice Feig, Mrs Romina Zappulla, Professor Lois Donovan

Project Name: The E2CAR Trial:A Phase I clinical trial to evaluate administration of EphA2 targeted CAR T cells to children with sarcoma
Project Summary: Solid tumour sarcomas in children are rare cancers that can recur, become treatment resistant, or spread in the patient by the time of diagnosis. Immunotherapies which direct a patient's immune system to attack their cancer can be curative in childhood leukaemias, but untested against sarcomas. The E2CAR trail will test the administration of immunotherapy to children with incurable sarcomas as a first step in developing effective curative treatments to offer when standard therapies have failed.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Geoffrey McCowage, Doctor Caroline Bateman, Doctor Kavitha Gowrishankar, Doctor Lucy Cain, Doctor Smadar Kahana-Edwin, Professor Geraldine O'Neill, Professor Ian Alexander, Professor Jonathan Karpelowsky, Professor Peter Shaw, Professor Stephen Gottschalk
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Oncology and carcinogenesis, Cancer therapy (excl. chemotherapy and radiation therapy)

Organisation: The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: ADAPT (Achieving Durable remission via Adaptive Pro-survival Targeting in Acute Myeloid Leukaemia)
Project Summary: This proposal will create a new trial called ADAPT to establish novel regimens to enhance outcomes among older patients with acute myeloid leukaemia who have a sub-optimal response to venetoclax, which was pioneered by this research team. We will also investigate how to deliver therapy more safely, ceasing treatment in those with a low chance of relapse guided by sensitive technologies and optimising use of antibiotics to manage low blood counts to reduce the risk of antibiotic resistance.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Andrew Wei, Associate Professor David Westerman, Associate Professor Michelle Yong, Associate Professor Piers Blombery, Doctor Carolyn Grove, Doctor Chong Chyn Chua, Doctor Ing Soo Tiong, Doctor Michelle Tew, Doctor Natasha Anstee, Doctor Tim Spelman, Professor Andrew Roberts, Professor David Ritchie, Professor Karin Thursky, Professor Monica Slavin, Professor William Stevenson
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Oncology and carcinogenesis, Haematological tumours

Project Name: Generating new evidence to reduce complications and improve the safety and efficacy of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) in patients with severe cardiac and respiratory failure: THE RECOMMEND Platform Trial
Project Summary: Patients in Australia who are admitted to intensive care with very severe failure of the heart or lungs may receive extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) if other forms of life support fail. ECMO is a device that acts like a heart-lung bypass, but over 50% of these patients die and survivors are often left with significant disabilities. This trial will determine the optimal treatments for patients on ECMO to improve survival and reduce disability.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Carol Hodgson, Associate Professor Neil Orford, Associate Professor Priya Nair, Associate Professor Vincent Pellegrino, Doctor Aidan Burrell, Doctor Alisa Higgins, Doctor Ary Serpa Neto, Doctor Elizabeth Ryan, Professor David J. (Jamie) Cooper, Professor Eddy Fan, Professor John Fraser, Professor Stephane Heritier, Professor Zoe McQuilten
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Intensive care

Project Name: Optimising the treatment of antibiotic resistant urinary tract infections in children: The FOSUTI Trial
Project Summary: Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are one of the most common bacterial infections affecting children worldwide, and increasingly, these are caused by drug-resistant infections as antibiotic resistance spreads globally. Currently, children require admission to hospital to be treated with antibiotics (via a drip) to treat these infections. We aim to show that a safe, tolerable antibiotic (fosfomycin) can be is used to treat UTIs in children, with just a single oral dose required for most infections.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Phoebe Williams, Associate Professor Adam Irwin, Associate Professor Amanda Gwee, Associate Professor Martin Howell, Doctor Daniel Yeoh, Doctor Khandoker Shuvo Bakar, Doctor Philip Britton, Doctor Shannon McKinn, Mr James Totterdell, Professor Christopher Blyth, Professor Thomas Snelling

Project Name: The Cannabidiol First-Episode Psychosis Study
Project Summary: Two thirds of young people with psychosis do not respond to antipsychotic medication during initial treatment and therefore are switched to a second or third antipsychotic with a similar mechanism of action. Since cannabidiol, a non-intoxicating part of the Cannabis plant, does not appear to depend on the same mechanism, this agent may represent a new class of treatment psychosis when treatment with conventional antipsychotic medication as sole antipsychotic agent has a low success rate.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor G. Paul Amminger, Associate Professor Simon Rice, Doctor Hok Pan Yuen, Doctor Long Le, Doctor Richard Kevin, Professor Alison Yung, Professor Andrew Thompson, Professor Ashleigh Lin, Professor C. Barnaby Nelson, Professor Kelly Allott, Professor Patrick McGorry
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Psychiatry (incl. psychotherapy)

Project Name: A Phase 2, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of sodium selenate as a disease modifying treatment for chronic drug resistant temporal lobe epilepsy (SELECT Trial)
Project Summary: We propose the world’s first clinical trial of a drug treatment (sodium selenate) to reduce the severity of a common and poorly controlled type of epilepsy – Temporal Lobe Epilepsy (TLE). Current medical treatments for this condition fail to control the seizures in at least 30% of patients. This trial will investigate whether 6 months treatment will have a longer-term effect to reduce the number of seizures, and improve wellbeing and quality of life.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Terence O'Brien, Associate Professor Charles Malpas, Associate Professor Lucy Vivash, Associate Professor Pablo Casillas Espinosa, Associate Professor Patrick Carney, Doctor John-Paul Nicolo, Doctor Lisa Gillinder, Doctor Nicholas Lawn, Professor Christopher Hovens, Professor Dennis Velakoulis, Professor Leonid Churilov, Professor Mark Cook, Professor Patrick Kwan, Professor Piero Perucca, Professor Sandy Shultz
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Neurosciences, Central nervous system

Project Name: Interfant-21: A new international clinical trial for infants diagnosed with KMT2A-rearranged acute lymphoblastic leukaemia
Project Summary: Infants diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) have poor outcomes. Rearrangements of the KMT2A gene are present in up to 80% of infants with ALL and have exceptionally low survival rates of less than 40%. Interfant-21 is an international clinical trial that will test whether the addition of a novel immunotherapeutic agent, blinatumomab, to standard chemotherapy can improve survival in infants diagnosed with KMT2A-rearranged ALL.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Rishi Kotecha, Associate Professor Andrew Moore, Doctor Janine Stutterheim, Doctor Matthew O'Connor, Doctor Michelle Henderson, Doctor Michelle Martin, Doctor Seong Lin Khaw, Ms Robyn Strong
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Oncology and carcinogenesis, Cancer therapy (excl. chemotherapy and radiation therapy)

Project Name: PRioRTI: PReventing chronic pain after whiplash Road Traffic Injury
Project Summary: After a whiplash injury sustained in a road traffic crash, up to 50% of people will develop chronic pain and disability. Doctors are increasingly using pregabalin for acute whiplash, even though it is not a recommended treatment. Our pilot trial showed promising effects of pregabalin to prevent chronic pain after whiplash injury. We will conduct a large and definitive trial to determine if these effects are real.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Michele Sterling, Associate Professor Jane Nikles, Doctor David Klyne, Doctor Jennifer Setchell, Doctor Rachel Elphinston, Emeritus Professor Geoffrey Mitchell, Professor Antonio Celenza, Professor Chung-Wei Christine Lin, Professor Luke Connelly, Professor Michael Dinh, Professor Paul hodges, Professor Robert Ware, Professor Stephan Schug
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Clinical sciences not elsewhere classified

Project Name: Preventing bronchiectasis in children: A multicentre randomised controlled trial and cohort study
Project Summary: Our consumer co-designed proposal responds to internationally identified clinical needs and research gaps. In children with chronic wet cough, we will link carefully collected clinical characteristics with novel omics data obtained from blood and airway specimens using state-of-the-art technology. We will also undertake a multi-centre randomised controlled trial aimed to prevent bronchiectasis and other clinical outcomes of children with chronic wet cough who have high-risk trait.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Anne Chang, Associate Professor Gabrielle McCallum, Associate Professor Katherine Baines, Associate Professor Robyn Marsh, Doctor Danielle Wurzel, Doctor Hannah O'Farrell, Doctor Vikas Goyal, Emeritus Professor Keith Grimwood, Professor Andre Schultz, Professor Hiran Selvadurai, Professor Julie Marchant, Professor Shyamali Dharmage, Professor Stephanie Yerkovich, Professor Steven McPhail
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Cardiorespiratory medicine and haematology, Respiratory diseases

Project Name: Individualised blood pressure targets versus standard care among critically ill patients with shock - a multicentre randomised controlled trial
Project Summary: Shock is a common cause of death in ICU. Nearly all patients with shock need medications to support their blood pressure (BP). Current practice of standard BP target is a one-size-fits-all approach. Targeting patients' usual pre-illness BP in ICU has not been tested in an RCT. Therefore, we aim to investigate whether BP targets that approximate patients' own pre-illness BP readings can potentially improve the rates of death and major adverse kidney events at day 14 among ICU patients with shock.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Rakshit Panwar, McNicholas Bairbre, Winston Cheung, Associate Professor Jayesh Dhanani, Associate Professor Peter Kruger, Assistant Professor Joao Teixeira, Doctor Amit Kansal, Doctor Krishna Sunkara, Doctor Mahesh Ramanan, Doctor Paul Secombe, Doctor Shailesh Bihari, Professor Alistair Nichol, Professor Kiran Shekar, Professor Marlies Ostermann, Professor Ravindranath Tiruvoipati
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Intensive care

Project Name: INCremental dialysis to improve Health in people starting HaemoDialysis (INCH-HD)
Project Summary: When, and how often, to start haemodialysis (HD) is an important decision. Most patients start HD three times per week (conventional HD), however this approach may not be suitable for all patients; there is some evidence it may actually be harmful. An alternative approach is to start a less frequent twice-weekly (incremental) HD routine. The INCH-HD trial will test if incremental HD preserves the quality of life of patients and families and is a safe, practical, cost effective treatment option.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor David Johnson, Associate Professor Andrea Viecelli, Associate Professor Matthew Roberts, Doctor Ginger Chu, Doctor Martin Wolley, Doctor Nicole Scholes-Robertson, Ms Elaine Pascoe, Professor Allison Jaure, Professor Carol Pollock, Professor Charmaine Lok, Professor Kirsten Howard, Professor Peter Kerr, Professor Rathika Krishnasamy, Professor Robert Walker, Professor Stephen McDonald
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Nephrology and urology

Project Name: Neurostimulation to improve walking after spinal cord injury
Project Summary: This randomised controlled trial (RCT) will determine if transcutaneous spinal electrical stimulation combined with locomotor training can restore walking ability in people with spinal cord injury. The trial will include people with incomplete SCI from Sydney, Melbourne, and Perth. We will also examine the effects on neurological function, spasticity, neuropathic pain and quality of life. We expect that any physical improvements will also improve mental wellbeing and functional independence.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Jane Butler, Doctor Bon San Lee, Doctor Elizabeth Bye, Doctor Marnie Graco, Doctor Martin Heroux, Doctor Peter Humburg, Professor Gavin Williams, Professor Lisa Harvey, Professor Simon Gandevia, Professor Stephen Goodall
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /:
MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Physiotherapy;
MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Neurosciences, Neurosciences not elsewhere classified

Project Name: Restoration of Respiratory and Upper Limb function after cervical spinal cord Injury (RRULI)
Project Summary: Exercise for people with longstanding spinal cord injury makes weak muscles stronger, but weakness returns when exercise training stops. We have early evidence that both electrical stimulation of the spinal cord through the skin, and breathing very short bursts of low oxygen levels, when added to exercise training, may produce longer lasting benefits. This trial will determine which combinations of these treatments shows the most promise.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor David Berlowitz, Associate Professor Emily Fox, Associate Professor Kathryn Hayward, Doctor Claire Boswell-Ruys, Doctor Kate Carey, Doctor Nicole Sheers, Professor James Middleton, Professor Janet Taylor, Professor Leonid Churilov, Professor Mark Howard
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /:
MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Neurosciences, Neurosciences not elsewhere classified;
MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Physiotherapy

Project Name: Randomized E-hypnotherapy for Chronic Pelvic Pain Syndrome Trial (REST)
Project Summary: Chronic pelvic pain syndrome impacts up to 20% of Australians. It is associated with poor quality of life and psychological health, but the effective treatment is lacking. Hypnotherapy is known to improve mental health and pain. Our pilot studies showed that hypnotherapy might help to treat depression, anxiety and pelvic pain. This study will examine whether hypnotherapy improves pain, mental health, and quality of life as compared to relaxation alone and a waitlist group over 12 months.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Antonina Mikocka-Walus, Associate Professor Nikki McCaffrey, Associate Professor Simon Knowles, Associate Professor Subhadra Evans, Doctor Anna Klas, Ms Katherine Stanley, Professor Adrian Esterman, Professor Jane Andrews, Professor Matthew Fuller-Tyszkiewicz

Project Name: ReconNECKt: A randomised placebo-controlled trial to test the safety, clinical and cost effectiveness of a new treatment for chronic neck pain
Project Summary: Chronic neck pain is a common problem that comes at great personal, economic and social cost. It has been recognised as a high priority problem by consumers, industry and government. Our project is a randomised clinical trial to test the safety and effects on pain, function and quality of life, and cost-effectiveness of a new treatment for chronic neck pain that is based on modern neuroscience. We will compare our treatment to a carefully designed placebo treatment.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor G. Lorimer Moseley, Associate Professor Natasha Stanton, Doctor Aidan Cashin, Doctor Daniel Harvie, Doctor Emma Karran, Doctor Rutger de Zoete, Doctor Sarah Wallwork, Professor Benedict Wand, Professor James McAuley, Professor Michele Sterling, Professor Stephen Goodall, Professor Trudy Rebbeck
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Physiotherapy

Project Name: Modulating stem cell differentiation in individuals with high risk clonal haematopoiesis: the MOSAIC trial
Project Summary: Throughout life, our blood stem cells acquire mutations in their genes. Some mutations allow those stem cells to dominate blood cell production, a phenomenon called clonal haematopoiesis. Many complications of ageing, including blood cancers, heart disease, and infections, are connected to these mutations. We will attempt to reverse the effects of these mutations using a new treatment we developed to restore normal stem cell production, with the goal of preventing the complications of ageing.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Mark Polizzotto, Teresa Neeman, Tracy Murphy, Yogen Saunthararajah, Doctor George Vassiliou, Doctor Julie Thoms, Doctor Nila Dharan, Doctor Peter Campbell, Doctor Stephanie Ward, Professor Eric Stone, Professor John Pimanda, Professor Kathy Petoumenos, Professor Mark Hertzberg, Professor Miles Davenport, Professor Stefan Bohlander
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Oncology and carcinogenesis, Haematological tumours

Organisation: Australia New Zealand Gynaecological Oncology Group
Project Name: Tailored adjuvant therapy in POLEmut & NSMP early stage endometrial cancer (TAPER)
Project Summary: The number of endometrial (uterine) cancer (EC) cases in Australia is rising rapidly. Research advances mean biological (molecular) markers in tumour samples can identify a specific group of EC patients who will have exceptionally good survival, and who might not need either chemotherapy or radiotherapy after surgery, saving the patient long term side effects and reducing treatment costs overall. This clinical trial will implement molecular testing of EC to avoid unnecessary toxic therapies.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Alison Brand, Associate Professor Lyndal Anderson, Associate Professor Orla McNally, Associate Professor Yoland Antill, Doctor Bryony Simcock, Doctor Pearly Khaw, Doctor Viet Do, Mrs Constanza Vargas, Ms Kathryn Cornthwaite, Professor Caroline Ford, Professor Haryana Dhillon, Professor Jessica McAlpine, Professor Martin Oehler, Professor Paul Cohen
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Oncology and carcinogenesis, Molecular targets

Project Name: Targeted, Adaptive Genomics for Ethical, Evidence-based Expansion of Newborn Screening: a type II hybrid effectiveness-implementation trial
Project Summary: Every year thousands of Australians suffer unnecessary death or disability from treatable genetic conditions because effective screening is unavailable. We have developed and tested a way to screen newborns using genomics for 53 treatable health conditions. This project will introduce this screening approach into healthcare to see how effective it is at identifying treatable genetic conditions in newborns, the impact on parents, and what health system factors contribute to its success.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Natalie Taylor, Amy Peterson, Associate Professor Bonny Parkinson, Associate Professor Timothy Dobbins, Doctor Bennett Shum, Doctor Brittany McGill, Doctor Carolyn Mazariego, Doctor Denis Bauer, Doctor Jacobus Ungerer, Doctor Jing Pang, Doctor Varinder Jeet, Professor Claire Wakefield, Professor Gerald Watts

Project Name: Delayed cord clamping in babies born before 37 weeks gestation to prevent anaemia, death and disability (WAMM - Wait a Minute or More): a pragmatic stepped-wedge implementation trial
Project Summary: Every year, more than 25,000 Australians are born preterm, before 37 weeks of pregnancy. A few of them need immediate help to breathe. But for the others, waiting to clamp the umbilical cord 60 seconds or more after birth reduces anaemia and improves healthy long term survival. This project will involve staff and parents in maternity hospitals across Australia. It will test how to bring the benefits of "waiting a minute or more" before clamping the cord to as many preterm babies as possible.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor William Tarnow-Mordi, Associate Professor Amy Keir, Associate Professor Christoph Lehner, Associate Professor Malcolm Battin, Doctor Dennis Bonney, Doctor Himanshu Popat, Doctor Kristy Robledo, Doctor Naomi Spotswood, Professor Adrienne Gordon, Professor Graeme Polglase, Professor Kei Lui, Professor Khalid Aziz, Professor Sailesh Kumar, Professor Tobias Strunk
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Paediatrics and reproductive medicine, Obstetrics and gynaecology

Organisation: St Vincent's Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: A Randomised Controlled Trial to Assess if the Implementation of an Artificial Intelligence Mammogram Reader Improves Breast Cancer Screening
Project Summary: One million women annually are screened for breast cancer. Early detection reduces the risk of dying however mammographic interpretation is challenging. The project will provide implementation evidence of the effectiveness of an AI mammogram reader in breast cancer screening to improve accuracy and experience. Ultimately this can enable a more effective and personalised BreastScreen service to women.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Helen Frazer, Associate Professor Graham Hepworth, Associate Professor Michelle Reintals, Associate Professor Peter Brotchie, Doctor Davis McCarthy, Doctor Jocelyn Lippey, Doctor Lauren Oakden-Rayner, Doctor Mark Howard, Professor Dennis Petrie, Professor Robert Sparrow

Project Name: Identifying Advanced Liver Fibrosis in Primary Care
Project Summary: Significant scarring of the liver typically causes no symptoms until life-threatening complications occur such as liver cancer and liver failure when it is too late to treat its cause or provide care to prevent complications. This trial will examine whether using computer software integrated into a general practice and combined with new diagnostic tests will increase the detection of advanced liver fibrosis in patients with risk factors for liver disease who attend their general practitioner.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Leon Adams, Associate Professor Jo-Anne Manski-Nankervis, Associate Professor Nicole Rankin, Associate Professor Patty (Panagiota) Chondros, Doctor Andrew Kirke, Doctor Barbara de Graaff, Professor Alexander Thompson, Professor Douglas Boyle, Professor Gary Jeffrey, Professor Jon Emery
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Gastroenterology and hepatology

Project Name: Just Say No to the Just in Case Cannula: An Implementation Science Trial with Roadmap for National Roll Out
Project Summary: Have you or your family ever waited for care in an ED and wondered what the nurses and doctors were doing? They may have been inserting a ‘Just In Case Cannula’ (IV), in the belief that they were being safe, caring clinicians. However, IVs are painful to insert, have serious side effects and come at a high cost. Up to half of IVs are not used for any treatment. We plan to improve cannula use and safety in EDs nationally. We will ensure value for money, reduce waste and drive national uptake.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Diana Egerton-Warburton, Doctor Long Le, Associate Professor Lisa Kuhn, Associate Professor Joanne Enticott, Associate Professor Leah Heiss, Associate Professor Paul Buntine, Associate Professor Viet Tran, Professor Claire Rickard, Professor Daniel Fatovich, Professor Gerard O'Reilly, Professor Gerben Keijzers, Professor Helena Teede, Professor Julia Morphet, Professor Louise Cullen, Professor Peter Cameron

Project Name: The CONSEP trial: Implementing screening for a hidden cause of hypertension
Project Summary: One in 3 adult Australians have high blood pressure (HBP) and 10% of them have a condition called primary aldosteronism (PA). PA makes HBP hard to control and leads to strokes, heart attacks and kidney failure. While easy to detect with a blood test, GPs hardly ever order this test to check for PA in patients with HBP. CONSEP will test a new strategy to help GPs find patients living with PA, opening the door to better outcomes for those living with this very treatable condition.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Jun Yang, Doctor Heather Morris, Doctor Stella Gwini, Professor Christopher Reid, Professor Gang Chen, Professor Grant Russell, Professor Helen Skouteris, Professor Mark Nelson, Professor Michael Stowasser, Professor Nigel Stocks, Professor Peter Fuller

Project Name: A programme to improve medical follow-up and health outcomes for First Nations children hospitalised with lung infections
Project Summary: First Nations children have high rates of lung disease. Those who have been hospitalised with a lung infection are at higher risk. Our research aims to reduce this burden of chronic lung disease. With a culturally secure, cooperative approach, parents will be empowered to recognise key symptoms and seek help. The research will also improve how this condition is managed by clinicians in primary care and hospitals. The goal is improved lung health outcomes for First Nations children.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Pamela Laird, Doctor Matthew Cooper, Professor Andre Schultz, Professor Anne Chang, Professor Fenella Gill, Professor Maree Toombs, Professor Richard Norman, Professor Roz Walker

Project Name: CoDeEndo: Co-Designing, Evaluating, and Implementing Supportive Care for Endometriosis
Project Summary: Impacting 1 in 10 women, endometriosis is under-recognised. Usual care, comprised of hormone and pain medications, has limited efficacy, is associated with considerable side effects, and discontinued by 40% of patients. Surgery often fails to prevent recurrence of disease. Comprehensive management of chronic pain is urgently needed to address the poor QoL of 830,000 Australians with endometriosis. This project will evaluate and implement a person-focused supportive care model for endometriosis.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Antonina Mikocka-Walus, Associate Professor Heidi Staudacher, Associate Professor Mike Armour, Associate Professor Nikki McCaffrey, Associate Professor Subhadra Evans, Doctor David Skvarc, Ms Katherine Stanley, Professor Alison Hutchinson, Professor Felice Jacka, Professor Jason Abbott, Professor Liliana Orellana, Professor Patricia Livingston
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Public health and health services, Preventive medicine

Project Name: Comparative Effectiveness of Ketamine and Esketamine in Treatment Resistant Depression
Project Summary: Ketamine is a highly effective new treatment for treatment-resistant depression. Two main forms of ketamine are available in Australia, a patented new drug, and a generic form of ketamine widely available at low cost. This will be the first study to directly compare these two forms of ketamine, in terms of effectiveness, acceptability, safety and cost effectiveness.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Colleen Loo, Associate Professor Shanthi Sarma, Doctor Adam Bayes, Doctor Donel Martin, Doctor Mary Lou Chatterton, Doctor Stevan Nikolin, Mr Dusan Hadzi-Pavlovic, Ms Karen Wells, Professor Anthony Rodgers, Professor Christopher Davey, Professor Malcolm Hopwood, Professor Nicholas Glozier
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Psychiatry (incl. psychotherapy)

Project Name: iCare – An interactive online portal to improve health and wellbeing for people living with complex cancers, and their informal carers: a Phase II randomised controlled trial
Project Summary: Our proposed study addresses an area of high-unmet need related to chronic, complex cancers. Our Phase II trial will test the feasibility and acceptability of a co-designed interactive web-based portal, that supports people with upper GI cancers, the burden experienced by carers, and the unmet needs of both groups. The results will inform a hybrid implementation trial to deliver meaningful health impacts to carers and people with cancer.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Patricia Livingston, Associate Professor Neil Orford, Associate Professor Nicole Kiss, Associate Professor Nikki McCaffrey, Doctor Natalie Winter, Professor Alison Hutchinson, Professor Andrew Barbour, Professor Anna Ugalde, Professor Antonina Mikocka-Walus, Professor Bernard Smithers, Professor David Watson, Professor John Zalcberg, Professor Liliana Orellana, Professor Michael Jefford, Professor Victoria White
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Public health and health services, Health counselling

Project Name: Sugammadex, neostigmine and postoperative pulmonary complications
Project Summary: Pneumonia and other lung complications after surgery are common, distressing and costly. Muscle weakness after surgery increases the risk of lung complications. Sugammadex reverses muscle relaxant drugs better than neostigmine. We propose a large study of surgical patients aged 40 years and over to determine if sugammadex reduces the risk of lung complications compared with neostigmine. This study has the potential to improve outcomes for millions of patients and health services worldwide.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Kate Leslie, Associate Professor Jai Darvall, Associate Professor Sabine Braat, Professor David Story, Professor Matthew Chan, Professor Nancy Devlin, Professor Paul Myles, Professor Philip Peyton, Professor Timothy Short, Professor Tomas Corcoran
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Anaesthesiology

Project Name: Enhancing point-of-care testing for hepatitis C infection: the OPTIMISE study
Project Summary: Hepatitis C testing and treatment has declined in Australia, slowing elimination progress. Point-of-care testing for active hepatitis C infection provides results in an hour, enabling same-visit diagnosis and treatment. But, this test is more costly and has a longer time to result than point-of-care antibody testing. This MRFF Project will conduct a comparative effectiveness trial to assess the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness, and acceptability of point-of-care hepatitis C testing strategies.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Jason Grebely, Associate Professor Alisa Pedrana, Associate Professor Philip Cunningham, Associate Professor Richard Gray, Doctor Alison Marshall, Doctor Evan Cunningham, Doctor Lise Lafferty, Doctor Louise Causer, Doctor Marianne Martinello, Doctor Melanie Kingsland, Doctor Sophy Shih, Doctor Susan Matthews, Professor Carla Treloar, Professor Denise Esserman, Professor Gregory Dore
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Public health and health services, Epidemiology

Project Name: A comparative effectiveness trial of digital mental health care models for adults with epilepsy
Project Summary: This clinical trial will compare the acceptability and effectiveness of two models (guided vs unguided) of delivering a digital psychological intervention aimed at improving mental health and functional outcomes in adults with epilepsy. The guided model delivers the intervention with support from mental health specialist. Whereas the unguided model offers the intervention in a standalone, self-directed format. This trail will inform the public health potential of these two approaches to care.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Milena Gandy, Doctor Eyal Karin, Doctor Genevieve Rayner, Doctor Kaitlyn Parratt, Doctor Tobias Thomas Winton-Brown, Professor Blake Dear, Professor Henry Cutler, Professor Nickolai Titov, Professor Patrick Kwan
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Public health and health services, Mental health

Project Name: A comprehensive digital solution to empower asthma and comorbidity self-management
Project Summary: Asthma control and self-management via existing asthma care models remain low. New, cost-effective, and evidence-based models of care with better reach and higher uptake are needed. This trial will demonstrate the effectiveness of a comprehensive, national, digital asthma care program compared to usual care in achieving asthma control. The findings will have direct healthcare system implications and if effective can be upscaled nationally to assist millions of people with asthma.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Peter Gibson, Associate Professor Mohanraj Karunanithi, Doctor Dennis Thomas, Doctor Hugh John Fardy, Doctor Rebecca McLoughlin, Doctor Rebecca Wyse, Doctor Simon Deeming, Professor Elizabeth Holliday, Professor Vanessa McDonald
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Public health and health services, Health promotion

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: Hospital Acquired Pneumonia PrEveNtion (HAPPEN study)
Project Summary: Pneumonia is the most common type of HAI, accounting for approximately one third of all HAIs, with non-ventilator healthcare-associated pneumonia (HAP) the most common. Remarkably, HAP receives little attention by policymakers, researchers and funders. There have been no randomised controlled studies exploring HAP prevention in hospital undertaken anywhere to date. We propose to undertake intervention involving improvements in oral care to reduce the incidence of HAP.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Brett Mitchell, Professor Allen Cheng, Doctor Sonja Dawson, Doctor Julee McDonagh, Doctor Auxillia Madhuvu, Associate Professor Helen Rawson, Associate Professor Philip Russo, Associate Professor Jenny Sim, Associate Professor Andrew Stewardson, Doctor Nicole White, Professor Rhonda Wilson

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: Nurse-Led Improvements to the Quality and Safety of Residential Aged Care - Project HIRAID-AgedCare
Project Summary: Nurses in the aged care sector are underqualified and understaffed, leaving them ill-equipped to handle the complex clinical needs of older Australians. The proposed project aims to develop a new model of care: HIRAID-AGEDCARE, which will be based upon the existing HIRAID model currently is use by emergency nurses across NSW hospitals. HIRAID-AGEDCARE will provide an evidence-based framework to help nurses perform their roles optimally and standardise nursing care across the aged care sector.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Ramon Shaban, Professor Kate Curtis, Doctor Moira Dunsmore, Professor Margaret Fry, Professor Yun-Hee Jeon, Doctor Mary Lam, Professor Richard Lindley, Professor Lee-Fay Low, Professor Brendan McCormack, Ms Margherita Murgo, Professor Deborah Parker, Professor Donna Waters, Doctor Karen Watson

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: Remote Aboriginal Communities Ending TB (REACT)
Project Summary: Tuberculosis (TB) is an important public health issue and cause of preventable illness and death in some remote Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory. This project will listen to and work together with Aboriginal communities and health services to develop resources and strategies which increase awareness of TB to ensure it is diagnosed early, increase use of treatment to prevent TB, and enable the health system to provide supportive and culturally appropriate care to people with TB.
Chief Investigator Team: Christopher Lowbridge, Trang Nguyen, Jessica Gatti, Doctor Vicki Krause, Professor Anna Ralph, Doctor Sean Taylor

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: Melatonin supplementation to reduce the induction of labour rates in first time mothers: The MyTIME Trial
Project Summary: The rate of first-time mothers having their labour is induced is increasing. Induced labour can be associated with harm for mother and baby and contributes to rising health costs. Melatonin is a hormone produced naturally in the body. One of its actions is that it helps start childbirth. We will do a double-blind study to determine whether giving pregnant women oral melatonin may help with starting labour normally. This could be a simple and cost-effective way to decrease induction of labour.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Zoe Bradfield, Professor Dorota Doherty, Professor Jeffrey Keelan, Doctor Lesley Kuliukas, Associate Professor Jane Warland, Doctor Scott White
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Midwifery, Clinical midwifery

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: IDC-IMPROVE: The co-design, implementation and evaluation of a care bundle to improve indwelling catheter care (IDC) in residential aged care homes
Project Summary: The priority health care issue this grant addresses is the gap in current services across Australia to support people with a long-term indwelling catheter who live in a residential aged care home. Long-term catheter use is associated with high morbidity and places considerable demand on emergency services. This research will support the aged care workforce to address the needs of residents with catheters, consequently reducing problems associated with catheter use.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Joan Ostaszkiewicz, Associate Professor Frances Batchelor, Doctor Jessica Cecil, Ms Helen Crowe, Doctor Kathleen Hunter, Doctor Liza Lau, Professor Catherine Paterson, Doctor Micah Peters, Ashlyn Sahay, Doctor Alyson Sweeney, Janie Thompson, Ms Elizabeth Watt, Julie Westaway
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Nursing, Nursing workforce

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: SAFE-HF - tranSlating heArt Failure guidElines into practice: a RCT of a Nurse Practitioner primary care service
Project Summary: Heart failure (HF) is a common disease of the heart with a high rehospitalisation and mortality rate. HF patients rarely receive the full benefits of evidence-based care simply due to inaccessibility to a HF specialist team. HF nurse practitioners are a vital component of this specialist workforce. This translational and innovative project will determine the effectiveness and costs of a HF nurse practitioner in primary care. It has the potential to keep patients out of hospital and save lives.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Andrea Driscoll, Professor John Atherton, Associate Professor Ralph Audehm, Doctor Alison Beauchamp, Doctor Susan Cartledge, Professor Alison Hutchinson, Doctor Grainne Lowe, Professor Phillip Newton, Professor Liliana Orellana, Ms Amanda Pereira-Salgado, Ms Margaret Pollock, Doctor Ella Zomer, Doctor James Theuerle
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Cardiovascular medicine and haematology, Cardiology (incl. cardiovascular diseases)

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: Building capacity to prevent healthcare harm for hospitalised infants: A Type 1 Hybrid Randomised Controlled Trial
Project Summary: Our aim is to test the effectiveness of a new IV biosensor, to prevent babies developing a significant, preventable injury, known as extravasation (a chemical burn). This will help to make hospitals safer for babies, ensure our clinicians are using the best technology available, and build research links to allow us to do powerful research in the future.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Amanda Ullman, Doctor Deanne August, Associate Professor Joshua Byrnes, Doctor Roni Cole, Professor Fiona Coyer, Professor Martha Curley, Professor Mark Davies, Associate Professor Lauren Kearney, Professor Samantha Keogh, Ms Tricia Kleidon, Associate Professor Nicole Marsh, Associate Professor Craig McBride, Ms Mari Takashima, Professor Robert Ware, Doctor Hui (Grace) Xu
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Nursing, Acute care

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: Implementing integrated psychological and physical care for Australians after road traffic injury
Project Summary: Our VISION is that all physiotherapists, nationwide, deliver effective early biopsychosocial care to improve health outcomes for people with nRTI. We will test an on-line implementation package (PICOT: Physiotherapists bIopsyChosocial On-line Training) compared to usual in-person training for broad implementation of physiotherapist-delivered integrated psychological and physical care for people after road traffic injury.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Michele Sterling, Doctor Rachel Elphinston, Doctor Roma Forbes, Professor Nadine Foster, Associate Professor Jason Lodge, Doctor Johanna Lynch, Associate Professor Shaun O'Leary, Doctor Kerry Peek, Doctor Jennifer Setchell, Professor Helen Slater, Doctor Julia Treleaven, Associate Professor Haitham Tuffaha
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Allied health and rehabilitation science, Physiotherapy

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: Responsible pre-operative Opioid use for Hip and knee ArthropLasTy (OpioidHALT) Study: Opioid tapering in patients prior to hip and knee arthroplasty
Project Summary: Hip and knee replacements are the most common joint replacement surgeries in Australia. Overuse of opioids in these patients appears to be common before surgery and have been associated with persistent opioid use after surgery, poorer post-operative pain, function and longer hospital stay. This research program will identify the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary pharmacist-led opioid tapering intervention to reduce persistent opioid use after hip and knee replacement surgery.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Jonathan Penm, Associate Professor Sam Adie, Doctor Kylie Bailey, Doctor Bernadette Brady, Associate Professor Betty Chaar, Mr Joseph Descallar, Professor Nicholas Lintzeris, Ms Shania Liu, Associate Professor Rebekah Moles, Professor Justine Naylor, Doctor Claire O'Reilly, Professor Asad Patanwala, Doctor Carl Schneider, Associate Professor Lei Si, Associate Professor Jennifer Stevens
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Allied health and rehabilitation science, Allied health and rehabilitation science not elsewhere classified

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: Implementing univerSal Tele-prehabiliTation into cAnceR caRe pathwayS STTARRS trial
Project Summary: Abdominal surgery is the most frequent major surgical procedure performed in developed countries. Complications after surgery are strongly associated with poor patient recovery and increased healthcare costs. Patient education before surgery including the importance of deep breathing, oral care, physical activity, nutrition and pain management show promise in reducing these complications. We aim to establish this innovative management into routine care and measure its effectiveness.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Linda Denehy, Doctor Ianthe Boden, Doctor Lara Edbrooke, Associate Professor Helena Frawley, Associate Professor Catherine Granger, Claire Hackett, Professor Alexander Heriot, Doctor Hilmy Ismail, Doctor Erin Laing, Professor Bernhard Riedel, Ms Catherine Sinton, Doctor Tim Spelman
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Allied health and rehabilitation science, Physiotherapy

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: E-PACT: Randomised Trial of Parenting Acceptance and Commitment therapy for Parents of children with neurodevelopmental disabilities
Project Summary: This project aims to have a lasting impact upon the lives of children with neurodevelopmental disabilities (NDD) and their families by growing parent capacity through parenting support. Based on five successful RCTs we have developed an online/telehealth solution: “e-PACT”. In this study we will trial e-PACT with 300 families. We predict that e-PACT will improve parental capacity as measured by the parent-child relationships, with benefits for both parent and child physical and mental health.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Koa Whittingham, Associate Professor Josephine Barbaro, Doctor Jacqueline Barfoot, Professor Roslyn Boyd, Associate Professor Kristelle Hudry, Doctor Syed Afroz Keramat, Doctor Amy Mitchell, Professor Iona Novak, Doctor Natasha Reid
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: PSYCHOLOGY, Clinical and health psychology, Clinical psychology

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: ESTEEM After Stroke: Improving access to stroke rehabilitation for regional Australians
Project Summary: This health Professoressional led research will improve regional stroke survivor’s access to stroke care. Access will be improved by supporting non-government health care organisations to deliver the ESTEEM Program. The ESTEEM Program is a peer-supported program combining exercise, socialisation and creative art activities. This research will determine the effect that participation in the ESTEEM Program has on stroke survivor recovery and their and their carer’s emotional health and quality of life.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Heidi Janssen, Doctor Marie-Louise Bird, Professor Coralie English, Doctor Carlos Garcia-Esperon, Doctor Kirsti Haracz, Doctor Liam Johnson, Professor Christopher Levi, Professor Michael Nilsson, Doctor Christopher Oldmeadow, Doctor Christine Shiner, Doctor Dawn Simpson, Professor Neil Spratt
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Health and community services

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: A national platform for improving quality of nutrition care for critically ill adults and children
Project Summary: We propose the first national platform to transform the future of nutrition care for critically ill adults and children in Australia. The primary aim of this proposal is to re-design and inform new models of nutrition care to ensure efficient and effective application of resources in the way consumers need. The impact will be improved quality of care and rapid reduction in complications associated with poor nutrition (for which critically ill patients are at high risk).
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Emma Ridley, Doctor Darshini Ayton, Professor Michael Bailey, Professor Warwick Butt, Doctor Lee-anne Chapple, Doctor Kate Fetterplace, Doctor Amy Freeman-Sanderson, Professor Carol Hodgson, Victoria King, Professor Andrea Marshall, Professor Alistair Nichol, Professor Sandra Peake, Doctor Oana Tatucu, Professor Andrew Udy, Ms Jacinta Winderlich
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Intensive care

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: Restructuring musculoskeletal health services to ensure equitable access to effective, affordable allied health care
Project Summary: Musculoskeletal conditions, such as back and neck pain, are extremely common and put a huge strain on the public healthcare system. This program of work is led by physiotherapists and aims to test new virtual models of care that improve the health of Australians, are preferred by patients & health Professoressionals, and use scarce healthcare money more efficiently. The new health services utilise virtual technology to reduce waiting times &; ensure equitable access to effective, affordable care.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Joshua Zadro, Professor Ilana Ackerman, Doctor David Anderson, Professor Rachelle Buchbinder, Doctor Danielle Coombs, Professor Ian Harris, Professor Lisa Harvey, Doctor Gustavo Machado, Professor Chris Maher, Doctor Stephanie Mathieson, Doctor Bethan Richards, Doctor Christina Abdel Shaheed, Professor Timothy Shaw, Doctor Michael Swain, Doctor Adrian Traeger
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Allied health and rehabilitation science, Physiotherapy

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Clinician Researchers: Nurses, Midwives and Allied Health
Project Name: Adoption, impact and sustainability of evidence-based practice into health care: Co-design and evaluation of projects, systems and processes
Project Summary: As allied health and nursing world-leaders in clinical, health services research and implementation science we will build evidence that supports effective adoption of evidence into health care. In partnership with consumers and stakeholders, we will develop and implement an efficient data collection system and systematically evaluate the funded Stream 1 and 2 projects led by nursing and allied health clinicians. These co-designed systems and resources will be transferrable to other MRFF schemes.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Julie Redfern, Professor Andrew Baillie, Professor Raymond Chan, Associate Professor Caleb Ferguson, Professor Robyn Gallagher, Associate Professor Alexis Hure, Doctor Karice Hyun, Professor Debra Jackson, Doctor Stephanie Partridge, Doctor Mitchell Sarkies, Professor Catherine Sherrington
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Implementation science and evaluation

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: Home hearing and vision care to improve quality of life for people with dementia and carers
Project Summary: Home care helps people with dementia continue to live in their own homes, rather than a aged care home. But over 70% of people have hearing or vision problems that worsen the impact of dementia, reduce quality of life and ability to live independently. Effective hearing and vision support is available, but most hearing and vision problems are not properly supported. We will work with older people to understand the barriers, then develop and test interventions to improve hearing and vision care.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Piers Dawes, Professor Brenda Gannon, Associate Professor Hamid Sohrabi, Doctor Carly Meyer, Professor Judy Lowthian, Doctor John Newall, Professor Lisa Keay, Professor Nancy Pachana, Doctor Yuanyuan Gu, Doctor Sheela Kumaraan, Associate Professor Iracema Leroi, Professor Chyrisse Heine, Doctor Angelita Martini, Doctor Marianne Coleman, Doctor Sabrina Lenzen
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Aged health care

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: Increasing days living in the community and improving quality of life among people living with dementia and their carers
Project Summary: There is a need to support people living with dementia to connect with needed health care and other services and proactively plan their care. This study will test the impact of a nurse led intervention on increasing the days spent in the community, and the quality of life of people living with dementia and their family carers using a randomised controlled design. Outcomes will be assessed for both the person with dementia and their family carer at baseline, 6 and 12 months follow up.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Mariko Carey, Doctor Kay Khaing, Professor Constance Pond, Professor John Attia, Professor Yun-Hee Jeon, Professor Anna Williams, Professor Balakrishnan Nairr, Mr Simon Deeming, Doctor Michelle Kelly, Associate Professor Joel Rhee, Doctor Jennifer White, Doctor Kylie Wales
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Primary health care

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: Enhancing allied health services for people with dementia in residential aged care: an integrated, transdisciplinary model
Project Summary: Complications due to frailty and injury after falls in people with dementia is a significant problem in Residential Aged Care Facilities (RACFs) in Australia. The project will utilise existing General Practice networks based at a RACF to coordinate a suite of evidence based allied health services including occupational therapy, physiotherapy, speech pathology, dietetics and pharmacy and optometry to residents in a RACF in Canberra
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Stephen Isbel, Assistant Professor Nathan D'Cunha, Associate Professor Jane Kellett, Associate Professor Faran Sabeti, Associate Professor Sam Kosari, Professor Rachel Davey, Associate Professor Angela Fearon, Doctor Paresh Dawda, Professor Michelle Lincoln, Professor Diane Gibson, Professor Mark Naunton, Doctor Jennifer Hewitt, Doctor Claire Pearce, Associate Professor Helen Southwood, Professor Pip Logan
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Aged health care

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: To know me is to understand me: Digital life story packages in dementia care transitions
Project Summary: To Know Me is to Understand Me (2KMUM) trains healthcare students to conduct reminiscence sessions with aged care residents with dementia in order to produce a 4 minute life story video and poster to capture the resident's identity and preferences. We will compare 2KMUM with usual care to find out if 2KMUM helps aged care and health staff understand how to provide personalised care and support for the resident, improving the resident and their family carer’s quality of life during transitions.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Katrina Anderson, Ms Catherine Bateman, Associate Professor Tracy Comans, Ms Annaliese Blair, Professor Victoria Traynor, Professor Sunil Bhar, Professor Ian Cameron, Professor Susan Kurrle, Doctor Michael Bird
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Aged health care

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: Connecting aged care, health care and social services systems to support older Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to live their best lives
Project Summary: An Aboriginal-informed System Connector Model for Ageing Well will link individuals to services and create or strengthen relationships between aged care, health care and social services, thereby increasing timely access to consistent, quality services across systems to support older Aboriginal people in South Australia to age well. Our project will generate evidence that is currently lacking on models of care that prevent ill health and improve quality of life for older Indigenous people.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Odette Pearson, Ms Kim Morey, Doctor Adriana Parrella, Doctor Courtney Ryder, Toni Shearing, Associate Professor Natasha Howard, Doctor Rachel Reilly, Professor Saravana Kumar, Ms Trischia Ritchie, Ms Sonia Waters, Doctor Jennifer Caruso
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Aged health care

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: Evaluating the implementation and uptake of prevention programs to support healthy ageing amongst Aboriginal people
Project Summary: Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Services (ACCHSs) run holistic and culturally safe preventive healthy ageing programs for their communities. This collaborative project will examine the reach and uptake of prevention programs at three ACCHSs in NSW. It will identify opportunities to optimise reach, with each community selecting an optimisation strategy which will be tested to assess impact on uptake in the community. Findings will be shared to support decision making, policy and practice.
Chief Investigator Team: Ms Sandra Bailey, Associate Professor Sumithra Muthayya, Mr James Newman, Professor Christine Paul, Professor Rebecca Ivers, Professor Juanita Sherwood, Doctor Michelle Kennedy, Ms Simone Sherriff, Ms Paulene Mackell, Mr Darryl Wright

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: Active Women over 50 in rural, regional and remote areas: an effectiveness-implementation trial
Project Summary: Women aged 50+ are a priority for targeted physical activity programs, since capacity starts to decline at this age, and women aged 50+ have unique barriers to becoming active. The Active Women over 50 program combines website information, health coaching, Facebook group and SMS or email motivational messages, to promote physical activity. This research will test the effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and implementation potential of this virtually delivered physical activity promotion program.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Anne Tiedemann, Associate Professor Leanne Hassett, Associate Professor Simon Rosenbaum, Associate Professor Georgina Luscombe, Professor Kirsten Howard, Doctor Dominika Kwasnicka, Professor Nehmat Houssami, Emeritus Professor Adrian Bauman, Professor Philayrath Phongsavan, Ms Geraldine Wallbank, Doctor Heidi Gilchrist, Doctor Grace McKeon, Doctor Raaj Kishore Biswas
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Public health, Health promotion

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: Oral Health in Aged Care: Addressing Oral Health Inequity and Unmet Dental Care Needs in Vulnerable Populations
Project Summary: This program aims to evaluate and implement an intervention package that can reduce severe symptoms and functional limitations associated with untreated dental decay, a highly prevalent and debilitating unmet health need in residential aged care residents with dementia. The intervention will help improving quality of life and daily activities of those impacted residents and deliver a cost-effective and feasible approach to help this vulnerable population to maintain a healthy aging.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Loc Do, Doctor Diep Ha, Doctor Nicole Stormon, Helena Schuch, Professor Andrew Georgiou, Doctor Kristiana Ludlow, Mr Christopher Sexton, Doctor Claudia Lopez Silva, Emeritus Professor Laurence Walsh, Professor Saso Ivanovski, Doctor Matthew Nangle, Associate Professor Haitham Tuffaha, Professor Julie Henry

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: BEFRIENDING with GENIE: An intervention to reduce loneliness and increase social support and service access for people living with dementia and their caregivers from CaLD backgrounds
Project Summary: The BEFRIENDING with GENIE project aims to improve the quality of life of people living with dementia and their caregivers from Culturally and Linguistically Diverse (CaLD) backgrounds by reducing loneliness, increasing social support networks and improving access to, and knowledge about, appropriate services. It combines a successful BEFRIENDING program with a proven online social support network and engagement tool (GENIE) that will be piloted with 100 participants living in four states.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Loretta Baldassar, Doctor Manonita Ghosh, Doctor Jacques Raubenheimer, Professor Sunil Bhar, Doctor Simone Marino, Ms Mary Gurgone, Associate Professor Dannii Yeung, Doctor Sanetta du Toit, Doctor Catriona Stevens, Associate Professor Ivaylo Vassilev, Professor Colleen Doyle, Associate Professor Jade Cartwright, Doctor Anita Goh, Doctor Rosemary Saunders

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: Implementation and evaluation of a codesigned exercise program to reduce falls in older people from culturally and linguistically diverse communities
Project Summary: Falls are the second leading cause of disability in older people. There is strong evidence that exercise reduces falls, however most older people do not meet physical activity guidelines. We are currently codesigning a program, Move Together, to increase the uptake of exercise to reduce falls with older people from Italian, Arab and Chinese communities. This study will evaluate the effectiveness and cost effectiveness of Move Together, and develop strategies to support implementation.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Catherine Said, Doctor Lidia Engel, Ms Emily Ramage, Doctor Cassie McDonald, Associate Professor Michele Callisaya, Doctor Marlena Klaic, Doctor Sara Vogrin, Doctor Jesse Zanker, Professor Wen Lim, Associate Professor Stephanie Best

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: Strengthening and enhancing the utility of a neuropsychological tool for dementia in First Nations peoples
Project Summary: The Kimberley Indigenous Cognitive Assessment (KICA) is the only neuropsychological tool for dementia in Australia’s First Nations peoples. Reviews, feedback and research have identified gaps that are impacting KICA access and use. To address these gaps the project will review, revise and test the KICA-R in diverse communities. A training package will be co-developed to inform use. It is critical that we address this dementia research priority to improve dementia care for First Nations peoples.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Kate Smith, Ms Roslyn Malay, Associate Professor Sarah Russell, Professor Leon Flicker, Professor Dawn Bessarab, Associate Professor Dina LoGiudice, Doctor Zoe Hyde, Professor Edward Strivens, Associate Professor Carmela Pestell, Betty Sagigi
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /:
HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Aged health care;
HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Health services and systems not elsewhere classified

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: A new tool to optimise the early and accurate diagnosis of frontotemporal dementia
Project Summary: This project aims to improve the accurate diagnosis of frontotemporal dementia (FTD); a debilitating form of younger-onset dementia. Anhedonia (a loss of interest) was recently identified as a key marker of FTD. This project will create a new clinical tool that captures early features of anhedonia to streamline the FTD diagnostic pathway. The new tool and training materials will be made freely available to optimise the early detection of FTD and to improve treatment outcomes for those affected.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Muireann Irish, Doctor David Foxe, Professor Yun-Hee Jeon, Professor Dennis Velakoulis, Professor Gail Robinson, Doctor Alexis Whitton, Professor Lee-Fay Low, Associate Professor Fiona Kumfor, Associate Professor Rebekah Ahmed, Professor Olivier Piguet
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Geriatrics and gerontology

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: Enhancing utility of neuropsychological evaluation for earlier and effective diagnosis of dementia in Parkinson’s disease
Project Summary: Dementia is a major concern for people living with Parkinson’s disease; however, there are limited opportunities for early diagnosis. This research will assess a new intervention that includes 1) best practice guidelines for cognitive evaluation, and 2) a technology platform, to help clinicians to effectively identify dementia and those at high risk of dementia throughout the course of their Parkinson’s disease. Earlier diagnosis of dementia will improve access to support and quality of life.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Nadeeka Dissanayaka, Doctor Jacqueline Liddle, Associate Professor Mark Chatfield, Associate Professor John O'Sullivan, Professor Gerard Byrne, Doctor Leander Mitchell, Doctor Kirstine Shrubsole, Professor Nancy Pachana, Doctor Dana Pourzinal, Professor Martie-Louise Verreynne, Doctor Ji Hyun Yang, Doctor Peter Worthy, Doctor Sabrina Lenzen, Doctor Deborah Brooks, Associate Professor Annette Broome
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: PSYCHOLOGY, Clinical and health psychology, Clinical neuropsychology

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: Spatial navigation assessment: pathway to clinical translation and early diagnosis of dementia
Project Summary: Current clinical tests for Alzheimer’s disease are not sensitive enough to detect brain changes that begin 10-20 years before memory symptoms appear. Our team has developed novel tests of spatial navigation (how we navigate our surroundings) that are highly sensitive to these early brain changes. This project will optimise the tests for rollout in clinical services, enabling timely, accurate diagnosis that will fasttrack access to early interventions and improve outcomes for those affected.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Stephanie Wong, Professor Mark Jenki nson, Associate Professor Victor Roger Schinazi, Associate Professor Tobias Loetscher, Doctor Michelle Kelly, Professor Maria Crotty, Professor Michael Hornberger, Doctor Monica Cations, Professor Frini Karayanidis, Associate Professor Hannah Keage, Doctor Ashleigh Smith

MRFF Initiative: Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission
Project Name: An Integrated Method for the Assessment and Monitoring of Dementia and Cognitive Impairment: The Cognition - Optimised, Digitised, And Harmonised (C-ODH) platform
Project Summary: Neuropsychological testing is key to dementia diagnosis, but barriers such as time, cost, and geographical access, can limit the access of such tests. Utilising novel technologies, and with our Australian industry partners, we will develop and optimize digital assessments, and systems for their deployment, analysis and reporting. By the end of this study, we will have an assessment platform that will enable earlier, and more effective dementia diagnosis with greater geographical access.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Yen Ying Lim, Professor Susannah Ahern, Doctor Inga Mehrani, Associate Professor Scott Ayton, Doctor Rachel Buckley, Doctor Rosita Shishegar, Doctor Darshini Ayton, Professor Paul Maruff, Associate Professor Jane Alty, Professor Velandai Srikanth, Professor Sharon Naismith, Doctor Laura Bird, Doctor Jurgen Fripp

Project Name: Developing a promoter-less gene therapy approach for haemophilia A
Project Summary: Haemophilia A (Factor VIII deficiency) is a bleeding disorder that affects around 3,000 people in Australia. Gene therapy can tackle such deficiencies by delivering the corrective genes to the patient’s cells. However, questions on the durability of such therapies are common. In this proposal, we plan to harness the cellular natural DNA repair process to provide a precise and durable therapy, by safely inserting the correct copy of Factor VIII into a highly expressed region of the human genome.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Suzanne Scott
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: TECHNOLOGY, Medical biotechnology, Gene and molecular therapy

Project Name: Reducing medication-related harm in people living with dementia through community action: Development and testing of novel co-designed medication management resources across care settings
Project Summary: Poor medication management is one of the most common causes of hospital admission in people living with dementia, and is often avoidable. This project will educate, empower and support people with dementia and their carers to manage their medications safely by developing, and testing co-designed medication management guidance resources for use in the community and during the transition into aged care.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Mouna Sawan, Doctor Amanda Cross, Doctor Jacqueline Wesson, Doctor Karen Watson, Doctor Natali Jokanovic
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Pharmacology and pharmaceutical sciences, Clinical pharmacy and pharmacy practice

Project Name: Running for Health: community-based adaptive exercise for cardiorespiratory health in young people with moderate to severe cerebral palsy
Project Summary: In Australia, 420 children are born annually with cerebral palsy (CP), making it the most common physical disability. Of these, 40% will have moderate to severe motor disability which is associated with reduced mobility, poorer heart and lung health, increased risk of fractures, greater pain, lower levels of physical activity, and early death. We have promising data on a new adaptive physical activity called Frame Running which we will test in a trial of 90 children with moderate to severe CP.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Sarah Reedman, Associate Professor Leanne Sakzewski, Doctor Tamara Blake, Doctor Andrea Burgess, Doctor Stina Oftedal, Doctor Dayna Pool, Doctor Ellen Armstrong, Doctor Syed Afroz Keramat, Doctor Iain Dutia, Doctor Matthew Ahmadi

Organisation: The Council of the Queensland Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: Treatment of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder with Transcranial Focused Ultrasound
Project Summary: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a mental illness that can be very difficult to treat and causes significant disability and suffering. In this research, we plan to understand how focused ultrasonic sound waves can be used to change brain activity in a circuit that we think is crucial in persistent symptoms. We plan to show that this is a safe, tolerable and effective therapy and anticipate that it will prove to be a new option for people with OCD who have not responded to other treatments.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Philip Mosley, Doctor Luke Hearne
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: MEDICAL AND HEALTH SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Psychiatry (incl. psychotherapy)

Project Name: Harnessing nanopore sequencing technology to improve diagnosis of human disease
Project Summary: Nanopore sequencing is an emerging technology that enables cheap, fast, portable analysis of long DNA/RNA molecules. There are countless opportunities to streamline, improve or reimagine the diagnosis of human disease using nanopore technology. We outline a series of new tests that address unsolved challenges in genetic disease diagnosis, clinical RNA sequencing and cancer surveillance. In each case, we propose experiments to establish the advantages of nanopore sequencing over existing methods.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Ira Deveson, Doctor Kishore Kumar, Doctor Amali Mallawaarachchi, Doctor Andre Luiz Martins Reis, Doctor Hasindu Gamaarachchi, Doctor Pak Leng Cheong

Project Name: Plasma Flush- translating cold plasma technology as an antimicrobial wound irrigation towards clinical trials
