Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Carrington Shepherd, Doctor Helen Bailey, Mrs Sonya Criddle, Doctor Bernardo Dewey, Ms Janinne Gliddon, Ms Carolyn Lewis, Ms Keren Ludski, Professor Rhonda Marriott, Mrs Christine Parry, Ms Millie Penny, Mr Fred Penny, Doctor Danielle Pollock, Mrs Patricia Ratajczak, Associate Professor Mary Sharp, Doctor Scott White

Project Name: Strengthening the health and wellbeing of First Nations mums and bubs by optimising maternal iron intakes
Project Summary: Iron deficiency affects over half of all pregnant First Nations women and has significant health impacts for both mother and baby. Developing support programs that empower First Nations women to increase their iron intake during pregnancy has the potential to strengthen the health and wellbeing of First Nations communities. This study will develop and pilot the first community-led support program aimed at optimising iron intake for pregnant First Nations women living on Gomeroi lands.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Kirsty Pringle, Ms Ashley Bullock, Doctor Jyoti Chaku, Professor Clare Collins, Associate Professor Adam Collison, Doctor Saije Endacott, Professor Donna Hartz, Doctor Hayley Scott, Ms Lisa Shipley, Reakeeta Smallwood, Miss Amity Smith, Ms Marjorie Treweek, Ms Audrey Trindall, Doctor Rebecca Vanders
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: INDIGENOUS STUDIES, Aboriginal and torres strait islander health and wellbeing, Aboriginal and torres strait islander mothers and babies health and wellbeing

Project Name: RECLAIM: A randomised controlled trial to test the clinical and costeffectiveness of a new treatment to reduce the risk of developing chronic post-surgical pain following total knee replacement surgery
Project Summary: While many people with knee osteoarthritis (OA) benefit from a total joint replacement, ~15% develop severe, debilitating chronic post-surgical pain. Once this pain is present, there are no effective treatments. We will test a new lifestyle treatment that aims to prevent people with knee OA from developing chronic post-surgical pain after surgery. We will conduct a randomised controlled trial so that we understand how effective this new treatment is in terms of clinical outcome and cost.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Natasha Stanton, Doctor Felicity Braithwaite, Associate Professor David Campbell, Doctor Daniel Harvie, Professor Jonathan Karnon, Professor G. Lorimer Moseley, Peter Ninnes, Professor Tomohiko Nishigami, Professor Lucian Solomon, Doctor Tyman Stanford, Mr So Tanaka, Professor Benedict Wand, Professor Vikki Wylde

Project Name: Increasing access to physical activity for people with spinal cord injuries: The Train the Trainer model
Project Summary: This project aim to enhance exercise accessibility for individuals with spinal cord injuries (SCI) by providing specialised training to exercise professionals in community gyms and connecting them with people with SCI. The Spinal Cord Injury and Physical Activity Community program (SCIPACom) was successful in previous studies. We now propose a larger-scale study to assess the implementation of the program on a broader scale and to gain a deeper understanding of its impact for people with SCI.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Camila Quel de Oliveira, Professor Garry Allison, Doctor Anita Amorim, Doctor Elizabeth Bye, Doctor Nathalia Costa, Professor Simon Darcy, Doctor Marina de Barros Pinheiro, Professor Mary Galea, Doctor Beatriz Ito Ramos de Oliveira, Doctor Oscar Lederman, Doctor Karime Mescouto, Associate Professor Kris Rogers, Doctor Peter Stubbs, Doctor Bruno Tirotti Saragiotto, Doctor Tina van Duijn

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: APAP-YCS: a Co-designed adaption of the Adapted Physical Activity Program to promote lifestyle physical activity among young cancer survivors
Project Summary: APAP-YCS is a project designed with young people who have survived cancer. This project will empower young survivors through a tailored physical and lifestyle activity program to aid their recovery and to assist them to integrate their new reality with the life they want. The project will also train healthcare providers to improve their ability to help young survivors, and to enhance services and education in community settings.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Natalie Bradford, Doctor Kelly Clanchy, Professor Louisa Collins, Professor Jed Duff, Doctor Jessica Hill, Doctor Louise Marquart-Wilson, Professor Alexandra McCarthy, Doctor Xiomara Skrabal Ross, Professor Simon Smith, Doctor Rosalind Spence, Professor Stewart Trost, Professor Sean Tweedy, Doctor Roderick Walker, Doctor Kate Young

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: TeleCARE: A personalised, clinician-supported, virtual care telehealth exercise, nutrition, education, behaviour change and peer support model for cancer-related fatigue
Project Summary: Cancer-related fatigue is a common disabling condition, but implementation of a tailored, lifestyle-based self-management approach with carer and clinician support is lacking. This study will evaluate whether a clinician supported, virtual care telehealth model of care including exercise, nutrition, education, behaviour change, and peer support can improve fatigue and quality of life in cancer survivors, and whether this approach is translatable into clinical practice and feasible for scale-up.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Robin Daly, Doctor Brenton Baguley, Doctor Katherine Bolam, Miss Emma Bourke, Doctor Jack Dalla Via, Professor Linda Denehy, Associate Professor Erin Howden, Professor Alison Hutchinson, Doctor Mary Kennedy, Associate Professor Nicole Kiss, Associate Professor Nikki McCaffrey, Professor Liliana Orellana, Professor Carla Prado, Associate Professor Christopher Steer, Associate Professor Anna Ugalde

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: An equitable model of comprehensive cancer survivorship care for adolescents and young adults
Project Summary: Young cancer survivors face significant long-term physical/mental health problems, and social or financial hardship. Yet there are many barriers which make it hard to get the right survivorship care, and at the right time. We propose partnering with young people and health providers to develop and assess a survivorship program tailored to young survivors’ needs. This will empower survivors by improving equitable access to comprehensive survivorship care, helping them to thrive in the long-term.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Christina Signorelli, Doctor Sheena Arora, Professor Richard Cohn, Mr Joseph Elias, Doctor Vanessa Johnston, Professor Michael Kidd, Professor Elgene Lim, Jordana McLoone, Doctor Jessica Ryan, Doctor Ursula Sansom-Daly, Doctor Clarissa Schilstra, Doctor Monica Tang, Associate Professor Natalie Taylor, Doctor Elysia Thornton-Benko, Professor Claire Wakefield

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: Equitably maximising survivorship care and quality  of life for people living with HIV in Australia
Project Summary: People living with HIV (PLHIV) experience an intensive period of treatment and psychosocial adjustment following diagnosis. After which, lifelong treatment, alongside an excess burden of co-infections, chronic, and age-related diseases, mean survivorship care and quality of life are essential. We will establish a new multidisciplinary multi-sectoral team that will use best practice quantitative and qualitative methods to examine, for the first time, survivorship care for PLHIV in Australia.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Skye McGregor, Doctor Benjamin Bavinton, Professor Graham Brown, Jane Costello, Professor Rebecca Guy, Doctor Christopher Lemoh, Doctor Roanna Lobo, Doctor Hamish McManus, Doctor Dean Murphy, Doctor Thomas Norman, Doctor John Rule, Professor Claire Vajdic

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: Improving survivorship for critically ill patients aged over 65 (IMPROVE-65)
Project Summary: Critical illness can have long-term impact, with over 50% of survivors aged over 65 at high risk of ongoing disability at 6-months after hospital discharge. We will identify people who are at high risk of poor outcomes after critical illness and use novel electronic methods to improve their recovery, improving the services and communication between acute care, general practice and community care services.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Carol Hodgson, Professor David Brewster, Doctor Paul Buntine, Doctor Susan Cartledge, Ms Anais Charles-Nelson, Professor David J. (Jamie) Cooper, Doctor Alisa Higgins, Doctor Michelle Paton, Associate Professor Christopher Pearce, Professor Louise Rose, Professor Grant Russell, Doctor Ary Serpa Neto, Doctor Joanna Simpson, Professor Velandai Srikanth, Mrs Pamela Taylor

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: Early targeted intervention for PTSD in young survivors of Paediatric Intensive Care: A Hybrid Effectiveness Implementation Randomised Controlled Trial.
Project Summary: Each year, thousands of children develop significant psychological trauma following admission to intensive care for a life-threatening illness or injury. Despite advances in medical care to improve survival, strategies to mitigate and minimise psychological outcomes are lacking. This Australia-wide study will test the effectiveness of a targeted, brief early intervention in young traumatised children who have survived PICU and explore the best strategies for impactful, meaningful implementation
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Deborah Long, Professor Warwick Butt, Doctor Hannah Carter, Mrs Amanda Clayton, Doctor Gillian Colvillem, Doctor Alexandra De Young, Doctor Belinda Dow, Doctor Simon Erickson, Associate Professor Kristen Gibbons, Emeritus Professor Justin Kenardy, Professor Samantha Keogh, Professor Markus Landolt, Doctor Sainath Raman, Associate Professor Zephanie Tyack, Ms Nicki Walsh

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: ASPIRE – A new scalable and sustainable platform to improve survivorship care for assault victims living with severe physical and psychological deficits
Project Summary: Domestic violence and random assaults are widespread and lead to numerous detrimental consequences, such as traumatic brain injury (TBI). Pioneering this world-first initiative, we will deploy ASPIRE, an innovative web-based platform to enhance survivorship care for violence victims with TBI. By doing so, we aim to enhance both physical and psychological long-term outcomes while simultaneously reducing healthcare costs across the Australian community.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Karen Caeyenberghs, Associate Professor Hamed Akhlaghi, Professor Michael Berk, Doctor Zhaolin Chen, Doctor Juan Dominguez Duque, Professor Melinda Fitzgerald, Doctor Priscilla Gates, Doctor Sarah Hellewell, Professor Meng Law, Associate Professor Jean Lee, Professor Katie McMahon, Professor Richelle Mychasiuk, Professor Paul Parizel, Doctor Lata Satyen, Doctor Julian Stella
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /:
PSYCHOLOGY, Biological psychology, Cognitive neuroscience;
BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Neurosciences, Neurology and neuromuscular diseases

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: 'Ember to Empower': Developing and piloting a one-stop burn recovery toolkit for burn survivors
Project Summary: For burn survivors and their families, navigating access to resources, support, and services after they have left hospital has been identified as challenging and a high priority.  Developing a novel recovery toolkit called ‘Ember to Empower’ has been identified by burn survivors as a solution to address this priority, which is the focus of the project. Currently, there are no toolkits or programs that have been developed with survivors to comprehensively address this issue in Australia.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Zephanie Tyack, Mrs Charlotte Brown, Associate Professor Leila Cuttle, Doctor Alexandra De Young, Doctor Martha Druery, Associate Professor Dale Edgar, Professor Belinda Gabbe, Doctor Lisa Martin, Mr Dale Trevor, Professor Fiona Wood

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: Co-producing cancer survivorship resources with and for people with intellectual disability
Project Summary: People with intellectual disability face many barriers to receiving appropriate cancer care. This research aims to understand the cancer-related healthcare needs and preferences of people with intellectual disability, and to co-produce resources and support tools.  We also aim to improve healthcare practices by working directly with service providers, health professionals and policymakers to enhance equity in cancer survivorship.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Michelle Bellon, Doctor Jennifer Baldock, Associate Professor Lisa Beatty, Miss Jala Burton, Mr Timothy Cahalan, Associate Professor Aileen Collier, Mrs Felicity Crowther, Doctor Emma Kemp, Professor Catherine Paterson, Miss Stephanie Searle, Professor Julian Trollor, Miss Monica Welsh
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, People with disability

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: Consumer co-design and Pilot testing of TExt Messaging to support Pain self-management in breast cancer survivOrs (TEMPO-P)
Project Summary: Three out of ten women have chronic pain after breast cancer treatment. It affects their lives in many ways. Very few of them attend pain clinics. Our prior research shows texting can help people learn to manage chronic pain. Nearly everyone has a mobile phone, texts are cheap to send, and it avoids going to a pain clinic. Our study compares texting to a best-practice pain treatment program. If texting compares well to a pain program and people like it, it can be easily made widely available.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Paul Glare, Associate Professor Claire Ashton-James, Jessica Dawson, Professor Manuela Ferreira, Doctor Ali Gholamrezaei, Doctor James McCracken-Skeggs, Miss Naveena Nekkalapudi, Professor Michael Nicholas, Doctor Lina Pugliano, Doctor Anna Singleton, Jamie Young

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: Assessing the Feasibility of a Proactive Heart Health Check Model in Rural Populations
Project Summary: We co-designed a Heart Health Check Kit for home and pharmacy use, delivering results via phone or mail. This kit overcomes barriers rural communities face with the existing GP-centred model of heart health check care. We recruit rural participants to test the kit's feasibility, targeting people aged 45-79, and connect medium and high-risk individuals to available risk reduction programs and primary care. Success will be measured by community uptake and experiences with the proactive model.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Simon Egerton, Mrs Carrie Barlow, Associate Professor Carina Chan, Doctor Fiona Dangerfield, Associate Professor Brett Gordon, Associate Professor Lisa Hanson, Professor Leigh Kinsman, Doctor Voltaire Nadurata, Doctor Joyce Ramos, Mrs Brooke Shelly, Professor Timothy Skinner, Professor Joseph Tucci, Ms Katrina Umback
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /:
HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Digital health;
HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Rural and remote health services

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: A Culturally Informed Chronic Disease Prevention Model Using Technology and Indigenous Virtual Experience: THRIVE
Project Summary: Digital healthcare delivery models are increasingly being used in urban areas to streamline workflows, reduce costs, and optimise patient health outcomes. The adoption and impact of virtual healthcare models on rural Indigenous communities is not yet known. Enabling the implementation and adoption of a national virtual health service by using consumer-led and culturally informed frameworks will transform healthcare access for rural and remote Indigenous populations across Australia.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Bushra Nasir, Professor Khorshed Alam, Associate Professor Maria Donald, Mrs Lorraine Holley, Associate Professor Srinivas Kondalsamy Chennakesavan, Floyd Leedie, Doctor Priya Martin, Associate Professor Matthew McGrail, Professor Katharine Wallis, Salifu Yusif
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: HEALTH SCIENCES, Health services and systems, Rural and remote health services

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: Time is of the essence: using mixed methods to determine and understand the impact of COVID-19 sequelae in First Nations Australians in the Northern Territory
Project Summary: Our project aims to learn about the impact of long COVID in the Northern Territory (NT), focusing on First Nations people. To explore this, we will study people with long COVID from remote First Nations communities and renal patients. We will evaluate the impact of long COVID on physical health conditions and immune responses. We aim to guide future research directions and policies that contribute towards creating a service focused on First Nations people affected by long COVID in the NT.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Jane Davies, Associate Professor Oyelola Adegboye, Professor Christine Connors, Associate Professor Gillian Gorham, Associate Professor Nadarajah Kangaharan, Professor Katherine Kedzierska, Doctor Victoria Kerrigan, Mrs Joan Koops, Professor Sandawana Majoni, Mr Mark Mayo, Doctor Bianca Middleton, Doctor Thi Nguyen, Doctor Sophie Pascoe, Ms Cheryl Ross, Neil Wilkshire
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /:
BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Infectious diseases;
INDIGENOUS STUDIES, Aboriginal and torres strait islander health and wellbeing, Aboriginal and torres strait islander health services

Grant Opportunity: 2024 Survivorship Care and Collaborative Research Prioritisation
Project Name: Advancing Care Through Injury Outcome Navigators (ACTION) Study
Project Summary: Serious injury is a life changing event. Survivors of serious injury are required to navigate a myriad of health and social services that are underpinned by complex funding mechanisms to access the care that they need to recover. The ACTION trial will test whether implementing dedicated trauma patient navigators at Australian trauma centres enhances the experience and outcomes for survivors of serious injury and their close others, potentially transforming post-discharge care of trauma patients.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Belinda Gabbe, Doctor Clifford Afoakwah, Professor Zsolt Balogh, Professor Peter Cameron, Doctor Joanna Dipnall, Doctor Christina Ekegren, Professor Mark Fitzgerald, Doctor Lara Kimmel, Professor Natasha Lannin, Doctor David Livingston, Doctor Sandra Reeder, Associate Professor Warwick Teague, Professor Kirsten Vallmuur, Mrs Elizabeth Wake, Associate Professor Dieter Weber

Project Name: Personalised haematopoietic stem cells, moving transplantation into the 21st century
Project Summary: Many patients with leukaemia and bone marrow failure, or who receive high dose chemotherapy for cancer, require blood stem cell transplantation. Those without a suitably matched donor are at high risk of severe complications such as graft versus host disease. Personalised haematopoietic stem cells would provide a safe, therapeutic option for these patients. We can now generate these cells in the laboratory and we will develop techniques to make sufficient cells for patient transplantation.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Andrew Elefanty, Associate Professor Rachel Conyers, Professor Megan Munsie, Doctor Elizabeth Ng, Professor David Ritchie, Professor Edouard Stanley
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /:
BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Cardiovascular medicine and haematology, Haematology;
BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Medical biotechnology, Regenerative medicine (incl. stem cells)

Project Name: Bioengineering functional kidney proximal nephron arrays for bioartificial kidneys
Project Summary: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a leading cause of death globally with limited treatments. Portable bioartificial kidney (BAK) devices containing living human kidney cells show promise, but face challenges in establishing an optimal cell source. This project aims to generate accurate, stable, renewable, and functional kidney cells from human stem cells for future BAK development. If successful, this could transform the BAK field, improving outcomes and quality of life for CKD patients.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Jessica Vanslambrouck, Doctor Kynan Lawlor, Professor Melissa Little, Associate Professor Richard Mills, Associate Professor Catherine Quinlan

Organisation: The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: Making cultured red blood cells for transfusion a reality
Project Summary: There is an urgent need for innovative solutions to meet transfusion needs. Cultured red blood cells (cRBCs) produced from patient-derived stem cells in vitro represent a promising alternative. However, current in vitro production methods are financially untenable for large-scale application and there has been limited progress internationally. This incubator project will establish the feasibility of a novel approach to enhance and reduce costs of cRBC production, enabling this therapy.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Sant-Rayn Pasricha, Doctor Cavan Bennett, Associate Professor Melissa Call, Professor Erica Wood
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Cardiovascular medicine and haematology, Haematology

Project Name: Enhancing pluripotent stem cell derived heart muscle grafts for future clinical trials
Project Summary: Heart failure costs in Australia are over $1 Billion p.a. with 50% mortality within 1 year (stage IV disease). This arises from the heart’s limited capacity for self-repair. This project builds on our team's previous work with novel stem cell derived heart muscle, enhancing the therapeutic cell product and adding to our understanding of stakeholder needs so that this innovative treatment can seamlessly transition to later stage development and clinical trials.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor James Chong, Doctor Zoe Clayton, Doctor Steve Dingwall, Professor Ian Kerridge, Professor Nathan Lewis, Professor Wendy Lipworth, Associate Professor Quan Nguyen, Professor David Owen, Professor Enzo Porrello, Doctor Leila Reyes
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Cardiovascular medicine and haematology, Cardiology (incl. cardiovascular diseases)

Project Name: Controlled release of secretome from tailored hydrogels for wound healing therapy
Project Summary: Epidermolysis Bullosa (EB) is a rare genetic condition that leads to extreme skin fragility and open wounds all over the body. Currently there is no cure and treatments rely on surface dressings to protect from infection and further trauma. We propose to develop a completely new approach for the management of  EB wounds using a gel containing healing promoting agents produced by stem cells to promote healing responses.  This WoundGel would transform the treatment of wounds for people with EB.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Allison Cowin, Professor Johannes Kern, Professor Ferry Melchels
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /:
BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Clinical sciences, Dermatology;
ENGINEERING, Biomedical engineering, Biomedical engineering not elsewhere classified

Project Name: Lighting up human brain cells to help find safer and more effective medications for dementia
Project Summary: Dementia is a leading cause of death and presents a significant and growing health issue in Australia. New effective and safer medicines are needed to treat memory, thinking and mood symptoms. We aim to create innovative and reliable, human brain cell-based models. We will combine these new models with computer-guided discovery to rapidly find new drugs with the best chance of translating into real world medicines to reduce the impact of dementia on people living with dementia and their carers.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Karen Gregory, Professor Afia Ali, Doctor Rachelle Balez, Doctor Amanda Cross, Associate Professor Michelle Halls, Doctor Manuela Jorg, Doctor Amandeep Kaur, Doctor Lauren May, Professor Colin Pouton, Doctor Emily Reeve

Organisation: The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: Development of a patient stem-cell derived disease model platform for screening treatments for human colorectal cancer
Project Summary: Bowel cancer represents a critical and intractable health issue in Australia and globally. Recent advances in propagating patient tumour tissue in the laboratory now provide an opportunity to better model disease. This project will generate an Australian benchmark bio-resource of 200 patient tumour models for bowel cancer and workflows for high-throughput drug development to accelerate translation of emerging therapeutics into the clinic.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Oliver Sieber, Professor Peter Gibbs, Associate Professor Kym Lowes, Doctor Shehara Mendis, Doctor Dmitri Mouradov, Associate Professor Rachel Wong
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Oncology and carcinogenesis, Chemotherapy

Project Name: Evaluating new therapies to promote cardiomyocyte proliferation in heart failure using human stem cell derived cardiac organoids
Project Summary: Heart failure is a leading cause of death across the world with many patients still reliant on a heart transplant. Approaches to promote the regeneration of the heart may reduce the need for transplantation and transform the lives of patients. Here, our internationally recognised team of stem cell biologists and clinicians, will use stem cell models of the heart to evaluate the potential of new drugs that enhance heart regeneration to treat heart failure.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Enzo Porrello, Professor James Chong, Doctor Sean Humphrey, Professor Igor Konstantinov, Doctor Kevin Watt, Associate Professor Emily Wong
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /:
BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES, Biochemistry and cell biology, Signal transduction;
BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES, Biochemistry and cell biology, Cell development, proliferation and death

Organisation: The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: A novel platform to test and correct blood cell disorders
Project Summary: About 1/1000 Australians suffer from disorders of the blood and immune system, which are life-long and can be fatal. However, many newly diagnosed patients have an underlying cause that has never been seen before. We will implement a new 'blood in a dish' system using patient stem cells which can both "test" which disease they have, and then find which therapies might "correct" the disease. This system will allow a new generation of diagnostics and therapies for these patients with few options.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Shalin Naik, Doctor Esther Bandala Sanchez, Professor Simon Harrison, Doctor Miles Horton, Doctor Jeffrey Mitchell, Doctor Drew Neavin, Professor Joseph Powell, Doctor Charlotte Slade, Professor Melissa Southey, Doctor Sara Tomei, Miss Shuk-Yin (Sylvia) Tsang, Professor Erica Wood

Project Name: Developing genetic predisposition models of paediatric neuronal tumours
Project Summary: Neuronal tumours are the leading cause of death and disease related mortality in children. In this application we intend to generate new stem-cell based models of childhood neuronal tumours to uncover how genetic defects lead to cancer, and to provide new resources for identifying better treatment options to improve outcomes and decrease treatment toxicity.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Quenten Schwarz, Associate Professor Raelene Endersby, Associate Professor Jamie Fletcher, Professor Gregory Goodall, Professor Jordan Hansford, Professor Natasha Harvey, Professor Yeesim Khew-Goodall, Doctor Maria Kirby, Doctor Katherine Pillman, Doctor Mark Pinese, Professor Stuart Pitson
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES, Biochemistry and cell biology, Cell development, proliferation and death

Project Name: Establishing a comprehensive iPS Cell-Based Platform for Modelling Neurodevelopmental Disorders of the Epigenetic Machinery
Project Summary: Our project focuses on understanding and finding treatments for rare brain disorders caused by problems in how our cells control gene activity. These disorders often lead to severe learning disabilities and other serious brain disorders. We will create stem cells from patients with these disorders. By turning these stem cells into brain cells, we can make “disease models” to better understand how the diseases develop and also test many potential drugs  that might help treat the disorders.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Jose Polo, Doctor Rudrarup Bhattacharjee, Professor Ryan Lister, Doctor Daniel Poppe, Doctor Adrienne Sullivan
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /:
BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES, Genetics, Neurogenetics;
BIOMEDICAL AND CLINICAL SCIENCES, Medical biotechnology, Regenerative medicine (incl. stem cells)

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Frontier Health and Medical Research (Batch Two)
Organisation: The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: Next-generation dendritic cell immunotherapy for intractable solid cancers
Project Summary: This project aims to develop a first-in-human dendritic cell (DC)-based immunotherapy to treat patients with incurable solid cancers. It will use a world-first platform to produce type 1 conventional DCs (DC1s) at scale and supercharge them with chimeric antigen receptors (CARs). The resulting CAR-DC1s will enable enhanced tumour recognition and functionality. Program of research aims to develop technology to extend the lifespan and quality of life of patients with incurable solid cancers.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Stephen Laurence Nutt, Professor Kristen Radford, Professor Simon Harrison, Professor Shalin Naik, Professor Jeanne Tie, Doctor Cindy Audiger, Doctor Shengbo Zhang, Associate Professor Meredith O'Keeffe
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: Biointelect Venturer
Project Summary: Biointelect Venturer (BV), an innovative virtual Incubatorprogram designed to accelerate the development of preventative health technologies in Australia. BV will focus on supporting Australian small-to-medium enterprises (SME) with early-stage vaccines, vaccine-related technologies, and immunotherapies for infectious diseases at TRL 2 through 6, by leveraging existing infrastructure and facilities across Australia and from BV project partners and applying specialised product development expertise, upskilling and training. Our comprehensive, national approach aims to de-risk technologies and enhance their commercial and translation potential.
Chief Investigator Team: Ms Jennifer Herz, Professor Margaret Danchin, Doctor Jeff Davies, Doctor Martin Elhay, Doctor Mitch Hartman, Ms Leanne Hobbs, Ms Erica Kneipp, Professor Trent Munro, Doctor Camille Shanahan
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: ABOLISH DMG:  Defining the aetiology and biology of diffuse midline glioma
Project Summary: High risk childhood brain tumours are the leading cause of death and disease related mortality in children. In this application we intend to use new stem-cell based differentiation models to uncover the genetic drivers of childhood brain cancer to provide new resources for identifying better treatment options to improve patient outcomes.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Quenten Schwarz, Associate Professor Pascal Duijf, Professor Gregory Goodall, Professor Natasha Harvey, Associate Professor Luciano Martelotto, Doctor Marion Mateos, Doctor Katherine Pillman, Doctor Mark Pinese, Professor Stuart Pitson, Professor Jose Polo, Doctor Muhammed Hamidur Rahaman, Doctor Adrienne Sullivan
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

Organisation: Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation
Project Name: Targeting Glioma with Precision Radiotherapy and Biochemical Dose Amplification
Project Summary: Gliomas, including glioblastomas, are aggressive brain cancers that are difficult to treat due to their spread into healthy brain tissue. This project develops Neutron Capture Enhanced Particle Therapy (NCEPT), a new approach combining advanced drugs and precision radiation to selectively target tumour cells while protecting healthy tissue. By collaborating with leading researchers and facilities, this work aims to create a safer, more effective treatment for patients with limited options.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Mitra Safavi-Naeini, Doctor Chris Dobie, Doctor Ryoichi Hirayama, Mr Nicholas Howell, Doctor Klaudiusz Jakubowski, Associate Professor Hien Le, Doctor Carrie-Anne Ng, Associate Professor Giancarlo Pascali, Associate Professor Scott Penfold, Doctor Antoni Rucinski, Associate Professor Alexandre Santos, Associate Professor Angelo Schiavi, Doctor Frederic Sierro, Professor Danielle Skropeta, Doctor Masaru Wakatsuki
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

Project Name: BALLOON: Bacterial mucosal immunotherapy for prevention of lower respiratory tract infections in preterm born infants
Project Summary: Preterm infants are very susceptible to serious lung infections in conjunction with their pre-existing lung diseaseoften resulting in hospitalisation. Severe lung infections also increase the baby's chance of developing wheeze, asthma and breathing problems through life. This clinical trial will test if a mouth spray (Bactek) can prevent severe early life lung infections by training the immune system of preterm infants.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Shannon Simpson, Mrs Amber Bates, Associate Professor Natalie Carvalho, Professor Jeanie Cheong, Associate Professor Kim Dalziel, Doctor Cassidy Du Berry, Doctor James Gibbons, Professor Helen Liley, Doctor Abhijeet Rakshasbhuvankar, Professor Paul Robinson, Doctor Shivanthan Shanthikumar
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

Project Name: HIGH-FIVE – Phase 3 randomised trial of five fraction radiation therapy for high-risk prostate cancer
Project Summary: HIGH-FIVE is a Phase 3 randomized trial comparing 20-39 treatments daily radiotherapy (control arm) vs 5-treatment stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT, intervention arm) for high-risk prostate cancer, with metastases free survival as the primary end point. If 5-treatment prostate SBRT is shown to be non-inferior, this will be a new standard of care radiotherapy option for high-risk prostate cancer, with huge implication on patients’ treatment convenience and public healthcare cost saving.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Wee Loon Ong, Professor Damien Bolton, Professor Annette Haworth, Doctor Karen Hoffman, Doctor Therese Kang, Doctor Long Le, Professor Jeremy Millar, Professor Paul Nguyen, Associate Professor David Pryor, Doctor Mark Sidhom, Doctor Niluja Thiruthaneeswaran, Professor Rory Wolfe
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: The Invisible Infertile: Understanding Fertility Treatment Experiences Among CALD Women to Inform Psychoeducational Support and Culturally Responsive Care.
Project Summary: Migrant and refugee women from culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) backgrounds experience inequities in accessing fertility treatments and poorer outcomes. This mixed-method study explores the physical and psychological impact of fertility treatment for CALD women in Australia, and the barriers and facilitators to culturally responsive care. Findings will inform the co-creation of psychoeducational support resource for CALD women and recommendations for healthcare professionals.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Alexandra Hawkey, Ms Delaram Ansari, Professor Angela Dawson, Associate Professor Carolyn Ee, Associate Professor Rakime Elmir, Doctor Maria Hach, Professor Pranee Liamputtong, Doctor Shanna Logan, Doctor Rosalie Power, Associate Professor Shameran Slewa-younan, Professor Jane Ussher
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Identifying and addressing physical, emotional and psychological impacts of fertility treatment and its outcomes on prospective parents
Project Summary: Infertility affects 1 in 6 couples and Australia has one of the highest rates of infertility treatment globally. Advances in care are significant, however there is a plethora of misinformation, perverse commercial incentives and limited research, evidence or translation on the physical, emotional and psychological impacts of infertility treatment for prospective parents, especially in priority populations. Here we partner to identify and mitigate impacts including a novel digital intervention.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Helena Teede, Mrs Susanne Baker, Professor Jacky Boivin, Doctor Michael Costello, Associate Professor Joanne Enticott, Professor Roger Hart, Ms Cailin Jordan, Ms Rebecca Kerner, Doctor Sarah Lensen, Professor Ben W. Mol, Associate Professor Lisa Moran, Doctor Sandra Reeder, Professor Luk Rombauts, Mrs Ladan Yeganeh
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Safer Baby (SEEK): Strengths-based Education, Empowerment and Knowledge for help-seeking during pregnancy
Project Summary: Parents need timely, evidence-based, appropriate, and equal access to help when they are concerned during pregnancy. Getting rid of barriers and empowering parents to seek help fosters healthier pregnancies. We will deliver co-designed solutions, resources and education for both parents and healthcare professionals to support help-seeking during pregnancy and promote shared understanding for culturally safe and responsive pregnancy care.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Christine Andrews, Mrs Valerie Ah Chee, Associate Professor Frances Boyle, Associate Professor Zoe Bradfield, Associate Professor Miranda Davies-Tuck, Doctor Kelsey Deane, Professor Vicki Flenady, Professor Adrienne Gordon, Professor Charlotte Hespe, Professor Janet Kelly, Associate Professor Christoph Lehner, Mrs Samantha Payne, Doctor Danielle Pollock, Ms Deanna Stuart-Butler, Mrs Kirstin Tindal
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: TIM TAMS: Placental Health Test to Prevent Stillbirths and Adverse Pregnancy Outcomes
Project Summary: Blood tests are commonly ordered to check on the health of the liver, kidney, thyroid and so many organs. No such health test exists for the placenta. In an Aussie-wide effort stretching from the city to remote Broome (including first Nation Australians), we will validate the first placental health blood test. A test that's simple, accurate and accessible. A high risk result will save babies from stillbirth. A low risk result will offer reassurance that the placenta is healthy and baby is safe.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Stephen Tong, Doctor Lucy Bartho, Professor Adrienne Gordon, Doctor Roxanne Hastie, Professor Lisa Hui, Professor Tu'uhevaha Kaitu'u-Lino, Ms Sienna Kolatowicz, Doctor Teresa MacDonald, Doctor Simone Mulder, Mrs Elsa Murray-White, Professor Craig Pennell, Mrs Alexandra Tighe, Professor Susan Walker, Associate Professor Jared Watts

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Development and Validation of a Novel Stillbirth Risk Prediction Model in Australia
Project Summary: Building on our previous work that developed Australia’s first stillbirth prediction model, this project will create a new, comprehensive risk tool by integrating both established and novel clinical variables. Using data from local health districts, the tool will improve prediction accuracy across diverse populations and settings. This will enable earlier identification of high-risk pregnancies, allowing for timely interventions to reduce stillbirth and improve outcomes.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Gavin Pereira, Ms Olga Aleshin, Doctor Diana Bond, Doctor Laura Gerhardy, Ms Haylee Hawkins, Mrs Catherine Hughes, Professor Natasha Nassar, Professor Camille Raynes-Greenow, Doctor Antonia Shand, Associate Professor Gizachew Tessema, Doctor Kingsley Wong

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Australian Perimenopause and Menopause (A-PaM) Study
Project Summary: Many women experience challenging symptoms during perimenopause and menopause that can affect physical and mental health and work life. This new national study will address current knowledge gaps on perimenopause and menopause and how the impacts vary for women across Australia and from diverse communities, including their healthcare service and workplace preferences. Study findings will inform improvements in healthcare and workplace support for all women going through this life transition.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Gita Mishra, Professor Jason Abbott, Professor Debra Anderson, Ms Delaram Ansari, Doctor Mridula Bandyopadhyay, Doctor Mohammad Reza Baneshi, Associate Professor Jacqueline Boyle, Doctor Joan Carlini, Doctor Hsin-Fang Chung, Doctor Tessa Copp, Sandra Creamer, Professor Richard De Abreu Lourenco, Professor Annette Dobson, Professor Jenny Doust, Associate Professor Subhadra Evans, Associate Professor Luke Grzeskowiak, Professor Martha Hickey, Associate Professor Sheleigh Lawler, Professor Danielle Mazza, Professor Antonina Mikocka-Walus, Professor Barbara Mintzes, Doctor Sally-Anne Mortlock, Doctor Adele Murdolo, Doctor Maryam Naghsh Nejad, Mrs Mary O'Callaghan, Associate Professor Thelma Parker, Associate Professor Ines Rio, Doctor Ivana Rizzuto, Doctor Tin Fei Sim, Doctor Munawwara Talat Uppal, Associate Professor Lata Vadlamudi, Associate Professor Serena Yu

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: The impact of plastic food and drink packaging toxicants on unexplained female infertility
Project Summary: This project focuses on the risks posed by bisphenols (BPA, BPS, BPF) in food packaging, which can harm female fertility by affecting egg quality. In Australia, there are minimal regulations on bisphenol levels in food. We aim to determine safe exposure limits and raise awareness among consumers. By combining lab studies with real-world data and engaging with the public and stakeholders, we hope to inform policy changes and improve health outcomes related to unexplained female infertility.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Jessie Sutherland, Doctor Tanmay Bagade, Doctor Catherine Chojenta, Doctor Mark Green, Professor Deborah Loxton, Doctor Jacinta Martin, Professor Eileen McLaughlin, Ms Alexandra Peters, Professor Kirsty Pringle, Doctor Shaun Roman, Doctor Xianyu Wang, Doctor Ian Zammit
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: A role for mobile DNA in unexplained female infertility
Project Summary: The reasons that some women struggle to conceive are often unknown. We will examine how bits of DNA called "jumping genes" damage the genetic code of egg cells, contributing to female infertility. We will measure jumping gene damage in young versus aging egg cells and in egg cells produced during fertility treatments. Our Research aims to explain a significant portion of female infertility cases, and lead to new strategies for improved outcomes for women experiencing infertility.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Sandra Richardson, Doctor Adam Ewing, Doctor Michael Pankhurst, Doctor Stephanie Workman
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Early gestation immune determinants of pregnancy loss
Project Summary: Early pregnancy loss is common and improved care and prevention is needed. Preconception planning and treatment interventions for both intending parents are limited by poor understanding of the underlying causes. This study will investigate the importance of the female immune response, and the role of metabolic, hormone, and male partner factors to pregnancy outcome. The results are expected to provide valuable insight into causes of pregnancy loss, and will assist development of better care.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Sarah Robertson, Professor Simon Barry, Doctor Kerrie Foyle, Professor Mary (Louise) Hull, Doctor Jennie Louise, Doctor Lachlan Moldenhauer, Associate Professor Cecilia Sjoblom Ahlstrom
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: FIND MIPD: Functional Interrogation of Novel Disease Mechanisms to Improve Pregnancy loss Diagnosis
Project Summary: The loss of a pregnancy or newborn is a devastating outcome for parents, with profound psychological, social and economic impacts. A lack of explanation for their loss is distressing for many parents and a lack of genomic diagnosis often means no options to reduce recurrence risk. Despite the Genomic Autopsy Study providing over 400 nationally referred couples with genomic testing, half of all families remain without a genetic cause; warranting further interrogation of the biological mechanisms.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Matilda Jackson, Professor Cedric Bardy, Professor Christopher Barnett, Doctor Thi Thuong Ha, Professor Natasha Harvey, Doctor Lachlan Jolly, Associate Professor Quenten Schwarz, Professor Hamish Scott, Professor Paul Thomas, Doctor Kate Vandyke
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Mechanisms contributing to placental insufficiency and adverse neonatal outcomes across the birthweight centile continuum
Project Summary: Often poor outcomes in pregnancy are attributed to very small babies but our Research shows babies of any size can die either in utero or after birth. We propose the risk of death of any sized baby is due to a poor functioning placenta. We will test this hypothesis by examining placentae from babies of all sizes that had an adverse outcome. This work will define the common placental mechanisms that lead to stillbirth and neonatal death regardless of the size of the baby at birth.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Vicki Clifton, Associate Professor Brian Cox, Doctor Arutha Kulasinghe, Professor Wendy Robinson, Doctor Sarah Elizabeth Steane
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Evaluating NAD-related biomarkers for Miscarriage Risk (NADIM Study)
Project Summary: This project will determine levels of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), a form of vitamin B3, and related metabolites among women with a history and/or experiencing miscarriage and compare with women without miscarriage. We will assess lived experience and determine role of diet, lifestyle, and number/timing of miscarriage. Findings will show links between NAD and miscarriage and identify potential biomarkers to predict future pregnancy loss, inform prevention, and target new treatments.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Antonia Shand, Ms Olga Aleshin, Doctor Diana Bond, Professor Clare Collins, Doctor Hartmut Cuny, Professor Sally Dunwoodie, Doctor Laura Gerhardy, Professor Natasha Nassar, Doctor Rachael Rodgers, Doctor Francisco Schneuer, Doctor Cansu Uzuner
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Uncovering Causes and Predicting Pregnancy Loss in Assisted Reproductive Technology
Project Summary: This project aims to reduce pregnancy loss in assisted reproductive technology (ART), where around 20% of pregnancies are lost. Our goal is to understand the reasons for these losses and develop models to predict the risk of pregnancy loss. The findings and predictive tools for pregnancy loss in ART will be shared through a government-funded and trusted platform - YourIVFSuccess website. This will help couples and doctors make informed and personalised treatment decisions.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Wentao Li, Professor Georgina Chambers, Doctor Michael Costello, Doctor Oisin Fitzgerald, Associate Professor Tanya Nippita
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Understanding mechanisms and optimising health after early menopause
Project Summary: Around 10% of women experience early menopause (before age 45 years). This may follow surgery or cancer treatment, but is often spontaneous and in many cases the cause is not known. This will be the first study to determine the genetic and environmental risk factors for early menopause, deliver an evidence-based tool for diagnosis and management and new health information and support resources for culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) women who are at elevated risk of early menopause.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Martha Hickey, Doctor Mridula Bandyopadhyay, Doctor Hsin-Fang Chung, Doctor Tessa Copp, Doctor Martina de Witte, Professor Jenny Doust, Professor Kirsten McCaffery, Professor Gita Mishra, Doctor Sally-Anne Mortlock, Associate Professor Michelle Peate, Doctor Sarah Price, Associate Professor Ines Rio
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: The FERTILE Study: Evaluating ovarian toxicity Outcomes Following Immunotherapy in Triple-Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC)
Project Summary:
Immunotherapy causes substantial damage to ovaries in mice. It is not known if immunotherapy can cause similar damage to human ovaries, leading to infertility and early-onset menopause. 
This is a crucial information gap for patients.  
This study will assess ovarian function in premenopausal women with early-stage, curable triple negative breast cancer receiving chemoimmunotherapy, and will provide the first prospective human data on the impact of chemoimmunotherapy on ovarian function.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Wanyuan Cui, Professor Frances Boyle, Doctor Maree Colosimo, Ms Mariana Corrales Benítez, Professor Karla Hutt, Associate Professor Rohit Joshi, Doctor Sanjeev Kumar, Doctor Louisa Lo, Louise Nott, Doctor Christopher Oldmeadow, Doctor Genia Rozen, Associate Professor Catharyn Stern, Michelle White, Doctor Amy Winship
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: PPP study: Personalised POI Prediction
Project Summary: Around 16% of Australian women experience menopause before age 45, including those with premature ovarian insufficiency (POI), which happens before 40. Early menopause can lead to health issues like infertility and dementia. Diagnosis is often delayed, causing distress and poorer health. We will develop a risk prediction tool for POI to enable early identification and better care. This will build on our work with international guidelines and the Ask Early Menopause App, helping women worldwide.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Joanne Enticott, Mrs Susanne Baker, Professor Emily Callander, Mrs Kirsty Costa, Doctor Lan Du, Professor Megan Galbally, Doctor Alicia Jones, Ms Cailin Jordan, Doctor Samantha Kozica, Doctor Karen Magraith, Mr Yitayeh Mengistu, Associate Professor Lisa Moran, Doctor Sandra Reeder, Professor Helena Teede, Associate Professor Amanda Vincent
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Australian Premature Ovarian Insufficiency NeTwork (A-POINT): A national patient-centred multiomics study to discover causes of early menopause
Project Summary: This project uses cutting-edge “multiomic” technologies to study patients with early menopause. We will validate likely genetic causes using innovative models of ovarian disease, including patient cells, in vitro assays and animal studies. We will also identify lifestyle and genetic risk factors for low ovarian reserve using a Western Australia birth cohort. Identifying cause enables personalised care, better outcomes, and pre-symptomatic diagnosis with opportunity for fertility preservation.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Elena Tucker, Associate Professor Alison Archibald, Doctor Katrina Bell, Associate Professor Louise Conwell, Associate Professor Belinda Dawson McClaren, Associate Professor Sunita De Sousa, Doctor Rebecca Deans, Professor Sonia Grover, Ms Chloe Hanna, Professor Roger Hart, Professor Gary Hime, Associate Professor Sebastian Lunke, Professor Andrew Sinclair, Associate Professor David Stroud

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Improving Health Outcomes of People with Intellectual Disability
Project Name: Achieving good oral health for young people with intellectual disability is everyone's task
Project Summary: The project aims to develop and evaluate an oral health assessment tool for non-dental professionals and carers who regularly interact with people with intellectual disability. Such a tool will allow early oral conditions to be detected, prevented from further progression, and promptly referred for treatment. It will effectively prevent oral diseases and allow vulnerable people with disability to live unaffected by oral pain and complications.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Loc Do, Doctor Vinh Bui, Doctor Kitty-Rose Foley, Doctor Diep Ha, Professor Steve Kisely, Doctor Trudy Lin, Doctor Claudia Lopez Silva, Doctor Kristiana Ludlow, Doctor Son Nghiem, Professor Johannes Prins, Doctor Helena Schuch, Doctor Lydia See, Doctor Kirstine Shrubsole, Doctor James Smith, Professor Amanda Wheeler
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Improving Health Outcomes of People with Intellectual Disability
Project Name: Australia’s first co-created workforce model to advance preventive oral healthcare for people with intellectual disability
Project Summary: People with intellectual disability often have poor oral health. This can be from a lack of preventive oral health care, or from inadequate care from untrained disability support workers. This project will work with people with intellectual disability and disability services to co-create a cutting-edge online oral health education resource for disability support workers. The oral health of people with intellectual disability will be improved, with problems identified and treated earlier.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Nathan Wilson, Doctor Samuel Arnold, Professor Hanny Calache, Professor Ajesh George, Associate Professor Caoimhin Mac Giolla Phadraig, Doctor Phuong Nguyen, Miss Inès Phlypo, Doctor Archana Pradhan, Miss Kylie Scott, Associate Professor Leonie Short, Professor Linda Slack-Smith, Associate Professor Joanne Watson

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Improving Health Outcomes of People with Intellectual Disability
Project Name: Enhancing Access to Healthcare for People with Intellectual Disabilities: A Multi-tiered Sedation Model
Project Summary: People with intellectual disabilities face poorer health outcomes, including higher rates of preventable deaths. Sometimes blood tests can be distressing, leading healthcare providers to skip essential tests. Blood tests are vital to manage health conditions, yet these are often overlooked. This project aims to test an idea that a team of healthcare professionals can look at several ways to complete a blood test, this might include gradually building up confidence, or sedating medications.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Jessica Smith, Doctor Richard Barnes, Doctor Katie Brooker, Ms Ruby De Greef, Ms Leila Elliott, Doctor Catherine Franklin, Professor Gillian Harvey, Professor Jonathan Karnon, Doctor Murthy Mittinty, Doctor Andrea Simpson, Ms Mia Smyrell, Doctor Megan Stewart, Doctor Fiona Taverner, Ms Michelle Templeton, Associate Professor Craig Whitehead
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Improving Health Outcomes of People with Intellectual Disability
Project Name: Co-designing and evaluating a cross-sector physical activity navigator program for adults with intellectual disability
Project Summary: The project aims to increase participation in physical activity for adults with intellectual disability who are more likely to be physically inactive than adults without disability. A cross-sector navigator program will be co-designed and delivered to provide support to adults with intellectual disability and their family to identify and participate in suitable physical activity. The program will be evaluated with likely outcomes of improved health and social benefits for people with disability.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Leanne Hassett, Associate Professor Natalie Allen, Ms Jenni Cole, Doctor Che Fornusek, Associate Professor Joanne Glinsky, Doctor Phil Hamdorf, Doctor Abigail Haynes, Doctor Katherine Lawler, Doctor Georgia Mckenzie, Associate Professor Gillian Nisbet, Doctor Louise Pearce, Professor Catherine Sherrington, Professor Nora Shields, Professor Benjamin Smith, Professor Jennifer Smith-Merry

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Improving Health Outcomes of People with Intellectual Disability
Project Name: Profound Pathways: Improving Health Care Transition and Decision-Making for Young Adults with Severe and Profound Intellectual Disabilities
Project Summary: People with severe and profound intellectual disabilities have complex health care needs and have difficulties accessing, managing, and deciding about their health care. When young people move to adult health care their needs are not always met. Profound Pathways is led by people with lived experience to highlight these urgent problems and to co-design solutions for health care transition and decision-making that better include people with severe and profound intellectual disabilities.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Michelle King, Associate Professor Michelle Bellon, Professor Christine Bigby, Mr David Bunker, Professor John Devereux, Ms Sheree Henley, Professor Glenn Marshall, Jordana McLoone, Ms Kristine Pierce, Associate Professor Malcolm Smith, Doctor Hayley Smithers-Sheedy, Doctor Anneliese Synnot, Professor Tari Turner, Professor Amanda Ullman, Associate Professor Sarah Wallace

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Improving Health Outcomes of People with Intellectual Disability
Project Name: My Health Care Choices My Way
Project Summary: This project will help young people with intellectual disability get better health care when they move from children's to adult health services. Working together with young people, families, doctors, advocates and educators, we will make tools and training to help people make their own health choices and get care that works for them. Led by people with disability, the project includes both First Nations and non-First Nations streams and will develop national guides to improve health services.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Iva Strnadova, Doctor Rula Ali, Professor Reema Harrison, Associate Professor Benjamin Harris-Roxas, Miss Julie Loblinzk Refalo, Professor Kevin Lowe, Doctor Laurel Mimmo, Associate Professor Mary-Ann O'Donovan, Doctor Elizabeth Palmer, Associate Professor Gregory Pratt, Mrs Skie Sarfaraz, Ms Bronwyn Terrill, Professor Julian Trollor, Doctor Mary White, Professor Susan Woolfenden

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Improving Health Outcomes of People with Intellectual Disability
Project Name: From silos to synergy: Improving timely access to health services that support healthy ageing in people with intellectual disability
Project Summary: Australians aged 65+ can access aged health care, but this doesn't suit people with intellectual disabilities, who often age prematurely. Current policies create barriers to proper care. Inspired by Indigenous health policies, this project aims to set a fairer age for access and develop key health indicators. Researchers will analyse existing datasets, study ageing trends, and gather insights from affected communities to recommend better policies.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Kate Laver, Doctor Manya Angley, Doctor Irene Belperi, Professor Gillian Caughey, Professor Maria Crotty, Doctor Kisani Manuel, Doctor Jacqueline Roseleur, Doctor Jessica Smith, Doctor Ruth Walker, Associate Professor Craig Whitehead

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Improving Health Outcomes of People with Intellectual Disability
Project Name: Reducing health inequities for older people with intellectual disability in rural Australia
Project Summary:
This project will look at how health services in rural areas can be improved to better support older people with an intellectual disability. 

It has been co-designed with rural people with lived experience of intellectual disability. 

We will talk with people about their experiences with services. We will also look at how people's health changes over time. 

We will use this information to help services to work together to better support for older people with intellectual disability in rural areas.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Stuart Wark, Associate Professor Sally Bristow, Professor Andrew Cashin, Doctor Gisselle Gallego, Associate Professor Melissa Nott, Doctor Ann Skoss, Professor Kim Usher, Professor Sarah Wayland, Professor Nathan Wilson

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Improving Health Outcomes of People with Intellectual Disability
Project Name: Patient-led identification of unmet health and psychosocial needs by people with intellectual disability
Project Summary: Routine health screening is a way to identify and address unmet needs to improve health outcomes among people with intellectual disability. Patient-reported outcome measures are a method of health screening in which patients can identify their own needs; the results can be used by health services to provide appropriate care. We will co-produce, implement and test a patient-reported outcome measure system for and with people with intellectual disability to improve their health outcomes.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Reema Harrison, Doctor Louise Ellis, Professor Ling Li, Professor Elizabeth Manias, Doctor Laurel Mimmo, Professor Rebecca Mitchell, Doctor Virginia Mumford, Doctor Bronwyn Newman, Associate Professor Melissa Nott, Professor Patrick Olivier, Professor Pandora Patterson, Professor Iva Strnadova, Professor Julian Trollor, Professor Johanna Westbrook, Professor Susan Woolfenden

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Improving Health Outcomes of People with Intellectual Disability
Project Name: Know Me, Support Me: AI reasoning tool for identifying and managing health issues of people with intellectual disability
Project Summary: People with intellectual disability often need support for their health. Sometimes their supports might miss signs that the person’s physical or mental health is changing. Our project will develop an AI tool to help notice these changes and seek medical help when needed. The tool will also help them talk about the signs with health professionals, so they can make health plans. We will work with people with intellectual disability and their supporters to co-design the AI tool and test it.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Margo Barr, Professor Rhonda Faragher, Professor Karen Fisher, Ms Erin Forrester, Mrs Lisa Hutchinson, Doctor Frank Iorfino, Doctor Cathy O'Callaghan, Doctor Peri O'Shea, Doctor Dinesh Palipana, Professor Vivienne Riches, Doctor Ann Skoss, Associate Professor Natalie Taylor, Professor Stuart Wark, Doctor Janelle Weise, Professor Nathan Wilson

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Improving Health Outcomes of People with Intellectual Disability
Project Name: Building Reasonable adjustments, Inclusion, and Dignity in Emergency care for people with Intellectual Disabilities (BRIDGE-ED)
Project Summary: People with disability can experience difficulties navigating emergency departments, communicating their needs and preferences and understanding treatment options. Disability Liaison Officers (DLOs) act as a bridge between healthcare staff, patients and carers. Using a co-design framework, we will conduct a stepped-wedge cluster randomised trial to assess the effect of DLOs on health outcomes and patient experience of people with intellectual and other developmental disabilities.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Biswadev Mitra, Associate Professor Hamed Akhlaghi, Doctor Elyssia Bourke, Professor George Braitberg, Associate Professor Paul Buntine, Doctor Kate DCruz, Doctor Joanna Dipnall, Doctor Kitty-Rose Foley, Mr Peter Ghijben, Doctor Julia Gilmartin-Thomas, Doctor Carlee Holmes, Doctor Denise Jones, Associate Professor Robyn O'Halloran, Doctor Casey Peiris, Professor Nicholas Taylor

Project Name: Australian Pathogen Genomics Program
Project Summary: Pathogen genomics is a powerful new tool to understand infectious diseases transmission and outbreaks. The Australian Pathogen Genomics Program will embed pathogen genomic surveillance into practice nationally and optimise the surveillance approaches to reduce the burden of infectious diseases. The Program will also incorporate exciting new methods (such as wastewater surveillance) and ensure Australia's infectious diseases surveillance system is prepared for emerging threats.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Benjamin Howden, Doctor Patiyan Andersson, Doctor Alicia Arnott, Professor Asha Bowen, Professor Steven Djordjevic, Doctor Celeste Donato, Doctor Angeline Ferdinand, Professor Kathryn Glass, Associate Professor Amy Jennison, Professor Martyn Kirk, Mr Mark Mayo, Doctor Freya Shearer, Professor Vitali Sintchenko, Doctor David Speers, Professor Nicola Stephens

Project Name: Integrating sequencing technologies for bloodstream infection and sepsis diagnostics in critically-ill patients
Project Summary: Advances in genomics holds great promise to revolutionise our ability to treat patients with life-threatening infections. We will enrol more than 1200 ICU-admitted patients with suspected sepsis into a randomised trial, to compare a rapid host-biomarker test and targeted pathogen DNA sequencing from blood to guide antibiotic therapy. The trial will evaluate this novel approach, robustly assessing the clinical impact and health economic benefits in comparison to standard diagnostic methods.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Patrick Harris, Doctor Kim Edmunds, Doctor Brian Forde, Associate Professor Kristen Gibbons, Doctor Bianca Graves, Associate Professor Adam Irwin, Doctor Burcu Isler, Doctor Anna Maria Peri, Doctor Sainath Raman, Professor Jason Roberts, Professor Mark Schembri, Professor Kiran Shekar, Doctor Shradha Subedi, Associate Professor Alexis Tabah
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

Project Name: MITIGATE: Metagenomics and Integrated Transcriptomics for Infectious disease Genomics And Translational Evaluation
Project Summary: We want to improve how we diagnose infections using cutting-edge technology. Instead of relying on traditional methods, we’ll use a more advanced approach that looks at all the genes of both the patient and the infection, specifically in areas like brain and lung infections. Our plan is to speed up diagnosis, find more accurate results, and create treatments tailored to each patient. This project will also reduce healthcare costs by helping doctors make more precise decisions.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Prashanth Ramachandran, Doctor Katherine Bond, Associate Professor Penelope Bryant, Associate Professor Leon Caly, Doctor Amy Crowe, Associate Professor Maryza Graham, Euzebiusz Jamrozik, Doctor Chuan Kok Lim, Professor Lyndell Lim, Professor Monica Slavin, Doctor Eike Steinig, Professor Tim Stinear, Doctor Michelle Tew, Doctor Eloise Williams
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

Project Name: Precision AMR genomics to guide infection control and novel therapeutics
Project Summary: Rapid precise genomics allows us to pinpoint the nature of AMR transmission in people and in hospitals and to identify how this spreads. We use rapidgenomics platforms to enable clinicians and public health officials to recognise AMR transmission and intervene in timely fashion. We will provide these tools in accessible reports that not only accelerate well-proven responses to disease transmission but also directly and immediately enable exciting new therapies that we have pioneered.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Jonathan Iredell, Doctor Nouri Ben Zakour, Doctor Grace Blackwell, Doctor Jackie Chan, Doctor Kate Clezy, Doctor Jenny Draper, Doctor Alicia Fajardo Lubian, Doctor Annaleise Howard-Jones, Doctor Muhammad Kamruzzaman, Professor Ruby Lin, Associate Professor Sally Partridge, Doctor Indy Sandaradura, Professor Ramon Shaban, Doctor Holly Sinclair, Associate Professor Phoebe Williams

Project Name: Transforming Patient Care with Pathogen Genomics, Digital Health and Machine Learning
Project Summary: This project aims to use new technologies in healthcare, such as genome sequencing of bacteria that cause serious infections, combined with electronic medical record data from patients with these infections, to inform new diagnostics, optimised therapies and cutting-edge prevention of outbreaks of antimicrobial resistant organisms. New ways of analysis large amounts of data will be tested to help healthcare providers make the best decisions for patient care and hospital resource efficiencies.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Anton Peleg, Associate Professor Darshini Ayton, Doctor Jane Hawkey, Professor Kathryn Holt, Professor Tony Korman, Doctor Nenad Macesic, Professor Trisha Peel, Associate Professor Benjamin Rogers, Doctor Francesca Short, Professor Jiangning Song, Associate Professor Andrew Stewardson, Professor Rhonda Stuart, Associate Professor Sonika Tyagi, Doctor Kelly Wyres

Organisation: The Council of the Queensland Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: Harnessing Genomics and Citizen Science to Combat Invasive Mosquitoes and Mosquito-Borne Viruses
Project Summary: Exotic mosquito-borne diseases like dengue, Zika, and Japanese encephalitis pose a growing threat to Australian communities. This project uses genomics and citizen science to predict mosquito vector invasions, detect mosquito-borne viruses, and empower communities. By predicting hotspots, creating detection tools, and involving schools, we aim to build a scalable early-warning system, improving public health preparedness to reduce arbovirus outbreak risks for safer Australian communities.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Gordana Rasic, Doctor Jennifer Bannan, Doctor Nancy Cloake, Associate Professor Francesca Frentiu, Doctor Leon Hugo, Doctor Brian Johnson, Mr Brian Montgomery
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

Project Name: A Comprehensive ADME Genomic Profile to Enhance Safety and Reduce Medicine Harms
Project Summary: Over 700 medicines used in Australia show unpredictable effects, leading to safety issues and 275,000 hospitalizations annually. Better tools to predict how medicines will affect individuals could prevent 25% of these cases. Current methods focus on genetic testing, which hasn’t meaningfully changed in 40 years. This project explores a new approach: analyzing tiny liver particles found in blood to predict risks from non-genetic factors, improving medicine safety and reducing adverse events.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Andrew Rowland, Professor Susan Branford, Professor Henk Jan Guchelaar, Associate Professor Ashley Hopkins, Professor Christos Karapetis, Professor Jonathan Karnon, Doctor Ganessan Kichenadasse, Doctor Lauren Newman, Associate Professor David Ross, Professor Hamish Scott, Professor Michael Sorich, Associate Professor Timothy To, Doctor Ian Westley
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

Project Name: The Australian Pharmacogenetic Paediatric Oncology Network for Drug Safety (AUS-POND)
Project Summary: This project establishes a national network to improve children's cancer treatment using genetics. It has three parts: (1) Gathering data on treatment side effects and ensuring enrolment of diverse ancestry communities (2) linking genetic results to drug side effects and (3) improving the use of genotype informed prescribing by education for the workforce, web-portals of Research results and general public events. The goal is safer, more effective cancer treatment.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Rachel Conyers, Professor Ewan Birney, Professor John Christodoulou, Professor Tomas Fitzgerald, Professor Amy Gray, Associate Professor Amanda Gwee, Doctor Andreas Halman, Ms Dhrita Khatri, Professor Daniel MacArthur, Doctor Emma Magavern, Doctor Marion Mateos, Ms Claire Moore, Associate Professor Mirana Ramialison, Professor Jesse Swen, Doctor Felicity Wright

Project Name: Trial Implementation of Pharmacogenomics to improve Complex Hospital care
Project Summary: Building on their experience in the field of clinical pharmacogenomics (PGx) the investigators will identify and address the causes of the lack of clinical implementation by focusing on barriers including health records, molecular testing platforms and workforce education. We will demonstrate our impact in the fields of cancer therapy and organ transplant and use an Implementation Science approach to provide a general framework for accelerating the introduction of PGx into Australian hospitals.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Paul James, Doctor Marliese Alexander, Ms Stephanie Chau, Jenny Devine, Doctor Timothy Fazio, Associate Professor Peter Hughes, Associate Professor Safeera Hussainy, Doctor Kushani Jayasinghe, Senthil Lingaratnam, Professor Michael Michael, Associate Professor Chris Schilling, Associate Professor Leslie Sheffield, Graham Starkey, Associate Professor Natalie Taylor, Doctor Bryony Thompson

Project Name: Long-read sequencing and AI-driven functional annotation for equitable pharmacogenomics in Indigenous Australians
Project Summary: This project aims to improve medication safety for Indigenous Australians by identifying genetic differences that affect how genes are expressed their interactions with medicines. Using advanced long-read sequencing and artificial intelligence, we will create a detailed map of important medicine-related genes. This Research will help develop equitable, scalable, and accurate pharmacogenomic guidelines to reduce harmful reactions and improve health outcomes for all.

Project Name: CYP2C19 genetic testing to enhance antiplatelet drug safety and efficacy
Project Summary: Clopidogrel, used to prevent future heart attacks, is ineffective in a third of Australians. A gene test can identify these patients but isn’t done. This project aims to test all heart attack patients needing a stent in 5 NSW hospitals. Outcomes include identifying current antiplatelet prescribing, building practitioner/consumer knowledge, determining best testing methods, and assessing health and economic benefits. The goal is to ensure all Australians receive effective antiplatelet medicines.

Project Name: Pharmacogenetics to improve drug tolerability in child psychiatry
Project Summary: This project will investigate whether existing pharmacogenetic tests can reduce medication harm from drugs used to treat mental health disorders in children and whether better tests can be developed.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Enda Byrne, Professor David Coghill, Professor Valsamma Eapen, Doctor Kannan Kallapiran, Doctor Syed Afroz Keramat, Doctor Shaneen Leishman, Professor Sarah Medland, Professor Christel Middeldorp, Doctor Brittany Mitchell, Professor James Scott

Project Name: Improving pharmacogenomics prediction of antidepressant response via deep learning integration of multi-omics from multi-cohort randomised controlled pharmacogenomics trials: The ALIGNED multimodal multi-omic (ALIGNED-M4) study
Project Summary: Treatment-resistant depression (TRD) is common and diagnosed following several antidepressant trials-and-error rounds, resulting in significant adverse drug effects. Pharmacogenomics (PG), study of genetic factors impacting drug response, has improved antidepressant selection, however, 80% of people continue to experience depression following PG-guided treatment. We aim to conduct and integrate other genetic factors with PG, to improve prediction and precision treatment of TRD from the outset.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Kathy Wu, Professor Bernhard Baune, Professor Paul Fitzgerald, Associate Professor Janice Fullerton, Professor Stuart Grieve, Professor Anthony Harris, Professor Sean Hood, Associate Professor Alessandra Minelli, Associate Professor Kristen Nowak, Professor Anthony Rodgers, Professor Deborah Schofield, Associate Professor Rupendra Shrestha, Associate Professor Fatemeh Vafaee

Project Name: Polygenic Risk-Stratified Population-wide Screening for Type 1 Diabetes in Children
Project Summary: Every day, four Australian children are diagnosed with type 1 diabetes (T1D), a serious autoimmune condition, and often only after developing life-threatening complications. However, Polygenic Risk Scores (PRS) could identify 80% of future cases early, before symptoms appear. This Research will explore if and how PRS can be used to detect T1D in Australian children, including the feasibility, acceptability and health system impact. The goal is to help shape a future national screening program.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Kirstine Bell, Professor Jennifer Couper, Professor Maria Craig, Doctor Gladys Ho, Professor Kirsten Howard, Doctor Konrad Kangru, Associate Professor Sebastian Lunke, Associate Professor Deanne Minniecon, Professor Ainsley Newson, Doctor Ashley Ng, Associate Professor Sarah Norris, Associate Professor Kristen Nowak, Associate Professor Richard Oram, Professor Jane Speight, Doctor Angela Titmuss
