Project Name: ROSELLA: Implementation of polygenic risk assessment in general practice for Australia’s most common cancers
Project Summary: Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) are DNA tests that can identify individuals at high risk of Australia’s most common cancers (melanoma, breast, prostate and bowel). The ROSELLA trial aims to test how best we can deliver a PRS multi-cancer risk assessment to all Australians via general practice. If we can make risk assessment available to everyone equitably, we can ensure those most at risk of cancer receive the most appropriate cancer screening for their risk, reducing the burden of cancer for all.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Sibel Saya, Doctor Elizabeth Bancroft, Associate Professor Michael Caruana, Associate Professor Patty (Panagiota) Chondros, Doctor Jane Crowe, Ms Nikki Davis, Professor Jon Emery, Doctor George Fishman, Professor Mark Jenkins, Doctor Karen Mathew, Associate Professor Amy Nisselle, Associate Professor Nicole Rankin, Doctor Amelia Smit, Associate Professor Julia Steinberg, Professor Ingrid Winship

Organisation: The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: EPIGRAM: ExPlorInG the Role of GeneticAlly Predicted Metabolites in Epilepsy Risk and Severity
Project Summary: Epilepsy is a common, complex neurological disease with both genetic and environmental risk factors. This project will explore whether certain metabolites are associated with epilepsy risk using genetic profiling. Our expectation is that some metabolic groups will be more important than others (e.g., lipids) and that this importance may be limited to or driven by certain epilepsy types. Patients can then be targeted for clinical interventions such as the addition of supplements to their diet.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Melanie Bahlo, Professor Samuel Berkovic, Professor Maria Fuller, Doctor Zachary Gerring, Doctor Karen Oliver, Professor Piero Perucca, Professor Ingrid Scheffer, Professor Sanjay Sisodiya

Project Name: Testing the feasibility of PERSONA: a personalised breast and ovarian cancer risk assessment incorporating polygenic information that identifies high-risk women
Project Summary: Women can prevent breast and ovarian cancer if they know their personal risk and use risk-directed early detection and prevention strategies. This feasibility study will pilot an intervention involving a shared model of care between general practitioners and genetic counsellors to deliver a multifactorial breast and ovarian cancer risk assessment including polygenic information to young women. We will examine the intervention feasibility for deliverers, recipients, and the healthcare system.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Laura Forrest, Associate Professor Stephanie Archer, Professor Paul James, Doctor Jocelyn Lippey, Ms Sarah Powell, Ms Rebecca Purvis, Doctor Michelle Tew, Doctor Bryony Thompson

Organisation: The Council of the Queensland Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: Q-Inform - does knowledge of genetic risk for skin cancer change behaviour?
Project Summary: Despite the benefits of detecting cutaneous melanoma before it becomes metastatic, population-wide skin screening is not recommended as there is no evidence that it saves lives and can also lead to overdiagnosis of indolent lesions. We will undertake a randomised controlled trial to test if risk stratification based on a person’s genetic risk for melanoma improves adherence to recommended guidelines for skin screening while reducing unnecessary interventions and harms.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Matthew Law, Professor Anne Cust, Miss Lee Jones, Associate Professor Aideen McInerney-Leo, Professor Rachel Neale, Associate Professor Catherine Olsen, Doctor Huanwei Wang, Professor David Whiteman
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

Project Name: Biological impacts of a polygenic risk score on the normal breast
Project Summary: Mutations in BRCA1 mean that normal breast cells are less equipped to repairs themselves, driving breast cancer development. This has directed the way we screen and manage BRCA1 mutation carriers. In addition to rare mutations like BRCA1, small variations in 300 other genomic areas (polygenic risk score- PRS) can also elevate our breast cancer risk. We will determine how PRS is impacting the breast function to guide clinical management and the development of personalized preventatives.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Kara Britt, Professor Ian Campbell, Professor Phillip Darcy, Damien Grinsell, Professor Paul James, Professor Geoffrey Lindeman, Professor Alicia Oshlack, Professor Melissa Southey

Project Name: CRISP Alliance: Enhancing Polygenic Risk Scores with Proteomics for Colorectal Cancer Surveillance and Prediction
Project Summary: Our goal is develop new genetic tests that can help reduce the number of people getting and dying from colorectal cancer.  Our hope is that these new tests will be able to be used by doctors to decide how to treat and monitor their colorectal cancer patients, and increase participation in colorectal cancer screening for older Australians, and can identify which younger Australians (who are currently too young for screening) are at high risk and could be offered screening.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Mark Jenkins, Associate Professor Daniel Buchanan, Professor Karen Canfell, Doctor Natalie Diepenhorst, Doctor James Dowty, Professor Jon Emery, Professor Marc Gunter, Doctor Jie-Bin Lew, Associate Professor Robert MacInnis, Professor Finlay Macrae, Ms Julie McDonald, Doctor Sibel Saya, Associate Professor Aung Ko Win, Professor Ingrid Winship

Project Name: Developing an Australian-specific finished pangenome reference for prostate cancer polygenic risk score association analysis
Project Summary: Prostate cancer is the most common cancer impacting Australian men. Yet, distinguishing which men will receive a diagnosis remains a challenge. The key – our genetics. Using a multi-ethnic model and advanced pangenomic technologies, we will develop a new risk-prediction approach that interrogates for all variance across the human genome. The goal - a truly complete polygenic risk score to be used by clinicians to predict for prostate cancer risk and adversity, irrespective of patient ancestry.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Vanessa Hayes, Professor Rosalind Eeles, Doctor Weerachai Jaratlerdsiri, Doctor Pamela Soh, Professor David Thomas, Professor David Wedge

Project Name: EYE-GEN (Enhancing Access for Youth with Eye Disease to GENomic Services)
Project Summary: Genomic testing has a critical role in treating rare inherited eye diseases (childhood glaucoma, congenital cataracts, and retinoblastoma). Yet, there is a gap in accessing genetics services identified by consumers. This project will explore barriers to accessing services through interviewing families and healthcare professionals, and subsequent workshops with key stakeholders will develop and trial solutions. Outcomes will be evidence-based recommendations trialled for effective implementation.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Emmanuelle Souzeau, Professor Christopher Barnett, Associate Professor Sarah Cohen-Woods, Professor Jamie Craig, Professor Gillian Harvey, Professor David Mackey, Doctor Jonathan Ruddle, Doctor Sandra Staffieri, Doctor Deepa Taranath, Doctor Lachlan Wheelhouse Knight

Project Name: Implementation of state-based cascade testing centres for autosomal dominant conditions using familial hypercholesterolaemia as the exemplar
Project Summary: Familial hypercholesterolaemia is a genetic condition that leads to extremely elevated cholesterol. It affects more than 100,000 Australians; yet more than 90% of people with this condition are unaware. People usually remain unaware of this genetic condition until they or a family member experience a heart attack. Our Research will enable family members of people with this condition to undergo genetic testing and manage their condition before it is too late.

Project Name: Improving Access and Community Trust in Perinatal Genomics for Culturally and Linguistically Diverse Populations: The ImpACT-PG project
Project Summary: The growing availability of genomic testing provides prospective parents with valuable insights into their future child's health. However, the benefits of such testing are unevenly distributed, as people from culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) backgrounds face many barriers to accessing genomic healthcare. The goal of this project is to build community trust and improve access to perinatal genomics for CALD communities through consumer-centred research.

Project Name: Accelerating universal access to genomics by enabling Australia’s Largest healthcare workforce: a cancer nursing led co-designed pilot of The Nursing Compendium for Genomic-Informed Care (NGenCare)
Project Summary: Genomics promises better healthcare, but access is challenging. This project empowers nurses to facilitate access to genomics, using a practical compendium of resources co-created with nurses and consumers. We'll test this approach in cancer care, an area with many different testing needs, to help us refine and adapt the approach for other areas of health in the future. This could mean earlier diagnoses, more tailored treatments, and fairer access to the benefits of genomics.

Project Name: Diagnosis4All: Co-designing Equitable and Sustainable Solutions to Reduce the Diagnostic Odyssey
Project Summary: Access to a genetic diagnosis and linked precise and supportive care is inequitable for people living in communities in regional and remote Australia, who are from culturally and linguistically diverse communities and who are Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander. Our program is co-led by researchers from these priority communities and will explore how to overcome this inequity and test out a health solution, designed together with the communities, clinicians, health services and researchers.

Project Name: Enabling inclusive population-scale genomics through culturally appropriate participant information, innovation in language translation, and workforce development
Project Summary: To ensure genomic medicine can help everyone, we need data that fully represents our population. This project will make it easier for Australians from different cultures and diverse backgrounds to be part of genomics research. We will create and translate participant information, exploring new automated translation tools, and train researchers and bicultural workers to work with diverse communities to include them in genomics research. This will contribute to better health for all Australians.

Project Name: Preventing intra-uterine infection and neonatal sepsis treatment failure in CALD communities: Precision antibiotic therapy through pathogen genomics
Project Summary: During pregnancy, healthy microbes in the birth canal can protect against infections, but others can cause serious infections. Migrants from certain regions are more likely to carry drug-resistant microbes, and these harmful microbes can cause infection inside the womb putting lives of both mother and baby in danger. Our Research uses new technology to identify both beneficial and harmful microbes and their drug resistance from vaginal swabs. These tests will help us choose the right treatments.

Project Name: The South Asian Genes and Health in Australia Study
Project Summary: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the biggest cause of death in Australia. South Asians have a higher CVD risk than individuals with European ancestry, but are under-represented in health and genomic Research that informs the development of Australian tools and guidelines for assessing CVD risk. This leads to inequity in access to appropriate healthcare. By addressing this data bias, this project will help develop more equitable strategies for preventing CVD in a diverse Australian population.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Sonia Shah, Doctor Heena Akbar, Professor John Atherton, Professor Kim Greaves, Ms Anjali Henders, Professor Julie McGaughran, Doctor Mehwish Nisar, Doctor Andrew Webster, Doctor Tatiane Yanes, Professor Loic Yengo

Project Name: A GIFT (Genomics for Infection Prevention and Therapy) to the Neighbourhood:  Metagenomics enabled tracking, treatment and prevention of priority infections in culturally diverse communities
Project Summary: Cutting-edge genomics will be applied to prevent infectious diseases in culturally and linguistically diverse communities in Western Sydney, with a focus on the Pasifika diaspora. Experts in genomics and multicultural healthcare will work together to deliver a novel disease prevention and early treatment program. School-age children and their parents will participate in the study and test the ability of genomics to identify sources of infection and improve community health.

Project Name: Connect-TBI: A National Informatics and Data-Driven Approach to Improve Care for Moderate to Severe TBI
Project Summary: CONNECT-TBI will establish a national data asset to support the care and outcomes or people who experience moderate to severe traumatic brain injury (TBI).  Using an interdisciplinary and evidence-informed approach, CONNECT-TBI will gather data about all important aspects of a person’s traumatic brain injury (TBI), their treatment and care. The CONNECT-TBI data asset will be used to improve understanding of care and outcome pathways, and facilitate clinical trials and research.

Project Name: i-RECOveR:  Evaluating in-person and telehealth delivery of an interdisciplinary treatment for persistent post-concussional symptoms after mild traumatic brain injury
Project Summary: Many people with mild traumatic brain injury have persistent symptoms. We  will evaluate a co-ordinated care model delivering psychological, physiotherapy and medical treatment for persistent post-concussional symptoms in adults of all ages, comparing outcomes of delivery in-person and via telehealth to facilitate treatment access for rural and remote communities. We will assess treatment delivery processes, costs and participant experience and evaluate a public hospital clinic.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Jennie Ponsford, Ms Stephanie Antonopoulos, Associate Professor Geoff Argus, Mr Ryan Baxter, Associate Professor Natasha Brusco, Ms Katie Davies, Doctor Emily Gibson, Doctor Michael Makdissi, Associate Professor Adam McKay, Doctor Dean McKenzie, Professor Biswadev Mitra, Doctor Jack Nguyen, Professor Trevor Russell, Ms Isabella Sandstrom, Associate Professor Catherine Willmott

Project Name: Psilocybin-ASsisted Therapy for Persisting Post-Concussion Symptoms (PAST-PPCS)
Project Summary: Many people who sustain a concussion go on to experience debilitating persisting postconcussion symptoms (PPCS) for months to years after the injury. Effective interventions for PPCS are lacking; however, treatment with psilocybin (i.e., magic mushrooms) in other settings effectively alleviates a range of symptoms relevant to PPCS (e.g., headaches, cognitive impairment, depression, anxiety). Here we will conduct the first clinical trial investigating the efficacy of psilocybin therapy for PPCS.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Terence O'Brien, Professor Joshua Byrnes, Professor Karen Caeyenberghs, Doctor Zhibin Chen, Doctor Georgia Fuller Symons, Doctor Paul Liknaitzky, Doctor Jennifer Makovec Knight, Professor Sandy Shultz, Professor Suresh Sundram

Project Name: Mind the Gap: Partnering with consumers to implement person-centred concussion management
Project Summary: Evidence-based practice can improve outcomes after a concussion, but 50% of people don’t get the care they need. The first Australian Concussion Clinical Practice Guidelines can improve patient outcomes but requires effective targeted implementation strategies. With consumers, we will bridge this gap in care by codesigning a patient-driven model of concussion care that integrates existing services through a novel Concussion Conversation Tool and an Australian Concussion Health Pathway.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Karen Barlow, Professor Vicki Anderson, Professor Franz Babl, Ms Megan Butner, Mr David Cole, Tim Cudmore, Professor Gavin Davis, Vinay Gangathimmaiah, Doctor Emily Gibson, Associate Professor Benjamin Matthews, Associate Professor Rhonda Orr, Professor Jennie Ponsford, Doctor Mark Ralfe, Associate Professor Emma Tavender, Associate Professor Julia Treleaven

Project Name: Enhancing Community Engagement in TBI Rehabilitation Through the Social Brain Toolkit: A Framework for Implementation and Impact
Project Summary: The Social Brain Toolkit offers online programs to improve communication skills for people with moderate to severe traumatic brain injury (TBI). A Virtual Clinic will be set up, which will include program delivery by student health professionals and mentoring by people with TBI. The project will compare the Virtual Clinic to usual care to see which is more effective. The aim is to create a sustainable model for TBI rehabilitation and strengthen the future health workforce.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Rachael Rietdijk, Ms Petra Avramovic, Professor Kirrie Ballard, Nicholas Behn, Doctor Elise Bogart, Doctor Sophie Brassel, Doctor Melissa Brunner, Mrs Naomi Fuller, Doctor Suzy Goldsmith, Professor Jerry Hoepner, Ms Victoria Kennedy, Doctor Renee Lim, Associate Professor Nikki McCaffrey

Project Name: Codesigning an integrated model of care for early management of individuals with moderate-to-severe traumatic brain injury who have pre-existing mental health difficulties
Project Summary: Individuals with moderate-to-severe traumatic brain injury with pre-existing mental health difficulties such as depression and substance use are at greater risk of poor outcomes. Their management requires a well-coordinated and personalised mix of brain injury, mental health and drug and alcohol services. A best-practice model of care to support these individuals is currently unavailable. Our project aims to develop this model to facilitate more tailored and effective care and improve outcomes.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Cynthia Honan, Doctor Holly Emery, Associate Professor Jennifer Evans, Professor Belinda Gabbe, Professor Timothy Geraghty, Associate Professor Matthew Gullo, Professor Malcolm Hopwood, Professor Natasha Lannin, Professor Skye McDonald, Doctor Jessie Mitchell, Professor Tamara Ownsworth, Associate Professor Grahame Simpson, Associate Professor Dana Wong

Project Name: Concussion Essentials: A seamless, evidence-based intervantion model for personalised management of concussion: from injury to recovery
Project Summary: Child and youth concussion is a major community concern.  We have recently completed multiple linked Research studies that confirm our methods and interventions can i) assist families to safely manage their child's early recovery, accelerate return to normal activities. This application aims to now implement our work into clinical and community contexts, nationally, to minimise the long-term impacts of concussion.

Project Name: Hope in Healing: Developing a Model of Care Approach for those Impacted by Traumatic Brain Injury through Domestic Family Violence
Project Summary: This project will develop and test a supportive model of care for those who are impacted by a mild traumatic brain injury from domestic violence. This will be undertake through: (1) an expert consensus of what constitutes best practice care for this group; (2) co-designing a local model of care based on the expert consensus; and (3) testing the model of care with frontline domestic violence services. This work has the potential to alleviate the significant burden experienced by victim-survivors.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Breanne Hobden, Professor Mariko Carey, Doctor Jemma Keeves, Professor Deborah Loxton, Doctor Christopher Oldmeadow, Ms Sue Pollock, Mrs Shannon Richardson, Doctor Zoi Triandafilidis, Doctor Anousha Victoire

Project Name:
CUREator: Translating Research
into Health Outcomes
Project Summary: Utilising CUREator’s established and proven processes, in partnership with CSIRO, CUREator will identify and select 10-15 promising Australian biotechnology companies developing novel therapeutics for funding support. New and established SMEs will access competitive funding coupled with expert scientific and commercial guidance, international networks, hands-on support and mentorship to guide them through the critical development phases to the point of investment- or partnership-readiness. By aligning funding incentives and milestone-driven progress, CUREator will provide an important bridge to overcome the stop-start nature of translational Research and assist SMEs to secure follow-on funding and nurture the next generation of innovators.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Chris Nave, Doctor Amanda Vrselja, Doctor Michael Bettess, Professor Susan Nilsson, Doctor Charlotte Williams, Doctor Patricia Rueda, Doctor Aaron Debono, Doctor Christina Kulis, Doctor Mark York, Doctor Patrick James, Doctor Bob Soh, Doctor Jess Gledhill, Doctor Judith Scoble, Doctor Helga Mikkelsen, Doctor Melissa McBurnie

Grant Opportunity: 2022 Frontier Health and Medical Research (Batch Two)
Project Name:
Delivering precision medicine for lung cancer
using plasma genomics ASPi-2L
Project Summary: ASPiRATION-2 Liquid will evaluate a novel approach to personalised therapy for advanced lung cancer using circulating tumour DNA (ctDNA) testing through a patient’s journey to guide treatment. Plasma ctDNA analysis will be used to tailor treatment to the patient’s unique molecular profile, eliminating the need for invasive tissue biopsy. The first 5 years of the project will focus on patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) whose disease has progressed after first-line targeted therapy.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Benjamin Solomon, Professor Nick Pavlakis, Associate Professor Chee Khoon Lee, Associate Professor Thomas John, Professor Sarah-Jane Dawson, Professor Sean Michael Grimmond, Professor Stephen B Fox, Professor David Morgan Thomas, Mrs Lisa Ann Briggs, Professor Wendy Anne Cooper, Associate Professor Kate DeVere Sutherland, Professor Rachael Morton, Associate Professor Venessa Chin, Doctor Rebecca Yin Tay, Professor Michael John Millward
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: Advancing Brain-Penetrant PKC Inhibitors to Combat High-Grade Glioma
Project Summary: High-grade gliomas (HGG) affect >2,000 Australians annually and are the leading cause of death among young people. Most cases remain untreatable, with survival rates <15 months post-diagnosis. We demonstrated that combining the PKC inhibitor enzastaurin with the PI3K inhibitor paxalisib and radiation increased survival by 156% in HGG mouse models. Building on this, we developed JLD14, a novel PKC inhibitor with superior brain penetrance, potency, and selectivity. In this project, we will advance JLD14 through non/preclinical studies while developing additional PKC inhibitors as potential more favourable alternatives. Within 5 years, we aim to launch Phase I clinical trials in Australia, targeting TGA/FDA Phase II approvals within 10 years.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Matt Dun, Professor Jonathan Morris, Professor Michelle Monje, Affiliate Professor Jordan Hansford, Professor Ernst Wolvetang, Professor David Eisenstat, Associate Professor Eng-Siew Koh, Doctor Ryan Duchatel, Doctor Evangeline Jackson, Doctor Iliya Dragutinovic, Doctor Fatima Valdes Mora, Doctor Helen Wheeler, Professor Doan Ngo, Doctor Gerard Kaiko, Doctor Catherine Johnson
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: Designing an Australian National Adaptive Platform Trial for Endometriosis
Project Summary: Endometriosis affects 11% of Australian women causing distressing symptoms such as pain and infertility. Several interventions are used to treat people with endometriosis but unfortunately, we do not know whether they actually work. None of them has been tested in high-quality randomised studies assessing effectiveness and their interactions remain unknown. Overall, the lack of randomised evidence assessing the effectiveness and long-term results of endometriosis treatments is leading to clinical uncertainty, variation in clinical care and treatment outcomes. We plan to design a large adaptive platform trial assessing multiple endometriosis treatments with the ultimate goal of improving outcomes for Australians living with endometriosis.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Akwasi Amoako, Professor Grant Montgomery, Professor Luk Rombauts, Professor Antonina Mikocka-Walus, Associate Professor Mike Armour, Associate Professor Subhadra Evans, Associate Professor Nancy Sturman, Professor Andrew Martin, Professor James McGree, Professor Haitham Tuffaha, Associate Professor Rebecca Olson, Doctor Ding Ma, Doctor Brett McKinnon, Doctor Sally Mortlock, Ms Jessica Taylor

Project Name: Transforming Paediatric Critical Care: PLATINUM Trial Design & Development
Project Summary: The PLATINUM inception project aims to address the critical lack of high-quality evidence in paediatric critical care by developing an adaptive platform trial (APT). Through extensive stakeholder engagement and guidance from international experts in innovative trial design, we will establish the PLATINUM Master Protocol and associated operational documentation. Led by a multidisciplinary team of senior researchers and EMCRs with the support of all ANZ Paediatric Intensive Care Units, we will leverage existing ANZ trial infrastructure and national data pipelines, integrated with consumer preferences, clinician insights, and robust statistical and health economic modelling to develop an APT ready for immediate submission to funding bodies.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Kristen Stacey Gibbons, Professor Warwick Wolf Butt, Professor Fenella Gill, Professor Paul Mouncey, Doctor Anton Pak, Mrs Sumee Narayan, Doctor Sainath Raman, Doctor Patricia Gilholm, Doctor Nathalia Costa, Ms Alyssa Kate Serratore, Doctor Johnny Millar, Doctor Simon Erickson, Doctor Marino Festa, Professor Mark Peters, Doctor Ben Gelbart

Project Name: Innovating and testing solutions to accelerate stroke recovery
Project Summary: Stroke remains a leading cause of disability. Recovery is driven by brain plasticity. Increasing plasticity could accelerate recovery and address intractable problems of persistent disability. This project will establish evidence and capability to demonstrate feasibility of upscaling to a national adaptive platform trial to evaluate therapies that can upregulate plasticity and accelerate stroke recovery. This project consists of two concurrent streams. Stream 1 will pilot our adaptive trial in South Australia, collecting data in a hub-satellite model, ensuring greater trial access across metropolitan and rural stroke hotspots. Stream 2 will develop required infrastructure and resources, and build onshore capacity, for upscaling nationally.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Brenton G Hordacre, Professor Susan L Hillier, Associate Professor Beben Benyamin, Professor Craig Anderson
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: Preventing intrapartum fetal hypoxia: the iSEARCH Pre-Platform Pilot
Project Summary: The iSEARCH Pre-Platform Pilot is urgently needed to show feasibility for a National Adaptive Platform Trial, modelled on the UK RECOVERY Trial, to assess if intrapartum use of (a) sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor, (b) half-dose oxytocin and (c) future treatments prevent intrapartum hypoxia and its sequelae, especially in minority groups at greatest risk. We will initiate (1) relationships with community leaders and focus groups on stakeholder views on potential barriers, enablers and preferred outcome measures in a National Adaptive Platform Trial (2) endorsement from professional groups (3)  a trial website for randomisation and trial management and (4) a protocol with ethics approval for the National Adaptive Platform Trial.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor William Tarnow-Mordi, Professor Sailesh Kumar, Associate Professor Michelle Dickson, Professor Adrienne Gordon, Doctor Himanshu Popat, Doctor Rachel L O'Connell, Professor Tammy Hoffmann, Associate Professor Bradley Stephen de Vries, Associate Professor Anna Lene Seidler, Doctor Kristy Robledo, Doctor Kylie Elizabeth Hunter, Associate Professor Chi Kin Law, Professor David Simmons, Professor Jonathan Anthony Hyett, Professor Waldemar Alberto Carlo
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: PASSPORT: Paediatric Adaptive Sepsis Platform Trial
Project Summary: PASSPORT is an adaptive platform trial that will address high-impact evidence gaps in sepsis care not amenable to traditional randomised controlled trials. PASSPORT will be conducted through the Paediatric Research in Emergency Departments International Collaborative and its established Research network. Consumers and priority groups will inform all aspects of the project.   Partnerships will ensure evidence is translated into  health service delivery through policy reform, maximising return on investment. This approach will accelerate the identification of effective therapies, improve health outcomes for critically ill Australian children with sepsis, and build Australian capacity to conduct adaptive platform trials.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Elliot Long, Professor Franz E Babl, Associate Professor Shane George, Professor Katherine J Lee, Professor Andrew J Davidson, Professor Christopher Charles Blyth, Ms Kate L Rawnsley, Professor Meredith L Borland, Professor Stuart Dalziel, Doctor Sarah McNab, Professor Kim Dalziel, Professor Simon Stuart Craig, Associate Professor Emma Jane Tavender, Associate Professor Adriana Yock-Corrales, Professor Andrew Craig Steer
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: PlatfOrm for Diabetic Ulcer Management (PODIUM)
Project Summary: The PODIUM (PlatfOrm for DIabetic Foot Ulcer Management) initiative is a Platform adaptive trial to test promising therapies in subjects with diabetic foot ulcers. Foot ulcers in diabetes is an area of major unmet need, and scarce investment. Best practice includes antibiotics, restoring blood supply, non-weight-bearing and wound dressings. Despite this, one in five ulcers fail to heal, catastrophically resulting in a limb amputation or fatality. This costs society over $1.6B annually in direct care costs and around 28,000 disability-adjusted life years lost. PODIUM will initially test 2 oral and 2 topical therapies in a rigorous trial to expedite discovery of the most effective treatments to increase healing and reduce adverse outcomes.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Anthony Clifford Keech, Professor Stephen Morris Twigg, Associate Professor Byron Matthew Perrin, Associate Professor Peter Anthony Lazzarini, Doctor Emma Jane Hamilton, Professor Gemma Alexandra Figtree, Professor Jonathan Golledge, Ms Jane Cheney, Associate Professor Paul Wraight, Professor Ian Marschner, Doctor Joel Willem Johan Lasschuit, Doctor Vivienne Chuter, Doctor Pamela YiMing Chen, Professor Robert Alwyn Fitridge, Doctor Eleanor P Thong
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: BEAT-CF MARS- management of acute respiratory symptoms in Cystic Fibrosis
Project Summary: BEAT-CF is an established adaptive trial platform, with the purpose of patient-driven evidence, on, for and by people affected by cystic fibrosis (CF).  BEAT-CF has enrolled nearly a 1000 people with CF from CF centres across Australia. Amidst the transformation in CF management brought by modulator therapies, Research priorities have shifted toward minimising the burden and toxicity of CF-related treatment.  To this end, BEAT-CF MARS will nest a new domain to BEAT-CF’s existing platform to assess the safety of two antibiotic-sparing strategies for managing pulmonary exacerbations. The proposal addresses all of the scheme’s intended outcomes, 7 of MRFF’s 13 nominated Research priorities, and international consumer priorities for CF research
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Thomas Laurence Snelling, Professor Andre Schultz, Doctor Bernadette J Prentice, Doctor Sheila Sivam, Professor Adam Jaffe, Doctor Ameneh Khatami, Doctor Nathan Andrew Ward, Professor Peter Alexander Blanch Wark, Mr Mark Jones, Mr Mitch Messer, Doctor Evelyn Cheng Suan Tay
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: Trial for Reducing Infection After Arthroplasty with Dilute Povidone-Iodine
Project Summary: The Trial for Reducing Infection After Arthroplasty with Dilute povidone-iodine lavage (TRIAD) will examine if dilute intraoperative povidone-iodine lavage is superior in reducing surgical site infection (SSI) in hip and knee arthroplasty compared to saline lavage only. This study aims to generate robust, low-bias randomised clinical trial evidence that will significantly impact infection prevention clinical practices and healthcare policies in arthroplasty surgery.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Paul Smith, Professor Christopher John Vertullo, Associate Professor Christopher James Wall, Doctor Andrew Fraval, Adjunct Professor Michael Jeremy McAuliffe, Professor Ian Harris, Professor Richard Noel de Steiger, Doctor Janney L Wale, Doctor Catherine Jane McDougall, Ms Alicia Ann Norman, Conjoint Associate Professor David Craig Dewar, Ms Durga Bastiras, Doctor Sophia Corfield, Ms Michelle Lorimer
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: A Registry-based Randomised Trial of Radiotherapy in Advanced Lung Cancer
Project Summary: Metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is a leading cause of cancer-related death and the prognosis for patients with metastatic NSCLC remains poor. Primary Radiotherapy In MEtastatic Lung cancer (PRIME-Lung) is a registry-based randomised controlled trial for 420 patients with metastatic NSCLC. It is designed as a pivotal phase III trial that will test whether eradication of the primary tumour through non-invasive radiotherapy will limit metastatic spread,  improve survival and quality of life in this critical area of unmet need. PRIME-Lung will use the highly successful national AURORA lung cancer registry with >5000 patients already enrolled, enabling cost-efficient phase III trial delivery and maximising external validity.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Shankar Siva, Professor Benjamin Solomon, Professor Paul John Keall, Doctor Marliese Alexander, Professor Kenneth John O'Byrne, Associate Professor Thomas John, Professor David Anthony Palma, Professor Jarushka Naidoo, Professor Richard De Abreu Lourenco, Mr Chris Brown, Doctor Rebecca Mercieca-Bebber, Associate Professor Nicholas Hardcastle, Doctor Tracy Leong, Mrs Sue McCullough
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Organisation: The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: SMART: Streamlining GlioblastoMA Radiation Therapy
Project Summary: The Streamlining GlioblastoMA Radiation Therapy (SMART) trial is a nationwide registry-based Phase 3 randomised controlled trial embedded into the Brain Registry Australia: Innovation & TraNslation (BRAIN) that will address the unsatisfactorily high treatment burden for people affected by glioblastoma (GBM) – an aggressive brain cancer impacting all domains of life with a prognosis of less than 18 months. SMART will test if a shorter 4-week daily radiation therapy course, at a slightly higher dose per session, will result in non-inferior survival compared to the standard 6-week daily course, but improve the quality of life for patients and carers during a critical juncture in their lives, as well as benefit healthcare resourcing long-term.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Joseph Sia, Doctor Lucy Gately, Doctor James Whittle, Associate Professor Eng-Siew Koh, Associate Professor Georgia Halkett, Associate Professor Haryana Dhillon, Associate Professor Mark Pinkham, Doctor Elena Meshcheriakova, Doctor Saskia Freytag, Professor Peter Gibbs, Associate Professor Andrew Morokoff, Professor Martin Ebert, Associate Professor Arian Lasocki
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: Cost effectiveness of adaptive platform trials versus conventional trials
Project Summary: Clinical trials have exploded worldwide to produce significant health benefits, but with high costs. Adaptive Platform Trials (APTs) offer a promising alternative, but their efficiency and cost effectiveness is unknown. We are a multidisciplinary team of health economists, statisticians, trialists and patients working to assess the efficiency and cost effectiveness of APTs versus conventional trials. Guided by End User and Patient Advisory Groups, we will conduct surveys, focus groups, Discrete Choice Experiments and modelling to quantify efficiency factors using our team’s existing APTs. We’ll extend our published trial efficiency model to produce an innovative ‘APT-Cost Effectiveness Simulation Tool’ designed and translated for end users.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Kim Dalziel, Professor Katherine J Lee, Professor Philip Clarke, Professor Brett J Manley, Doctor Clare Whitehead, Associate Professor Chris Schilling, Professor Andrew Davidson, Professor Claire Wainwright, Doctor Li Huang, Ms Melinda Cruz, Mr Cade Shadbolt, Doctor Michelle Tew, Associate Professor Elliot Long, Doctor Middleton Melissa, Doctor Peto Leon
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: Expanding the BEAT-Calci Platform: Multi-Modal Treatments for Calciphylaxis
Project Summary: The Better Evidence And Translation for Calciphylaxis (BEAT-Calci) trial is an Australian, international, adaptive platform trial focused on kidney disease research, specifically targeting calciphylaxis—a rare, devastating condition with painful ulcers and high mortality. This landmark platform was designed with accommodation of multi-domains to minimise barriers to participation in rare disease and shorten time to evidence generation. We will assess the effectiveness of the medium cut-off (MCO) dialyser vs conventional high flux dialyser in treating calciphylaxis. With industry support, a piloted intervention, and coordination with study sites, we seek funding to establish this domain with global leadership and recruitment in Australia.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Rathika Krishnasamy, Professor Meg Jardine, Doctor Nicole Jane Scholes-Robertson, Professor Smeeta Sinha, Professor Nigel Toussaint, Associate Professor Michelle Barakat-Johnson, Professor Neil Christopher Boudville, Doctor Michael Gerard Collins, Doctor Brendan Smyth, Professor Grahame Elder, Doctor Elizabeth Lorenzi, Associate Professor Janak de Zoyssa, Doctor David Collister
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: Australasian Traumatic Brain Injury Collaboration
Project Summary: Despite resulting in costs of $2 Billion per year, and having an enormous health, social, and domestic impact, The Lancet Neurology Commission on traumatic brain injury (TBI) identified Australia and New Zealand as having “no reliable data” concerning this devastating disease. The Australasian Traumatic Brain Injury Collaboration (ATBIC) will address this major knowledge and healthcare gap. More specifically, ATBIC will leverage the existing partnerships and data collection infrastructure of pre-hospital healthcare services and clinical quality registries (AROC, ANZICS CORE, ANZTR, Monash University), to establish a national dataset, that will offer insights into each phase of care provided to moderate-to-severe TBI (msTBI) patients.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Andrew Udy, Doctor Luise Patricia Lago, Doctor Toby Jeffcote, Professor Edward Litton, Professor Fary Khan, Professor Mark Fitzgerald, Doctor Andrea Christine Clarke, Doctor Paul J Secombe, Doctor Lisa Margaret Higgins, Doctor Camila R Battistuzzo, Doctor Anais Charles-Nelson, Professor Rosalind L Jeffree, Professor Jamie Cooper, Doctor Daniel Bodnar, Doctor Bruce Patrick Powell.
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: A “Learning Health System” for Eating Disorder Treatment in Australia
Project Summary: Eating disorders (EDs) are complex and outcomes are poor. Yet due to a lack of routine clinical monitoring, we lack data that would otherwise support improvement and evaluation of policy and practice initiatives. We will deliver a project that will transform ED healthcare into a "learning health system". We will do this by co-designing with key stakeholders an innovative digital clinical quality registry that feeds back information on outcomes to clients, clinicians and government. We will then demonstrate the value of the registry to address unmet needs by using registry data to evaluate the ED Medicare scheme and build prediction models that will underpin a personalised approach to ED care, thereby innovating both policy and practice.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Deborah Mitchison, Associate Professor Gabriella Heruc, Doctor Katie Page, Professor Matthew Fuller-Tyszkiewicz, Professor Phillipa Jane Hay, Associate Professor Valerie Carole Jeanne Gay, Associate Professor Kris Rogers, Ms Kyra Bennett, Ms Niamh Kaitlin Taggart, Doctor Sian Alexandra McLean, Professor Tracey Wade, Associate Professor Sloane Madden, Associate Professor Susan Mary Byrne, Doctor Marion E Roberts, Mr Herve Harvard.
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: The Australian Perinatal Data Linkage Platform
Project Summary:
We are transforming decision-making during pregnancy. We will create Australia’s first national perinatal data infrastructure; linking national birth data with maternal prescribing records and health outcomes for mothers & children. Our initiative aims to provide critical evidence on the safety of prescribed medications during pregnancy, revealing their effects.
Central to this effort is the SAFE Pregnancy platform—a user-friendly online tool co-designed with consumers. It will provide easy access to new evidence, supporting informed decision-making between pregnant women and their care teams. This infrastructure will continuously integrate new data and enhance the platform, promoting safer pregnancies and healthier families.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Roxanne Hastie, Doctor Anthea Clare Lindquist, Professor Stephen Tong, Professor Partick Luke Olivier, Professor Lyle Cordell Gurrin, Doctor Alexandra Louise Waddell, Mrs Lisa Nucifora, Professor Susan Walker, Professor Brett James Manley, Professor Della Anne Forster.
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Not available

Project Name: The CURE Asthma data integration Research engine (CURE-ADIRE).
Project Summary: Australia has one of the highest asthma rates globally, significantly affecting children and First Nations People.  A cure remains elusive but is within grasp. Advances in biological profiling and data analysis offer new drug discovery opportunities, but progress has stalled due to a lack of data integration across studies. This prevents healthcare improvement and effective evaluation of new treatments.  The CURE Asthma Data Integration Research Engine (CURE-ADIRE) proposal, led by CI Dharmage, is  a flagship project of the CURE Asthma Initiative led by CI Anderson and aims to remove this barrier. It will unify Australian asthma cohorts in a national system, enhancing Research to discover and clinically test effective treatments and cures.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Shyamali Dharmage, Professor Gary Peter Anderson, Associate Professor Caroline Jane Lodge, Associate Professor Michael Patrick Menden, Associate Professor Adrian Charles Bickerstaffe, Doctor Danielle Fortunee Wurzel, Doctor Noel Garry Faux, Mr Anthony William Flynn, Mrs Judith Helen Wettenhall, Clinical Professor Alan Lloyd James, Associate Professor Rachel Louise Peters, Professor Peter le Souef, Professor Adnan Custovic, Professor Peter Sly, Clinical Professor Stephen Michael Stick.

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Investigating the Impact of Increased Alcohol Access from Policy Change on Alcohol-Related Harm in Central Australia
Project Summary: Our team will use a range of methods to investigate the impacts of the removal of alcohol availability measures in Central Australia. This collaboration with the Central Australian Aboriginal Congress builds on our 5-year project evaluating alcohol policies in the Northern Territory. The findings will inform policy makers and community with independent and timely information on the impacts of alcohol policy on alcohol consumption and harms for in Aboriginal peoples and in the general population.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Peter Miller, Associate Professor Jaithri Ananthapavan, Doctor Abdolvahab Baghbanian, Associate Professor John Boffa, Doctor Linda Cobiac, Doctor Kerri Coomber, Associate Professor Clare Farmer, Doctor Richard Johnson, Doctor Sally Kennedy, Doctor Phuong Nguyen, Professor Yin Paradies, Ms Emma Stubbs, Doctor Nicholas Taylor, Professor Lennert Veerman, Ms Yasmin Watts

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: The IMPACT (Identifying Mental and Physical Alcohol access-related Consequences in Teens) Study: Reducing harm for Australia’s young people
Project Summary: Our study will follow 1,000 Australians as they transition from age 15 to 18 to identify how the modern experience of alcohol availability, acceptability and attractiveness (e.g., social media marketing, online sale and delivery) impacts on young people and their health. Partnering with young people, governments and other services, we will provide evidence to shape alcohol policy and programs that are responsive to young people’s needs and effective in improving health and wellbeing.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Amy Peacock, Professor Kathryn Backholer, Associate Professor Raimondo Bruno, Doctor Philip Clare, Professor Emmanuel Kuntsche, Associate Professor Michael Livingston, Doctor Florentine Martino, Ms Mia Miller, Professor Paula O'Brien, Doctor Cassandra Wright
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Understanding and disrupting alcohol availability as a pathway to addressing mental ill-health, injury and harm with adolescents and young adults
Project Summary: The last 10 years has seen a rapid increase in where alcohol can be consumed and purchased, especially online. Similarly, there has been a rapid escalation mental and physical ill-health amongst adolescents and young adults.  This project sets out to examine how these changes are linked to increasing levels of alcohol availability in the community, and the impact on health services and sectors. It does this through a 21 year retrospective study and  a new prospective study.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Bosco Rowland, Doctor Julie Abimanyi-Ochom, Doctor Jacqueline Allen, Doctor Jennifer Bailey, Doctor Ryan Baldwin, Miss Leonardo Butterworth Banzhaf, Doctor Elizabeth Clancy, Miss Elle Handley, Associate Professor Adrian Kelly, Doctor Bianca Klettke, Professor Daniel Lubman, Doctor Rowan Ogeil, Ms Rachel Smith, Professor John Toumbourou, Doctor Ting Xia

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Youth Alcohol Use in the Digital Age: Harnessing longitudinal cohort data and living systematic reviews to inform prevention and harm minimisation.
Project Summary: The proliferation of digital technology and social media have seen concerning increases in access to alcohol among young people. We will (1) survey youth as part of a 16-year longitudinal study, and (2) systematically review the existing evidence, to identify the impacts of increased alcohol access on youth physical and mental health. In collaboration with partners and consumers, results will inform prevention and harm minimisation approaches to reduce the burden of alcohol on young Australians.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Delyse Hutchinson, Professor Steve Allsop, Professor Elizabeth Elliott, Doctor Christopher Greenwood, Doctor Alys Havard, Associate Professor Jacqui Macdonald, Professor Richard Mattick, Emeritus Professor Jackob Najman, Professor Craig Olsson, Doctor Katrina Prior, Doctor Natasha Reid, Professor Debra Rickwood, Professor Timothy Slade, Doctor Elizabeth Spry, Doctor Samantha Teague

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Identifying, evaluating and responding to the risk and impact of polysubstance use and new psychoactive substances among young Australians - codesigning for health
Project Summary: Young people are often unaware what combinations of drugs they are taking, and drugs such as ecstasy or cocaine can contain deadly substances such as powerful synthetic opioids. Our team of consumers, medical experts and researchers will access young people at high drug use events and combine state-of-the-art social Research and drug identification technology to understand what they are actually taking, the  risks and impacts, and codesign effective responses to prevent and manage health harms.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Simon Lenton, Associate Professor Raimondo Bruno, Sione Crawford, Mr Paul Dessauer, Mx Baillee Farah, Ms Erica Franklin, Professor Paul Griffiths, Doctor Jodie Grigg, Doctor Penelope Hill, Professor Malcolm McLeod, Associate Professor Anna Olsen, Associate Professor Jennifer Schumann, Doctor Jessamine Soderstrom, Ms Stephanie Tzanetis

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: The co-design and uptake of a community-driven approach to alcohol treatment for First Nations people and communities: Clean Slate Indigenous
Project Summary: First Nations Australians living in remote, regional and rural Australia have almost no access to clinical specialist treatment for alcohol dependence. A telehealth-based model for delivering specialist alcohol treatment, Clean Slate, would address this treatment gap. Given evidence that telehealth increases access to treatment for First Nations Australians, is acceptable to them and improves their health, this project will support a First Nations led adaptation and evaluation of Clean Slate.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Anthony Shakeshaft, Professor Roxanne Bainbridge, Doctor Anton Clifford-Motopi, Doctor Sara Farnbach, Doctor Victor Oguoma, Doctor Richard Violette, Salifu Yusif
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Co-designing and evaluating a tailored program for substance use disorder in young people with acquired brain injury
Project Summary: Brain injury is the most common cause of hospitalisation in young people. Up to 66% have a substance use disorder that endures post-injury, making return to work harder and increasing the risk of rehospitalisation. Effective substance use disorder interventions exist, but need modification for those with brain injury. This multistate project bridges the gap by co-designing a tailored interprofessional program for young people and evaluating its cost-effective implementation in existing services.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Matthew Gullo, Professor Joshua Byrnes, Professor Sharon Dawe, Professor Jennifer Fleming, Doctor Kate Gould, Doctor Hannah Gullo, Assistant Professor Carolyn Lemsky, Doctor Jessie Mitchell, Professor Tamara Ownsworth, Professor Jennie Ponsford, Professor Trevor Russell, Doctor Knut Schneider, Associate Professor Grahame Simpson, Doctor Ben Turner, Associate Professor Dana Wong

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Substance Use Support in Transition from Prison for Women (SUSTain)
Project Summary: Substance Use Support in Transition from Prison for Women (SUSTain) will improve health by closing a critical health systems gap in the provision of alcohol and other drug care for women released from prison in Victoria. Women with lived experience, alongside health providers and policymakers, will codesign, implement and evaluate a patient-centred transitional care model (TCM) for the treatment of substance dependence for women released from prison.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Rebecca Winter, Doctor Jocelyn Chan, Doctor Jon Cook, Doctor Michael Curtis, Professor Paul Dietze, Ms Karen Fletcher, Ms Daisy Gibbs, Ms Nikita Lotus, Doctor Thileepan Naren, Associate Professor Eugenia Pedagogos, Doctor Ashleigh Stewart, Professor Mark Stoove, Ms Katharina Storey, Doctor Shelley Walker, Mr Dallas Widdicombe

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: A Phase II study of medicinal cannabis products in the treatment of chronic pain in patients with opioid dependence
Project Summary:
Medicinal cannabis is widely used in Australia for chronic pain, despite the limited evidence for its safety and efficacy. No clinical trials have examined medicinal cannabis in people with both chronic pain and opioid dependence.
We will examine the impact of oral doses of THC, cannabidiol (CBD) and combination THC-CBD upon the outcomes of pain, mood, cravings, safety and consumer experience in people with both chronic back pain and opioid dependence, providing evidence to inform future trials.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Nicholas Lintzeris, Professor Marc Auriacombe, Doctor Anjali Bhardwaj, Professor Maurice Dematteis, Professor Apo Demirkol, Doctor Mark Hardy, Doctor Mary Ellen Harrod, Associate Professor Kok-Eng Khor, Doctor Llewellyn Mills, Doctor Jonathan Penm, Mr Arshman Sahid, Doctor Fuschia Serre, Mr Justin Sinclair

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Preclinical Evaluation of a Novel Analgesic to Improve Pain Relief for People with a Current or Past Opioid Use Disorder
Project Summary: The proposed Research has the potential to deliver major clinical impact for pain sufferers in Australia and globally. A multidisciplinary approach underpinned by key preliminary data will address the large unmet medical need for a novel strong painkiller with minimal abuse/misuse liability to both alleviate and prevent moderate to severe pain in people with a current or past opioid use disorder (OUD). Results arising from this Research could greatly assist in curbing the opioid crisis.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Craig Williams, Emeritus Professor Maree Smith, Professor Michael Berk, Professor Jennifer Cornish, Ms Nicolette Ellis, Associate Professor Susannah Tye
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: The feasibility, acceptability and impact of integrating an online pain management course into alcohol and other drug residential rehabilitation services.
Project Summary: Chronic pain and substance use disorders are among the most prevalent, debilitating, and costly health conditions globally. However, there have been few attempts to manage both conditions in parallel. The proposed study will use a mixed methods approach to codesign an optimal implementation strategy and assess the feasibility and acceptability of integrating an established online, clinician-assisted pain management program into alcohol and other drug residential services.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Gabrielle Campbell, Professor Amanda Baker, Doctor Anthony Barnett, Professor Jason Connor, Professor Blake Dear, Professor Louisa Degenhardt, Professor Leanne Hides, Associate Professor Julia Lappin, Doctor Briony Larance, Miss Carmen Chia Wern Lim, Doctor Nina Pocuca, Doctor Robert Stirling, Doctor Zoe Walter, Associate Professor Katie Witkiewitz
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Co-designing pain management with people in opioid dependence treatment
Project Summary: One in two people in opioid agonist treatment has current chronic pain. Yet, despite the high prevalence, pain is often undertreated. One key reason is that people in opioid agonist treatment are usually excluded form most pain management services. This creates a critical need for effective and accessible pain management programs that can be delivered in settings that minimise barriers to care. We will codesign a pain management program with consumers and health experts to address this gap.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Suzanne Nielsen, Associate Professor Claire Ashton-James, Doctor Ali Cheetham, Ms Clare Davies, Professor Paul Dietze, Doctor Rhiannon Dowla, Professor Paul Glare, Associate Professor Peter Higgs, Associate Professor Megan Lim, Ms Sarah Lord, Doctor Paul Maccartney, Associate Professor Bridin Murnion, Doctor Louisa Picco, Doctor Bosco Rowland, Ms Jie Yang

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Novel Treatments and Management Strategies for Chronic Pain
Project Name: Immuno-analgesics: Regulatory T-cell immunotherapies for pain management in complex regional pain syndrome
Project Summary: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) is a rare chronic pain condition that occurs after a limb injury. Symptoms include severe pain, swelling, and sensitivity. Current treatments are ineffective, and Research suggests an autoimmune link. We propose testing new immunotherapies that boost regulatory T cells, which reduce inflammation and relieve pain, using a humanised mouse model of CRPS. This project will provide critical evidence for advancing to small-scale clinical trials in CRPS patients.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Gila Moalem-Taylor, Associate Professor Paul Austin, Doctor Nick Christelis, Professor Peter Drummond, Doctor Colleen Johnston-Devin, Associate Professor Joanne Reed, Doctor Kerrie Sandgren

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Novel Treatments and Management Strategies for Chronic Pain
Project Name:
Development of novel allosteric 
modulators for the treatment of chronic 
pain
Project Summary: Chronic pain is very common with one in five Australians suffering from long-term pain that is serious enough to  cause disability. This type of pain is difficult to treat and most medicines come with side effects and don’t provide adequate relief in most cases. This project will focus on identifying new ways to treat pain and will develop new therapeutics that are safer and more effective.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Wendy Imlach, Professor Arthur Christopoulos, Doctor Steven Miller, Professor Peter Scammells, Professor David Spanswick, Associate Professor Celine Valant

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Novel Treatments and Management Strategies for Chronic Pain
Project Name: Automated screening of in vitro patient avatars for endometriosis treatment selection
Project Summary: Endometriotic lesions create chronic pain through an inflammatory mediated interaction with the nervous system. This inflammatory reaction however is different for each patient. We plan to use laboratory models of individual endometriotic lesions for each patient, scale these to create efficient testing procedures and use them to advance novel treatments and integrate these into clinics as improved management strategies.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Brett McKinnon, Associate Professor Akwasi Amoako, Professor Kaylene Simpson, Doctor Sugarniya Subramaniam, Jessica Taylor

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Novel Treatments and Management Strategies for Chronic Pain
Project Name: PainED-CP: Co-Creating an Innovative Pain Education Intervention for Children with Cerebral Palsy
Project Summary: Up to 75% of children with cerebral palsy experience pain. Pain has been poorly managed in this vulnerable group who have unique and complex challenges; our priority is to change this. Pain education is an essential part of effective management, yet is not available for children with cerebral palsy. We will partner with children and families to develop new and engaging ways to provide pain education for children with a range of abilities, to improve important outcomes for children and families.

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Novel Treatments and Management Strategies for Chronic Pain
Project Name:
The OPTIMISE Feasibility Trial: 
OPTIMIsing treatment of chronic pain after whiplash injury using StressModEx.
Project Summary: Chronic whiplash pain is notoriously difficult to treat. Guideline recommended treatment of physiotherapy exercise has only small effects and does not take psychological distress into account. This trial will assess the feasibility of a optimised physiotherapist-led treatment that integrates physical and psychological care, and a new physiotherapist training model to deliver this care. It will pilot processes for a future large scale clinical trial that tests clinical and cost-effectiveness.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Michele Sterling, Doctor Nigel Armfield, Doctor Katherine Brain, Mrs Ana Paula Carvalho-e-Silva, Professor Luke Connelly, Associate Professor Melissa Day, Doctor Rutger de Zoete, Doctor Rachel Elphinston, Doctor Sabrina Lenzen, Doctor Karime Mescouto, Christopher Papic

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Novel Treatments and Management Strategies for Chronic Pain
Project Name:
Gut theRapy for the Alleviation of 
Chronic pElvic pain: The GRACE Trial
Project Summary: Our Grace Trial aims to investigate a new, novel treatment option for people living with Chronic Pelvic Pain (CPP). We will test whether transferring gut microbiome from a healthy person into a person with CPP (i.e., a poo transplant) is a feasible treatment strategy. We will also test if poo transplants can improve some of the common symptoms of CPP including pain, as well as mental and physical health, to help people get back to their level of everyday functioning before they had CPP.

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Novel Treatments and Management Strategies for Chronic Pain
Project Name:
Yarning through pain: A pilot study of three new strategies to improve 
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander pain 
care
Project Summary: Chronic pain is a significant burden on Australian society, with greater burden on Indigenous peoples. Currently many chronic pain management services are culturally unsafe and inaccessible to many Indigenous people. This study tests a new approach to support Indigenous peoples with chronic pain on their health care journey, and support clinicians to deliver culturally safe pain care. The findings will inform a larger study to improve outcomes for more Indigenous people with chronic pain.

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Novel Treatments and Management Strategies for Chronic Pain
Project Name: The Psilocybin Efficacy and Acceptability on Cluster headache Episodes (PEACE) Trial
Project Summary: Cluster headache, known for their severe pain, affect one in 2,000 people, placing a high burden on both personal well-being and healthcare costs. The PEACE trial, guided by consumer insights, will test generic psilocybin’s safety and efficacy in preventing these headaches through a rigorous, multi-center, placebo-controlled study. This Research could provide a new, effective treatment option for cluster headache sufferers, aiming to lessen their pain and improve their quality of life.

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Novel Treatments and Management Strategies for Chronic Pain
Project Name: A feasibility study for a clinical trial of antibiotics for chronic low back pain with modic type 1 change
Project Summary: Chronic low back pain affects 3.9 million Australians, with healthcare costs of $3.4 billion annually. Some people with chronic low back pain have changes in the bones of their spine thought to be due to a low grade bacterial infection. Using antibiotics to clear the infection is a novel promising treatment for these people. Our study will establish the feasibility of conducting a trial to definitively establish the efficacy, safety, and cost-effectiveness of this promising new treatment.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Chris Maher, Professor Johannes Alffenaar, Professor David Beard, Lars Christian Bråten, Professor Rachelle Buchbinder, Doctor Giovanni Ferreira, Professor Mark Hancock, Doctor Abigail Haynes, Doctor Caitlin Jones, Professor Chung-Wei Christine Lin, Mrs Kerry Mace, Professor John Magnussen, Professor Barend Marais, Doctor Kristy Robledo, Professor Peter Youssef

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Novel Treatments and Management Strategies for Chronic Pain
Project Name:
Matching a multidisciplinary 
management strategy to patients with chronic musculoskeletal pain: the MATCH pilot and feasibility randomised controlled trial
Project Summary:
The Queensland-wide Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy Screening Clinic and Multidisciplinary Service assists 
overburdened public hospitals by managing thousands of patients each year with musculoskeletal conditions nonsurgically. We have recently designed a new model of care for the service to better match multidisciplinary care to patients’ needs, called MATCH. We will now test if service clinicians and patients think MATCH is feasible and acceptable for use in the service in a pilot trial.

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Integrated Multidisciplinary Models of Primary Care
Project Name: Improving the Wellbeing of people with Opioid Treated Chronic Pain in Australia (I-WOTCH-AU)
Project Summary: I-WOTCH-AU is a multidisciplinary pain management program for Australians who take opioids to manage their chronic pain. The program aims to help people reduce their opioid use and improve their pain and function. The program will be tailored to Australia’s healthcare system, with input from doctors, pharmacists, nurses, and people with lived experience of chronic pain. A trial will assess its effectiveness, safety, and potential for reducing opioid-related harm in Australian primary care.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Aili Langford, Professor Zanfina Ademi, Assistant Professor Loai Albarqouni, Professor Laurent Billot, Doctor Giovanni Ferreira, Doctor Christine Mary Hallinan, Doctor Chris Hayes, Doctor Simon Holliday, Professor Chung-Wei Christine Lin, Professor James McAuley, Professor Suzanne Nielsen, Doctor Emily Reeve, Professor Harbinder Sandhu, Doctor Janney Wale

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Integrated Multidisciplinary Models of Primary Care
Project Name: Justice in Healthcare: Whole person multidisciplinary primary care for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who are in prison
Project Summary: We will develop and test a model of multidisciplinary primary care to prevent, detect and manage the holistic health needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who are in prison. We will adapt the best-practice community model of Indigenous health checks to the prison context, drawing on patient, community and clinician input, clinical audits, and health assessments, through phases of information gathering, co-design, implementation, and evaluation.

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Integrated Multidisciplinary Models of Primary Care
Project Name: Enhanced Paediatrics in Primary Care (EPiPC)
Project Summary: One in three rural Australian children start school with development, speech or physical difficulties that affect their ability to learn. Working with rural general practitioners (GPs) and families we have developed a new way of working in rural areas. The Enhanced Paediatric in Primary Care (EPiPC) program has created local teams of GPs, paediatricians, and allied health professionals who deliver early treatment to improve the development, health and wellbeing of preschool rural children.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Shannon Pike, Doctor Lahiru Amarasena, Doctor Heba Azer, Associate Professor Linda Ferrington, Doctor Nan Hu, Professor Raghu Lingam, Professor Faye McMillan AM, Ms Narelle Mills, Associate Professor Melissa Nott, Ms Kristine Pierce, Associate Professor John Preddy, Doctor Rezwanul Rana, Professor Lena Sanci, Doctor Vilas Sawrikar, Doctor David Schmidt

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Grant Opportunity: 2024 Integrated Multidisciplinary Models of Primary Care
Project Name: The Big-RIVERS Project: Regional Integrated Vision for Effective Renal Support
Project Summary: The Big-RIVERS (Regional Integrated Vision for Effective Renal Support) Project aims to implement and assess the effectiveness and impacts of a new regional, digital model of care. The project aims to enable effective care coordination for chronic conditions and improve patient journeys and health outcomes for First Nations peoples in the Big Rivers Region of the Northern Territory.
Chief Investigator Team: Ms Natasha Pavlin, Associate Professor Asanga Abeyaratne, Associate Professor Oyelola Adegboye, Professor Alan Cass, Mr Sinon Cooney, Mr Peter Gazey, Associate Professor Gillian Gorham, Doctor Matthew Hare, Doctor James Harley, Mr Peter Henwood, Associate Professor Nadarajah Kangaharan, Ms Velma King, Professor Sandawana Majoni, Doctor Sophie Pascoe

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Energy inefficiency in Long COVID and ME/CFS
Project Summary: This study looks at why some people stay very tired and sick long after COVID-19 or other infections. Known as PASC and ME/CFS, these conditions are tough to diagnose and treat. We’ll study how the body makes energy and handles stress using blood flow tests, body chemistry checks and cellular health. Wearable devices and at-home sampling will track exertion recovery. Our aim is to find the factors that culminate in different helpings to explain the diverse patient experience and common symptoms.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Christopher Armstrong, Doctor Sarah Annesley, Doctor Lily Chu, Mr David De Souza, Doctor Steve Gardner, Doctor Katherine Huang, Professor Leigh Johnston, Doctor Daniel Missailidis, Doctor Kegan Moneghetti, Ms Rebecca Morse, Professor Etheresia Pretorius, Professor David Putrino, Doctor Elena Schneider, Jaime Seltzer, Doctor Natalie Thomas

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: CRISP: Consumer-led Research Initiative on food and drink Sensitivity in PASC
Project Summary: SARS-CoV-2 can cause Long COVID (PASC), with symptoms lasting over 12 weeks. Over 10% of Australians suffer from PASC, lacking proper diagnosis and treatment, leading to dismissed symptoms and limited relief. Our consumer-led initiative studies food and drink sensitivities in PASC patients to discover novel markers of disease. These markers will help develop diagnostic biosensors to improve understanding and treatment, enhancing the quality of life for affected individuals.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Stephanie Gras, Professor Brian Abbey, Doctor Guneet Bindra, Emily Cochrane, Associate Professor Lloyd D'Orsogna, Doctor Luckshman Ganeshanandan, Professor Conor Hogan, Professor Elaine Holmes, Doctor Jenny Huang, Doctor Saimon Moraes Silva, Professor Kirsty Short

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Real-World Impacts of Post-Acute Sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC): A Quantitative Study of Metabolic Health post-COVID in Busselton, WA
Project Summary: This research project will study how COVID-19 affects the body long-term, focusing on Post-Acute Sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC). Using unique data from the Busselton Health Study in Western Australia, researchers will compare metabolic changes before and after COVID infection, and with or without PASC symptoms to identify biological markers of PASC. This work aims to better understand, diagnose, and treat PASC, which affects many Australians and often goes unrecognized by healthcare providers.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Jeremy Nicholson, Doctor Jennie Hui, Associate Professor Michael Hunter, Doctor Nathan Lawler, Doctor Samantha Lodge, Doctor Reika Masuda, Doctor Luke Whiley, Professor Julien Wist, Professor Bu Yeap

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Investigating biomarkers and driver mechanisms of Post-acute Sequalae of COVID-19 (PASC)
Project Summary:
Long COVID, also known as Post-Acute Sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC), affects many people even after they
recover from the initial infection with SARS-CoV-2, causing ongoing health issues. Our research aims to find
specific markers in the blood and understand the underlying causes of these long-term symptoms. By identifying
these factors, our team hope to develop new diagnostics and treatments to improve the lives of those suffering from
PASC.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Chansavath Phetsouphanh, Doctor Sara Ballouz, Professor Bruce Brew, Ms Sonia Bustamante, Doctor David Darley, Doctor Mark Donoghoe, Professor Gregory Dore, Doctor Jessica Kauhausen, Professor Anthony Kelleher, Doctor Ki Wook Kim, Doctor Michael Peluso

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: An Experimental Medicine Approach to Understand the Mechanisms Underpinning the Post-Acute Sequelae of COVID-19
Project Summary: In order to develop improved treatments there is an urgent need to better understand what causes Long COVID in some people following SARS-CoV-2 infection. A recent study revealed that metformin, an already approved drug typically prescribed to patients with diabetes, significantly reduces the risk of developing Long COVID, but it is not known how or why. Here, we will investigate what changes metformin induces in Long COVID patients which will help us understand the causes of Long COVID.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor David Lynn, Doctor Simone Barry, Professor Maria Crotty, Professor Jonathan Gleadle, Ms Debrah Jaggard, Doctor Anthony Khoo, Doctor Miriam Lynn, Doctor Kisani Manuel, Doctor Angela Molga, Associate Professor Renjy Nelson

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Organisation: The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research
Project Name: Defining IL-6 family cytokine signalling to identify better treatment options for long COVID
Project Summary: Long COVID causes lasting organ damage due to persistent inflammation. IL-6 family cytokines are known to drive fibrosis, blood vessel dysfunction, and iron imbalance, and may therefore critically contribute to long COVID disease outcomes. This project aims at identifying their cellular sources, effects, and relevance to human disease. Using advanced mouse models and patient data, it aims to provide critical foundational knowledge to inform treatment strategies for maximal clinical benefit.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Marcel Doerflinger, Doctor Cavan Bennett, Doctor Rory Bowden, Doctor Emily Eriksson, Doctor Ka Yee Fung, Doctor Stefanie Mendes Bader, Professor Anthony Papenfuss, Associate Professor Tracy Putoczki, Doctor Maria Tanzer

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Predictors of PASC: International big data discovery and machine learning cross-validation in the Australian OUTcomes Post COVID (OUTPOST) cohort study
Project Summary: Some people experience prolonged symptoms after an infection, while others recover quickly. This variation is not fully understood due to the need for large sample sizes for robust predictions. Our consumer co-designed project will analyse predictors of post-infective fatigue using a large, pooled international sample and apply the results to the largest Australian Long COVID study. This will help understand who develops Long COVID and why, aiding doctors, patients, and policymakers.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Lucette Cysique, Doctor Joanne Carson, Associate Professor Erin Cvejic, Professor Andrew Lloyd, Professor Lena Sanci, Doctor Carolina Sandler, Doctor Miranda Smith, Doctor Braulio Mark Valencia Arroyo, Professor Vegard Wyller

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: PERCEIVE-Outreach: A Scalable, Risk-Based Model for Managing Persistent Cardiovascular Impact in Long COVID
Project Summary: Long COVID can cause lasting health issues, including breathlessness and fatigue months after infection. We developed and tested a multidisciplinary intervention combining exercise and medical care and found it improved patients’ functional capacity. This research will work with patients and health experts to expand this program nationally using a risk-based, fully remote approach. Our goal is to reduce health burden, lower costs, and improve quality of life for those with Long COVID.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Quan Huynh, Associate Professor Melinda Carrington, Associate Professor Verity Cleland, Ms Margaret Deerain, Professor David Dunstan, Associate Professor Erin Howden, Professor Ralph Maddison, Professor Thomas Marwick, Associate Professor Kerryn Pike, Professor Janette Radford, Doctor Andrew Ridge, Professor Paul Scuffham, Ms Susanne Tegen, Mrs Kristyn Whitmore

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: BEACON Model of Care: Bridging Evidence and Care for Optimised Outcomes for PASC
Project Summary: The BEACON model of care offers an innovative, service-based clinical pathway designed to bridge the gap between primary and specialist care through targeted education and peer-to-peer learning. It will also deliver scalable, evidence-based, and personalised treatments to people living with long COVID, helping them access the right care, closer to home. Its effectiveness will be tested in a national trial to ensure it truly improves care quality and health outcomes for those affected.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Oyungerel Byambasuren, Doctor Mina Bakhit, Professor Andrew Bonney, Gary Deed, Doctor Elsa Dent, Doctor Daniel Ewald, Professor Steven Faux, Professor Paul Glasziou, Professor Michelle Guppy, Associate Professor Mark Jones, Doctor Su Mon Kyaw-Myint, Doctor Darryn Marks, Doctor Suzanne McDonald, Professor James McGree, Professor Mark Morgan, Associate Professor Jane Nikles, Professor Julie Redfern, Doctor Pippa Yeoman, Professor Nicholas Zwar
