MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: SAGE – Scalable Allied health and General practitioner rEsponses to Long-COVID in primary care.
Project Summary: People with Post-Acute Sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC) suffer with disabling symptoms like fatigue, brain fog and breathlessness. The SAGE trial will provide education and training to upskill GPs, practice nurses, allied health professionals, as well as patients, in the diagnosis and care of PASC. A new model of care will be tested comparing multidisciplinary symptom-focused rehabilitation (physical therapy and psychological support) compared to self-directed management in primary care.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Carolina Sandler, Professor Andrew Baillie, Professor Bernie Bissett, Associate Professor Erin Cvejic, Associate Professor Lucette Cysique, Professor Sarah Dennis, Doctor Jacqueline Epps, Professor Elizabeth Halcomb, Professor Rowena Ivers, Doctor Matthew Jones, Professor Andrew Lloyd, Doctor Carolyn Mazariego, Associate Professor Joel Rhee, Doctor Marie-Claire Seeley, Doctor Eng Joo Tan

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: Developing a new model of care for post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 in Culturally and Linguistically Diverse communities of Australia
Project Summary: This project aims to create a new model of care for culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) communities affected by post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 (PASC). The findings will help shape clinical guidelines and policy decisions, ensuring healthcare responses are fair and tailored to the varied needs of Australia's diverse population. By engaging communities directly, the project ensures that healthcare is inclusive, effective, and accessible for all.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Kefyalew Alene, Dylan Barth, Professor Christopher Blyth, Professor Jaya Dantas, Doctor Beth Gilmour, Associate Professor Hannah Moore, Doctor Belaynew Taye, Ms Salem Tegegn, Associate Professor Gizachew Tessema, Doctor Getinet Yaya

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: CONCORD: Co-designing a Novel Care Model for Culturally and Linguistically Diverse Communities
Project Summary: Long COVID affects 3-10% of Australians, with a greater impact on Culturally and Linguistically Diverse (CALD) population who are less likely to access care. In this study, we will partner with CALD communities, cultural organisations, and primary care providers to develop a model that helps CALD patients recognise long COVID symptoms and supports doctors in managing these patients effectively. This will ensure accessible and equitable health outcomes for CALD Australians with long COVID.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Ruby Biezen, Professor Douglas Boyle, Professor Kirsty Buising, Doctor Samantha Chakraborty, Ms Kerrie Chapman, Professor Wendy Chapman, Associate Professor Patty (Panagiota) Chondros, Doctor Sandra Davidson, Doctor Terri Dentry, Doctor Andrew Donald, Doctor Ann-Marie Duncan, Doctor Amireh Fakhouri, Doctor Katherine Gibney, Doctor Kristen Glenister, Ms Elham Hafiz, Professor Martin Hensher, Associate Professor Danielle Hitch, Doctor Jenny Huang, Doctor Barbara Hunter, Professor Lata Jayaram, Ms Gauri Kapoor, Mr Adrian Laughlin, Mrs Kate Macheda, Doctor Caroline McBride, Associate Professor Craig Nelson, Doctor Michael Pellegrini, Doctor Tegan Podubinski, Associate Professor Megan Rees, Professor Catherine Said, Professor Lena Sanci, Leigh Seidel Marks, Doctor Miranda Smith, Doctor Matthew Suen, Miss Emma Tindill, Doctor Emma Tippett, Doctor Trang Vu, Associate Professor Kylie Vuong, Doctor Joanne Wrench

MRFF Initiative: Emerging Priorities and Consumer Driven Research
Project Name: RECOVER trial – Restoring Energy and Capacity in Older adults via Embedded Rehabilitation
Project Summary: Frail older people are more likely to experience long-term effects known as Post Acute Sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC), which can harm their independence and quality of life. This project aims to test a flexible, effective model of care for these individuals. Partnering with aged care organisations, the study will assess its success and ensure it meets the needs of older people. By training the workforce and evaluating effectiveness and implementation, the project seeks to improve health outcomes.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Kate Laver, Associate Professor Zoe Adey-Wakeling, Doctor Shailesh Bihari, Professor Ian Cameron, Professor Gillian Caughey, Professor Maria Crotty, Stephanie Daly, Doctor Rik Dawson, Professor Stacey George, Associate Professor Stephanie Harrison, Professor Gillian Harvey, Ms Katrina Jarratt, Professor Susan Kurrle, Doctor Subbuh Luker, Doctor Irina Majumder, Doctor Kisani Manuel, Associate Professor Rachel Milte, Ms Helen Radoslovich, Doctor Miia Rahja, Professor Geraint Rogers, Associate Professor Shahid Ullah, Associate Professor Craig Whitehead, Doctor Stephanie Wong

Project Name: Development of a novel diagnostic approach enabling the early detection of bronchiectasis in children: a multicentre cohort study with external validation
Project Summary: Our consumer co-designed prospective cohort study addresses the current problem of the delayed diagnosis of bronchiectasis in children, especially in Indigenous children living in remote communities. Through our multicentre cohort of 550 children, we will develop a diagnostic algorithm enriched with a blood marker to enhance accuracy. If successful, this approach could be transformative. Our study responds to identified consumer priorities and builds on current initiatives.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Anne Chang, Doctor Vikas Goyal, Emeritus Professor Keith Grimwood, Associate Professor Julie Marchant, Professor Steven McPhail, Professor Anna Nathan, Doctor Hannah O'Farrell, Doctor Marion Sanchez, Professor Andre Schultz, Professor Hiran Selvadurai, Mrs Lesley Versteegh, Associate Professor Charl Verwey, Professor Stephanie Yerkovich

Project Name: ELITE: Early Detection of Lung Disease to Improve Lifelong Trajectories
Project Summary: Low lung function in childhood is a significant predictor of chronic lung disease in adulthood. However, we currently lack sensitive lung function tests that be applied in young children. This project will provide the evidence needed to implement sensitive, easy-breathing lung function tests into the clinic. Early detection of lung function impairment will allow treatments to be offered in childhood to preserve lifelong lung health, reduce risk of chronic disease, and prevent premature death.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Kathryn Ramsey, Mrs Amber Bates, Doctor Tamara Blake, Doctor Cassidy Du Berry, Doctor David Hancock, Emeritus Professor Zoltan Hantos, Mrs Michelle Johnson, Doctor Marshall Makate, Professor Paul Robinson, Professor Philip Robinson, Associate Professor Shannon Simpson, Professor Peter Sly, Doctor Elizabeth Smith, Doctor Sanja Stanojevic, Judy Wettenhall

Project Name: Enhancing the Management of Chronic Respiratory Conditions in Primary Care
Project Summary: Community pharmacy is the common destination for consumers seeking symptom management support for chronic airway diseases. Many patients with limited diagnoses are treated for symptoms using over the counter products. Our project will have a co-design phase involving stakeholders, a case finding study in community pharmacies, a 12-month trial in general practice evaluating a care model using artificial intelligence for improving diagnostic accuracy, followed by cost effectiveness analysis.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Johnson George, Associate Professor Eli Dabscheck, Doctor Alana Delaforce, Ms Kali Godbee, Professor Mark Hew, Doctor Rajiv Jayasena, Doctor Sankalp Khanna, Associate Professor Joy Lee, Professor Ajay Mahal, Doctor Eldho Paul, Professor Gregory Peterson, Professor Janette Radford, Professor Bandana Saini, Doctor Tin Fei Sim, Doctor Justin Turner

Project Name: Transforming Paediatric Respiratory Care with X-ray Velocimetry Functional Lung Imaging
Project Summary: X-ray Velocimetry (XV) enables assessment of lung ventilation in patients from infancy to adulthood. It can detect early changes in lung disease prior to standard lung function tests, providing opportunities to diagnose disease earlier and measure treatment responses. This project will build on pre-clinical XV studies, measure its utility in three children’s lung conditions, explore the effects of treatment on disease progression, and develop AI approaches to mine the large datasets acquired.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Martin Donnelley, Associate Professor Kristin Carson-Chahhoud, Doctor Dhani Dharmaprani, Doctor Nina Eikelis, Professor Andreas Fouras, Reanna Gray, Doctor Jennie Louise, Associate Professor David Parsons, Doctor Nicole Reyne, Doctor Ronan Smith, Associate Professor Andrew Tai

Project Name: Predicting Chronic Lung Allograft Dysfunction: A Multi-Omics and AI-Driven Approach to Improve Long-Term Outcomes
Project Summary: Lung transplants save lives, but long-term survival is limited due to chronic lung allograft dysfunction (CLAD), a condition that damages the transplanted lung and leads to early death. This project aims to identify biological markers and patterns linked to CLAD using advanced molecular analysis. We will use this data to build an AI model to predict CLAD early, helping doctors improve outcomes. By tackling CLAD, we aim to make lung transplants a lasting cure, not just a temporary solution.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Benjamin Marsland, Mrs Giulia Iacono, Wendy Jenkins, Mr Matthew Macowan, Professor Glen Westall
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

Project Name: Preterm associated lung disease: identifying proteomic signatures of distinct respiratory phenotypes (PINPOINT)
Project Summary: Many people that were born early, or preterm, will develop multiple types of lung disease by the time they are adults. We do not know why some people born early develop ongoing and overlapping disease, or how to treat it. In this project we will test hundreds of proteins in the blood, called proteomics, to understand what changes are happening in the body of those that experience poor lung health after preterm birth. This helps us to better identify and treat lung disease in people born early.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Denby Evans, Professor John Blakey, Ms Tiffany Bradshaw, Doctor Maria Rosa Faner, Doctor James Gibbons, Doctor Prue Pereira-Fantini, Mr Wayne Ratajczak, Associate Professor Shannon Simpson, Doctor Elizabeth Smith, Doctor Sanja Stanojevic, Professor David Tingay
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

Project Name: Characterising the immunometabolic mechanisms of disease in people with concomitant asthma and COPD
Project Summary:
People with concomitant asthma and COPD have poor health outcomes and no effective treatments. Targeting metabolic factors, such as sugars or fats, that fuel immune cell inflammation may help treat disease.
This study will bring together a team of experts in metabolism and lung disease to characterise how metabolic factors cause concomitant asthma and COPD. This study will also identify and test new therapies that target metabolic factors for the treatment of concomitant asthma and COPD.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Jay Horvat, Yusuf Ali, Doctor Bronwyn Berthon, Doctor Alexandra Brown, Doctor Kurtis Budden, Professor Murray Cairns, Doctor Simon Chiu, Professor Anne Dixon, Associate Professor Christopher Grainge, Doctor Stephen Milne, Professor Matthew Poynter, Doctor Hayley Scott, Doctor Evan Williams, Assistant Professor Siu Ling Wong, Professor Lisa Wood
Field(s) of Research (DIVISION / Group /: Pending

Project Name: Eliminating Exacerbations: finding targeted treatments for multiple chronic respiratory conditions
Project Summary:
Viral exacerbations cause significant illness and death in chronic respiratory diseases like preschool wheeze and COPD, worsening quality of life and accelerating disease progression. This project aims to uncover the molecular causes of these flare-ups using advanced stem cell models, identifying shared and unique disease mechanisms.
We will then use drug screening to find targeted therapies, offering a new path to effective treatments for viral exacerbations across respiratory conditions
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Rhiannon Werder, Doctor Alejandro Hidalgo-Gonzalez, Doctor Sean Humphrey, Doctor Christine Keenan, Doctor Melanie Neeland, Doctor Sanjay Ramakrishnan, Professor Mirana Ramialison, Professor Sarath Ranganathan, Associate Professor Fernando Rossello, Doctor Shivanthan Shanthikumar, Professor Edouard Stanley

Project Name: Improving Asthma Outcomes for First Nations Pregnant Mothers: A Co-designed Implementation Strategy
Project Summary: Women with asthma often have worse symptoms of asthma while they are pregnant. First Nations mothers are even more at risk for worsening symptoms which can affect their baby. Our project aims to improve First Nations mother’s asthma control by treating their asthma using culturally safe management plans, which will lead to better health outcomes for both mothers and their babies.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Helen Petsky, Professor Vicki Clifton, Doctor Kerry Hall, Professor Andrea Marshall, Associate Professor Jamie Ranse, Associate Professor Rachel Walker, Professor Stephanie Yerkovich

Project Name: Improving access to effective non-pharmacological care for people with COPD in rural Australia (R2EACH)
Project Summary: For people with chronic lung disease, pulmonary rehabilitation improves symptoms and function and helps reduce healthcare costs. Yet program access is severely limited in rural Australia. This work will explore whether supporting pulmonary rehabilitation delivery directly into people’s homes in rural Australia improves program access. If more people can access, thus benefit from, pulmonary rehabilitation health system costs could be reduced.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Narelle Cox, Doctor Angela Burge, Doctor Lauren Christie, Associate Professor Eli Dabscheck, Professor Anne Holland, Doctor Arwel Jones, Professor Jessica Kasza, Professor Natasha Lannin, Associate Professor Gabrielle McCallum, Professor Christine McDonald, Professor Michael Stickland, Associate Professor Annkarin Wong Shee

Project Name: Unglamorous but essential: Ensuring the efficacy of inhaled therapies in rural and remote Indigenous communities
Project Summary: In rural and remote areas, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities face challenges in accessing support for chronic lung disease, including cultural barriers and lack of resources. A partnership with Aboriginal communities provides an opportunity to develop a model for supporting self-administration of inhaled therapies, led by Aboriginal Health Workers (AHWs), to improve health outcomes.

Project Name: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships for Paediatric Lung health Excellence (APPLE-3) study
Project Summary: We will conduct a clinical trial where 20 clinics are randomised to receive an intervention at different times. The intervention is a bundle of strategies to improve how doctors detect and mange chronic wet cough in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children. We know that timely detection and optimal management of chronic wet cough in children can prevent lifelong chronic disease. A successful methodology that facilitates such management could help children nationally.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Andre Schultz, Melanie Barwick, Professor Gareth Baynam, Professor Anne Chang, Doctor Matthew Cooper, Doctor Steven Mascaro, Professor Richard Norman, Professor Smita Shah, Doctor Cara Sheppard, Professor Maree Toombs, Mrs Lesley Versteegh

Project Name: PEAChY-D: Pharmacological Emergency management of Agitation in Children and Young adults – a pilot trial of Dexmedetomidine versus olanzapine
Project Summary: Agitation is a common reason for people to present to the emergency department for care. This is a high risk condition as those experiencing agitation can harm themselves and others. Having a treatment which helps these individuals to feel calm is a high priority. This study aims to look at whether it is practical to compare a new medication called dexmedetomidine to a medication we are currently using called olanzapine to help treat agitation in the emergency department setting.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Elyssia Bourke, Professor Franz Babl, Professor Simon Craig, Professor Andrew Davidson, Doctor Jeremy Furyk, Associate Professor Michael Gordon, Associate Professor Jonathan Knott, Professor Katherine Lee, Mr Chris Selman, Doctor Yen Ling (Celene) Yap

Project Name: NSAID administration Or Theatre Benzodiazepine Avoidance for Delirium & Days Alive and at Home
Project Summary: Delirium is distressing for patients and affects up to 50% of hospitalised older adults. It is associated with increased death, complications and prolonged stays in hospital as well as increased costs. It lacks treatments. We propose a pilot, blinded, multicentre, randomised controlled trial that will test the feasibility of a three-arm trial of two postoperative delirium prevention strategies that focus on two routinely administered therapies.

Project Name: Empowering Choice: pilot of a novel co-produced supported and shared decision-making model for early psychosis
Project Summary: Neither shared nor supported decision-making is currently implemented well or consistently in early psychosis services, to the detriment of patients’ rights and clinical outcomes. The Choices Study offers a powerful step forward towards a more inclusive, person-centred, and recovery-oriented approach to supporting young people experiencing psychosis. We will investigate the feasibility of Choices in a pilot cluster trial involving 56 participants.

Project Name: The Highly Effective and Radiation-Sparing Therapies in Younger Glioblastoma Patients (HEARTY) pilot study
Project Summary: The standard treatment with newly diagnosed glioblastoma (GBM), a rare brain tumour, is immediate radiotherapy and chemotherapy after diagnostic surgery. We will test a new approach for such patients who will have their tumours rapidly screened with existing technology to identify three subsets of patients whose tumours should be highly sensitive to existing therapies. We will test whether these patients can be better treated with these drugs rather than chemo-radiation.

Project Name: OrCaS - Organoids for Cancer Screening: Mucinous ovarian carcinoma
Project Summary: We will evaluate a method that will test cancer therapies using cells from the same patient in a rare ovarian cancer type. If successful, patients will have a pathway for personalised medicine, meaning they will receive a therapy that will work for them, overcoming the difficulties clinicians and patients face when there is no evidence to guide care.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Kylie Gorringe, Professor Alison Brand, Doctor Rachel Delahunty, Associate Professor Orla McNally, Doctor Niveditha Rajadevan, Professor Kaylene Simpson

Project Name: The effects of dual orexin receptor antagonists on cognition, neurodegeneration and sleep in Mild Cognitive Impairment: a feasibility RCT
Project Summary: This study will assess how novel drugs targeting the orexin system, a key system regulating waking states, may have broader brain benefits for people with Mild Cognitive Impairment, a prodromal phase of Alzheimer's disease, for whom there are very few effective treatment options for slowing a) disease and b) cognitive decline. This study will provide key information needed to inform a larger effectiveness trial of these agents in this high risk group.

Project Name: A Pilot Study for the IMPACT-CRC Trial: IMPlementAtion of Cytokine-Induced Killer Cell Therapy for Metastatic ColoRectal Cancer
Project Summary: Metastatic colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths in Australia. Our team is investigating whether cytokine-induced killer (CIK) cell therapy—an immunotherapy using a patient’s own blood to create potent immune cells—can improve outcomes with standard treatments. We have developed a clinical trial protocol and seek funding for a pilot study to assess our protocol's feasibility in a hospital setting here in South Australia.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Timothy Price, Doctor Elisa Cappuzzello, Belinda Evans, Doctor Kevin Aaron Fenix, Professor Guy Maddern, Professor Antonio Rosato, Doctor Eric Smith, Assistant Professor Roberta Sommaggio, Doctor Yoko Tomita

Project Name: A master protocol for PRecision therapies In Monogenic Epilepsies (PRIME)
Project Summary: Individuals with severe and rare genetic epilepsies suffer from uncontrolled seizures and problems with development, behaviour and movement. Treatment options remain limited to antiseizure medications, which fail to fully suppress seizures and have no effect on other comorbidities. Our innovative project will test four new medicines that target the underlying genetic mechanisms (precision therapies). These precision therapies hold promise to improve the care of these devastating rare diseases.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Piero Perucca, Professor Samuel Berkovic, Doctor Josephine Chan, Doctor Deepak Gill, Associate Professor Ilias Goranitis, Associate Professor Katherine Howell, Ms Sara James, Professor Emilio Perucca, Professor Ingrid Scheffer, Associate Professor Lata Vadlamudi, Doctor Shuyu Wang

Project Name: Phase I/II Trial of Personalised mRNA Vaccine Encoding Neoantigens in Children with Advanced Brain Tumours
Project Summary: PAEDNEO-VAX aims to trial a new personalised vaccine for children with aggressive brain cancers, where current treatments have limited success. By using each child's unique tumour information to create a tailored treatment, the vaccine aims to boost their immune system to specifically target and fight the cancer. This approach seeks to improve survival and enhance the quality of life for these young patients, offering a potentially more effective and less toxic alternative to existing therapies.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Jordan Hansford, Liz Dawes, Doctor Cinzia De Luca, Doctor Andrew Dodgshun, Doctor Rebecca Goldstein, Doctor Timothy Hassall, Professor Rajiv Khanna, Doctor Cecilia Moore, Ms Robyn Strong, Doctor Santosh Valvi, Doctor Nicola Waddell, Professor Brandon Wainwright

Project Name: StepSafe: a randomised controlled trial of integrated balance and cognition training to resolve unmet need for fall prevention in Parkinson’s disease
Project Summary: Falls in people with Parkinson's disease are frequent, devastating, and the incurred health care costs are high. Our six-month StepSafe trial will test whether a home-based cognitive-motor exercise program targeting impaired stepping and cognition can reduce falls over 6 months in people with Parkinson's disease. This intervention is highly scalable and has the potential to reduce the burden of falls, improve the lives of many people living with PD and reduce associated health care costs.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Jasmine Menant, Associate Professor Natalie Allen, Professor Jane Alty, Professor Michele Callisaya, Assistant Professor Jennifer Davis, Associate Professor Brook Galna, Doctor Peter Humburg, Professor Stephen Lord, Professor Meg Morris, Doctor Yoshiro Okubo, Doctor Paulo Pelicioni, Associate Professor Daina Sturnieks, Professor Carolyn Sue

Project Name: Targeting Stroma-Promoting Pathways in Pancreatic Cancer
Project Summary: Pancreatic cancer (PC) is the fourth deadliest type of cancer, with a very low survival rate of less than 12% over five years. Our research focuses on targeting specific molecular pathways involved in fibrous tissue surrounding PC. By targeting these pathways, we aim to modify the tumour structure, making them more vulnerable to chemotherapy. This study aims to determine the safety of combining novel anti-fibrotic therapeutics, with chemotherapy for treating pancreatic cancer.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Marina Pajic, Doctor Megan Barnet, Professor Lorraine Chantrill, Associate Professor Angela Shih-Yuan Chou, Doctor Rasha Cosman, Professor Thomas Cox, Professor Anthony Gill, Professor Anthony Joshua, Doctor Frank Lin, Doctor Jia Liu, Associate Professor Adnan Nagrial, Doctor Dannel Yeo

Project Name: Families Accessing Skills Training (FAST) Treatment of Youth OCD:  A Nationwide Randomised Controlled Non-Inferiority Trial
Project Summary: Cognitive-behavioural therapy, incorporating exposure and response-prevention (CBT-ERP) is a highly effective treatment for children and young people with debilitating obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Although CBT-ERP is a highly effective treatment, the majority of young people with OCD never receive it. With the help of parents, we have developed a method of delivering CBT-ERP that harnesses the power of both parents and technology to address this serious and important unmet clinical need.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Lara Farrell, Professor Joshua Byrnes, Melanie Dalton, Professor Caroline Donovan, Doctor Katelyn Dyason, Associate Professor Neeraj Gill, Professor Jessica Grisham, Matthew McKenzie, Doctor Iain Perkes, Professor James Scott, Professor Eric Storch, Kate Strang, Professor Allison Waters, Doctor Ping Zhang, Professor Melanie Zimmer-Gembeck

Project Name: PNOC028: Phase 1 Study of Intra-Tumoral Injections of Ex Vivo Expanded Natural Killer Cells in Children and Young Adults with Recurrent or Progressive Malignant Brain Tumours
Project Summary: This study tests a new treatment for children and young adults (1-39 years) with rare, aggressive brain tumours that have returned or are not responding to current therapies. It uses modified immune cells, called NK cells, delivered directly into the tumour. The trial aims to check if the treatment is safe, determine the best dose, and explore how the cells work in the brain. If successful, this approach could improve survival and make advanced cell therapies more accessible.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Nicholas Gottardo, Professor Mohamed Abdelbaki, Belinda Brunoli, Doctor Vickyanne Carruthers, Doctor Steven Foresto, Doctor Melissa Gabriel, Doctor Dinisha Govender, Doctor Dong-Anh Khuong-Quang, Dean Lee, Doctor Marion Mateos, Professor Annette Molinaro, Shanti Ramachandran, Ms Snigdha Saha, Doctor Nataliya Zhukova

Project Name: Co-Designing, Evaluating, and Implementing Supportive Care for Adolescents and Young Adults with Crohn’s and Colitis and their Carers (CAYAC)
Project Summary: Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis are incurable and life-limiting gastrointestinal disorders, with peak onset between 15-29 years. Adolescents and young adults face the burden of disease at a critical stage of life, disrupting growth, puberty, education and psychosocial development. Over 50% report psychological distress. We will evaluate whether a psychological, restorative, movement and nutritional program improves youth and carer quality of life and mental health at 2 and 6 months.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Antonina Mikocka-Walus, Associate Professor Subhadra Evans, Associate Professor Edward Giles, Associate Professor Emma Halmos, Doctor Anna Klas, Associate Professor Simon Knowles, Doctor Emma Marshall, Associate Professor Nikki McCaffrey, Associate Professor Lisa Olive, Professor Liliana Orellana, Associate Professor Melissa O'Shea, Ms Leanne Raven, Doctor David Skvarc, Associate Professor Leesa Van Niekerk, Associate Professor Elizabeth Westrupp

Project Name: Employing radiotherapy to augment glofitamab bispecific antibody immune response in relapsed lymphoma - The Radio-GLO study
Project Summary: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) is a rare aggressive cancer. Upfront chemotherapy cures 50% of patients, but those who relapse despite this therapy (rDLBCL) face dismal outcomes. Many have difficulty accessing the best treatments at specialised centres and experience high toxicity. Our study aims to improve outcomes with an accessible, low toxicity therapy using the potential synergy of T-cell activating therapy-glofitamab, & low dose radiotherapy in rDLBCL, compared with standard care.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Eliza Hawkes, Doctor Allison Barraclough, Associate Professor Belinda Campbell, Paul Cortissos, Associate Professor Gareth Gregory, Doctor Adam Irving, Doctor Colm Keane, Doctor Richard Khor, Doctor Denise Lee, Professor Sze Ting Lee, Doctor Kate Manos, Professor Zoe McQuilten, Associate Professor Claudia Rutherford, Professor Andrew Scott, Doctor Joel Wight

Project Name: The KOBRA trial: Improving Knee Osteoarthritis outcomes in young adults with a BRAce
Project Summary: In young adults (<40 years), osteoarthritis commonly occurs following knee reconstruction, forcing them to live with ‘old knees’ and reducing their quality of life. There are no effective treatments for young adults with osteoarthritis. In a clinical trial, we will determine whether a simple and universally accessible option (a slim-fit knee brace) can improve knee pain and quality of life, and prevent joint deterioration in 312 young adults with early osteoarthritis after knee reconstruction.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Adam Culvenor, Doctor Andrea Bruder, Michael Callaghan, Doctor Hannah Carter, Professor Kay Crossley, Professor Rana Hinman, Doctor Kathryn Mills, Doctor Hayden Morris, Professor Marcus Pandy, Doctor Brooke Patterson, Professor Richard Souza, Professor Emmanuel Stamatakis, Associate Professor Natasha Stanton, Associate Professor Marienke van Middelkoop, Associate Professor Nicole White

Project Name: Precision medicine Adaptive Network Platform Trial in Hypoxemic acute respiratory failure PANTHER
Project Summary: Patients in the intensive care unit (ICU) who are mechanically ventilated can develop leaking of fluid into the lungs and lung failure - called adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). This is carries a very high risk of death. Inflammation is a key cause. There are currently no effective drug treatments against this.  In this trial, patients will receive new drug treatments based on the type of inflammation they have. We aim to determine if several new medications can improve patients lives.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Aidan Burrell, Doctor Christopher Andersen, Ms Anais Charles-Nelson, Professor John Fraser, Doctor Alisa Higgins, Professor Carol Hodgson, Professor Danny McAuley, Doctor Elissa Milford, Professor Alistair Nichol, Associate Professor Emma Ridley, Doctor Elizabeth Ryan, Doctor Ary Serpa Neto, Professor Steve Webb

Project Name: Combining Azacitidine and Subasumstat to TReat TP53 mutant Acute Myeloid Leukaemia- the ASTRA trial
Project Summary: This study aims to explore the combination of subasumstat and azacitidine (AZA) as a treatment for patients with TP53 mutant acute myeloid leukemia, which currently have no effective therapies. TP53 mutations are common in chemotherapy-resistant or relapsed cases, and standard treatments often fail. The study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of subasumstat with AZA in these patients through a phase 1 dose-finding study, followed by a phase 2 trial.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor John Pimanda, Hussein Abbas, Professor Stefan Bohlander, Associate Professor Naval Daver, Associate Professor Anoop Enjeti, Doctor Paula Gonzalez Figueroa, Professor Mark Hertzberg, Doctor Christopher Jolly, Professor Richard Lock, Professor Jake Olivier, Doctor Jad Othman, Professor Mark Polizzotto, Doctor Jonathan Roco Alegre, Yogen Saunthararajah, Doctor Julie Thoms

Project Name: Towards eliminating low-value cardiovascular care: the PUMA Trial.
Project Summary: An invasive device, the pulmonary artery catheter (PAC), is frequently used to guide treatments in open heart surgery. PACs often generate inaccurate data, triggering unnecessary and risky interventions that may harm patients. PUMA is a world-first clinical trial comparing PACs to a simpler, less invasive alternative called a central venous catheter. Our findings could improve outcomes for heart surgery patients by eliminating unnecessary, low-value, and potentially unsafe treatments.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Rinaldo Bellomo, Professor Zanfina Ademi, Professor Michael Bailey, Professor Jayme Bennetts, Ms Paige Druce, Professor Mario Gaudino, Professor Silvana Marasco, Associate Professor Lachlan Miles, Professor Stephen Nicholls, Doctor Luke Perry, Doctor Sanne Peters, Professor Philip Peyton, Professor Christobel Saunders, Doctor Emily See, Professor Julian Smith

Project Name: Comparative Effectiveness of Buffered Solutions versus Saline for  Intravenous Fluid Therapy in Critically ill Children:  The RESONANCE-PICU Multicentre, Binational Randomised Controlled Trial
Project Summary: Every year, over 12,000 children are admitted to intensive care in Australia and New Zealand. Most receive intravenous fluids, usually saline, which may increase the risk of kidney injury and other poor outcomes. This study will compare saline to buffered fluids, which may be safer. Using hospital registry data, we will run a large trial to find out which fluid leads to better outcomes for critically ill children and helps guide safer care.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Sainath Raman, Professor Warwick Butt, Doctor Simon Erickson, Doctor Marino Festa, Professor Kristen Gibbons, Doctor Patricia Gilholm, Mia Jones, Professor Deborah Long, Jayashree Muralidharan, Associate Professor Matthew Semler, Alyssa Serratore, Anthony Slater, Professor Haitham Tuffaha, Professor Bala Venkatesh, Professor Paul Young

Project Name: STEP-PD: STarting incrEmental Prescription of Peritoneal Dialysis
Project Summary: Kidney failure is fatal without dialysis. Peritoneal dialysis (PD) completed at home offers greater flexibility and autonomy for patients . However, PD is often prescribed for 24 hours/day, 7 days/week for every patient starting dialysis. This practice is not evidence-informed, may be unnecessary and potentially harmful. The STEP-PD trial aims to determine the optimal approach to commencing patients on PD through starting at low dose PD and incrementing over time.

Project Name: A randomised double-blinded comparative effectiveness trial to determine the optimal intravenous treatment for children with severe exacerbations of asthma
Project Summary:
Most children with asthma who are treated in emergency departments respond to simple first-line treatment (inhaled medications, oral steroids and low-flow oxygen). Children who do not respond to this treatment often require intravenous (IV) medications. However, we do not know which of these medications is best.
This trial will compare two different IV treatment options (magnesium and aminophylline) for children with asthma to determine the best initial treatment, and best sequence of treatments.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Simon Craig, Professor Franz Babl, Professor Meredith Borland, Doctor Catherine Byrnes, Professor Stuart Dalziel, Doctor Shane George, Charmaine Gray, Associate Professor AMIT KOCHAR, Doctor Nancy Kong, Associate Professor Elliot Long, Doctor Mark Lyttle, Associate Professor Gillian Nixon, Mrs Francesca Orsini, Doctor Natalie Phillips, Associate Professor Emma Tavender

Project Name: protectHER: Implementing proven concussion and knee injury prevention for women/girls
Project Summary: Injury prevention programs WORK to reduce concussion and serious knee injuries in women/girls community football - but coaches/players don't use them. We designed (with players/coaches/others) activities designed to remove the barriers to, and improve the ability of coaches/players to use injury prevention programs. We will test if these activities work - in ~10,000 community women/girl Australian football and soccer players. We will also design ways to expand these activities nationwide.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Kay Crossley, Doctor Bridget Abell, Professor Christian Barton, Professor James Boyd, Doctor Andrea Bruder, Professor Peter Choong, Professor Carolyn Emery, Professor Martin Hagglund, Doctor Michael Makdissi, Professor Steven McPhail, Doctor Brooke Patterson, Associate Professor Kerry Peek, Doctor Matthew Whalan, Associate Professor Nicole White, Associate Professor Jackie Whittaker

Project Name: Testing optimal implementation strategies for the prevention of low back pain via the effective WalkBack walking and education program.
Project Summary: The primary aim of this trial is to assess and compare three strategies for increasing uptake of a proven preventive health intervention (WalkBack Intervention) for reducing the recurrence of low back pain. WalkBack is self-management program including a progressive walking and education program. An effective, large-scale rollout of the already proven WalkBack intervention would significantly reduce the burden of low back pain for the millions experiencing low back pain across Australia.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Mark Hancock, Doctor Aidan Cashin, Professor Simon French, Associate Professor Petra Graham, Doctor Hazel Jenkins, Professor Chung-Wei Christine Lin, Doctor Gustavo Machado, Professor Chris Maher, Professor Rebecca Mitchell, Doctor Natasha Pocovi, Professor Monica Taljaard, Professor Anne Tiedemann

Project Name: Implementing Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) with Prehabilitation (ERAS+)  in Routine Practice: Strategies to Optimise Surgical Care and Improve Outcomes through ERAS+.
Project Summary: Complications following cancer surgery are common and result in poor patient outcomes, including prolonged hospitalisation and increased healthcare costs. They occur due to variability in care and a failure to address modifiable risks. Enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) pathways standardise care and prehabilitation prepares people for surgery (e.g., fitness, eating well). They are not routinely used in Australia. This study will evaluate ways to implement this care so every patient benefits.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Bernhard Riedel, Doctor Ianthe Boden, Associate Professor Kate Burbury, Professor Gang Chen, Professor Linda Denehy, Doctor Lara Edbrooke, Doctor Hilmy Ismail, Associate Professor Nicole Kiss, Doctor Marlena Klaic, Associate Professor David Liu, Gregory Nelson, Associate Professor Camille Short, Doctor Jamie Waterland, Professor David Watters, Doctor Freda Werdiger

Project Name: Assessing a multi-component strategy designed to reduce low-value care for osteoarthritis.
Project Summary: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a painful condition that costs our healthcare system $4.3bn/year. The best treatments for OA are learning to self-manage, exercise, and weight control, yet, 2-in-3 people with OA are not offered this care. Some people undergo unnecessary imaging and surgical referrals, leading to surgeries they do not need and do not help them. This study will test a strategy to support health professionals to reduce the use of less helpful treatments and offer better options for knee OA.
Chief Investigator Team: Doctor Jillian Eyles, Doctor Jocelyn Bowden, Professor Andrew Briggs, Doctor Samantha Bunzli, Professor Glen Duncan, Doctor Vicky Duong, Professor David Hunter, Doctor Sarah Kobayashi, Professor Shannon Mihalko, Professor Mark Morgan, Professor Rachael Morton, Professor Nina Osteras, Associate Professor Ben Parkinson, Associate Professor Justin Roe, Associate Professor Christopher Vertullo

Project Name: Vital Steps: Implementing wearable activity trackers for better hospital outcomes
Project Summary: Researchers and clinicians are joining forces to help hospital patients move more and recover faster. After three years of collaboration, the team is launching Australia's first large-scale trial using wearable activity trackers in seven rehabilitation services as part of routine use across Southern Adelaide. The project aims to make patient movement a vital sign that's regularly monitored. For patients, this means better care. For hospitals, it means reduced costs and more efficient services.

Grant Opportunity: 2025 Incorporating Patient Data in Health Technology Assessment Decision Making
Project Name: A vaLue-based Person-centric enhanced health technology Assessment in CAncer medicine (ALPACA)
Project Summary: Cancer is the leading cause of disease burden in Australia. This project will improve how funding decisions for cancer medicines are made by focusing on what matters most to people affected by cancer. We will collect patientreported outcomes and preferences using a co-designed portal, and generate real-world evidence for breast, melanoma, and lung cancers. Working with patients, healthcare professionals, and policymakers, we aim to support fairer, more person-centred access to new treatments.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Gang Chen, Doctor Hadi Akbarzadeh Khorshidi, Associate Professor Marliese Alexander, None Sophy Athan, Professor Kim Dalziel, Professor Jayesh Desai, Associate Professor Lisa Devereux, Doctor Fanny Franchini, Professor Maarten IJzerman, Doctor Julia Lai-Kwon, Professor Grant McArthur, Doctor Ashley Ng, Associate Professor Anita Skandarajah, Professor Benjamin Solomon, Professor Karin Thursky

Grant Opportunity: 2025 Incorporating Patient Data in Health Technology Assessment Decision Making
Project Name: CORE-PROM: Co-Designing patient reported Outcomes, Repository, and Evidence for PROM integration in health technology assessment
Project Summary: We'll make patient voices count! Australia lacks a clear national approach for including patients reported outcomes in health technology assessments. Our project will co-design a framework with consumers to better capture what matters to patients, like quality of life and safety, after medicines are available. We'll develop implementation strategies, test them in real-world settings, and create an open-access library to support fairer, more transparent, and patient-focused decisions.

Grant Opportunity: 2025 Incorporating Patient Data in Health Technology Assessment Decision Making
Project Name: Valuing Emerging Central Venous Access Device Technologies through Patient-Reported Outcomes and Comparative Health Technology Assessment Research (VECTOR Study)
Project Summary: Central Venous Access Devices help deliver vital treatments but can also lead to serious complications, including infections or blood clots. Many devices are available and constantly changing; they are expensive, and their overall impact is not well understood. The VECTOR study will collect patient feedback to support decision-making between clinicians and patients; and inform which devices are funded. This knowledge will support safe, effective, efficient, and more patient-centred care.
Chief Investigator Team: Professor Joshua Byrnes, Professor Raymond Chan, Mrs Penelope Comans Inglis, Doctor Kerrie Curtis, Professor Stephen Goodall, Professor Samantha Keogh, Doctor Hansoo Kim, None Emily Larsen, Professor Nicole Marsh, Professor Brendan Mulhern, Professor Catherine Paterson, Jacinta Smith, Professor Amanda Ullman, Professor Robert Ware

Grant Opportunity: 2025 Incorporating Patient Data in Health Technology Assessment Decision Making
Project Name: PAtient-Centred Evaluation of medical devices (PACE)
Project Summary: The PACE project aims to improve how medical technologies are assessed by involving patients and communities more deeply in the process. It uses real patient experiences and consumer data to guide decisions, ensuring health policies better reflect what matters to people. Through innovative methods like citizens’ juries and living labs, PACE helps create fairer, more inclusive evaluations that value lived experience alongside economic and clinical outcomes.
Chief Investigator Team: Associate Professor Duncan Mortimer, Professor Joanna Coast, Professor Richard De Abreu Lourenco, Doctor Elizabeth Deveny, Associate Professor Bianca Devitt, Professor Anthony Harris, Dash Heath-Paynter, Professor Kirsten Howard, Professor Allison Jaure, Ms Jing-Jing Li, Ms Kristine Pierce, Professor Andrew Scott, Doctor Marcus Sellars, Kah-Ling Sia, Doctor Melanie Wyld

Grant Opportunity: 2025 Incorporating Patient Data in Health Technology Assessment Decision Making
Project Name: Societal, Health and Patient Experiences in HTA (SHAPE HTA): A framework for incorporating patient and societal preferences into HTA evaluations and the reimbursement decision-making of highly specialised technologies
Project Summary: The SHAPE HTA Framework helps assess new health technologies like gene therapies and genomic tests for funding decisions. These are hard to evaluate due to limited data and wide-ranging impacts on patients and families. SHAPE embeds patient outcomes, experiences and real-world data in health technology assessment processes to support fairer, faster, and more informed funding decisions. The aim being to improve patient access while keeping the health system sustainable.

Grant Opportunity: 2025 Incorporating Patient Data in Health Technology Assessment Decision Making
Project Name: Evaluating long-term effectiveness using real world evidence of highly specialised treatments – Cancer (EVEREST-C)
Project Summary: EVEREST-C will help decision makers to make better decisions about which cancer medicines should be publicly funded in Australia. We will create an easy-to-use living-library of real-world evidence about how medicines work in everyday life, not just in clinical trials. This will prioritise inclusion of outcomes that matter most to patients. Our goal is to provide decision-makers more accurate, patient-focused information to support smarter, fairer funding choices.

Grant Opportunity: 2025 Incorporating Patient Data in Health Technology Assessment Decision Making
Project Name: Advancing Patient Reported Outcomes in Long-Term Health Technology Assessment of Biocompatible Implantable Devices (APRO-BID)
Project Summary: This project seeks to develop novel methods and processes for the incorporation of patient reported outcomes into long-term health technology assessment of biocompatible implantable devices. Central to the project will be the patient and their carers and as such a co-design and development framework will be utilised to inform and implement the methods and processes that will be developed in this project.

Grant Opportunity: 2025 Incorporating Patient Data in Health Technology Assessment Decision Making
Project Name: My Heart, My Voice: Implementation of Patient- and Parent- Reported Outcome Measures (PROMs) for children and young people with implantable cardiac devices
Project Summary: Children with heart conditions often need multiple devices to keep their heart beating regularly, and for blood to flow and be pumped effectively. We will work together, as families with heart conditions, clinicians and registry hosts, to develop and implement a pathway for patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) to be safely and sustainably collected, used and stored in existing and future cardiac registries, so we can monitor and ensure children receive the support they need.
